title: February Frenzy
author: Steve
body:
Dave's worst nightmare: 28 teeth in the back!

The first monthly installment of the famed Flagstaff Frenzy will take place next Friday, February 25th at noon. We will meet at the Flagstaff Trailhead, where Baseline Road becomes Flagstaff Road.

See you there!

comments.comment_body:
Okay, here's a thought... A year or so ago I had a notion that folks from ITS might want to adopt Flagstaff Road, as in the Adopt-a-Highway Program. I put a little blurb in the Digital Cookie Jar, Dennis Maloney was the only guy who responded, and - being the zero gravity kind of person I am - I forgot all about it. But, ta-da!, here's another shot at it! Anyone interested? It looks really easy: http://www.dot.state.co.us/AdoptAHighway/ And the good publicity couldn't hurt, eh? Let me know; I'll happily be the point man. ...And one more thing. Would someone PLEASE PLEASE drop Steve Bailey Friday? (God knows I've tried.) 
-Dave Underwood
I'm game!  Can we tie a trailer for all the trash to Dave's bike?
I'm in on the adopt a road program, again. And one Friday I'll actually show up to get successfully dropped.

title: This Friday...Again!
author: Steve
body:
Werner, our boss, is rumored to be participating in this one. A source close to Mark has suggested that those who leave the boss behind will "regret the day they were born." Again, that rumor is unconfirmed. What is confirmed is the time we'll meet: Friday, 3/4 at 1:10pm at the Flagstaff Trail lower trailhead.

See you there!

title: Our Inaugural Ride!
author: Steve
body:
Flagstaff's Frenzied

Fueled by spite, Mark powered his way to the top of Flagstaff today. Bystanders with whom I spoke afterwards said they heard Mark uttering strange things under his breath on his way up the hill— things like: May the offspring of a thousand fleas infest the armpits of those who doubted me.

It would not surprise me either, for the almighty Flagstaff has reduced others to speaking in tongues, leaving them teetering on the brink of madness. There were only five brave souls on the mountain today, and while their mental faculties may have temporarily escaped them on the way up, they were quickly regained on the euphoric descent.

For those of you who doubted, watch your armpits...and don't act like you don't know who you are!

comments.comment_body: I made it!Yes, it's true. I made it to the top of Flagstaff! I just about turned back at the climb up past Chataqua, and then again at Mile 1. Steve Bailey and Dave Underwood took turns encouraging me. Thanks guys! I think it's a real accomplishment for me to just make it that far. There's some truth to the idea that my doubters fueled my desire to press on. It was a mixture of that and the nice encouragement from Dave and Steve. Watch the next DCJ for a picture of the group that embarked today.

Way to go Mark! Just watch out for the descents.
-lad

Friday's action started innocently enough. The pack maintained a mostly civilized demeanor as they moved in colorful array through west Boulder's ancient neighborhoods. But once on Flagstaff Mountain, things quickly degenerated into a game of cat and mouse. Leary attacked halfway up the first major climb, Dressler countered, and Underwood fell into the slipstream, already wasted, a broken man. Meanwhile, at the top of the Hole, Bailey and Werner started their bridge-up, setting a blistering pace past the cheering fans shoehorned into the hallowed confines of Panorama Point. Leary pulled strong through Die Lorelie, leaving Dressler and Underwood to patch together an uneasy alliance in response to the all-out assualt by the Bailey-Werner duo. Somewhere in the vicinity of the Snakes, the day's hitherto halcyon weather took a nasty turn, thrashing the peleton with high winds, freezing sleet, and snow. Leary's epic solo effort was now hanging by a slender Antron thread as Werner-Bailey-Dressler-Underwood hastily threw together a desperate echelon. It was on The Wall, the place where so many of cycling's past heroes have met their inner devils, that Leary made his last, furious bid for immortality, hammering his admittedly dated bike up the last few meters of that holiest of hills. 
Merckx, Hinault, Armstrong, and now Leary. 
Leary? 
- Phil Ligget, March, 2005

title: Heil Ranch Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Great showing for today's after work "spring ahead" ride (gallery)

In spite of threatening skies, eight intrepid riders braved the demanding trails of Heil Ranch. The 1200 feet of elevation gain and desiccating winds left us parched.

To further complicate things, we all started at different times, and thus found ourselves running in circles on the summit loop looking for one another. Occasionally, one group would meet up with another, but by and large we were like boyscouts on a camping trip.

Steve just sat down at the trail junction and waited for the rest, and in the end we regrouped and descended together. Thanks to everyone who came:

  • Eric
  • Dave U.
  • Noel
  • Dave C.
  • Joe
  • Sean
  • Terry
  • Steve

Hope some of you can make it out at lunch one of these days.

comments.comment_body:
NOW you're talking my kind of riding...

i'll leave the asphalt of flagstaff to you fitness freaks w/ long legs and big lungs.

give me the dirt! Heil, Hall, or White Ranch... name the day and i'll be there.

;-)

i'll be there...

also invited a couple of folks from the school of ed.

looks like great weather is in store!

terry

It's okay, Dennis.  I won't give you a hard time about it in this forum; after all, didn't some employee just get sacked after talking smack on her blog about her boss?!  See you on Flagstaff, then....

title: Pre-Giro Ride up Flagstaff
author: Steve
body:
Passo dello Stelvio in the Italian Alps

If you're all pumped for the Giro and are already having dreams of leading Cunego, Basso, and Simoni up the Colle delle Finestre and Passo dello Stelvio, then join us for a Friday Flagstaff ride.

Apart from our very own hometown celebrity, Dave Underwood, we might see some hard core cyclists getting ready for the Boulder Stage Race or even other celebrities.

Indeed, Dave and I bumped into a famous author today!

We'll meet at Telecom at 12:10p. See you there!

title: Tuesday Ride up Flagstaff at 12:10p
author: Steve
body:
Come see my new wheels...

Since Friday causes trouble for many of you, how about tomorrow 5/10 at 12:10? Dave and I will be there....who else? Those of you who said "it's too cold" this winter have no excuses now.

title: Flagstaff with Steve's Bro
author: Steve
body:
Even after riding to Ward and Ned this weekend, my bro was up for more! (gallery)

My brother was here from San Diego and wanted to see Flagstaff's serpentine pavement for himself.

Ask and ye shall receive, my brother!

title: Flagstaff Ride
author: Steve
body:
Flagstaff in 3D

To honor our comrade Dave Underwood, who's out of commission for a spell due to knee surgery, I propose a Thursday jaunt up this blog's eponymous mountain. So, let's meet at 12:10p at Telecom. Weather looks like it will cooperate...see you there!

Looks like six people signed up so far.  That won't win us any competitions, but hey, it's not bad for ITS! :)

title: Noon Ride on Flag
author: Steve
body: On Thursday the 25th, let's gather at Telecom at noon and head up this blog's eponymous altar. See you then!

comments.comment_body: Sorry Steve, but not today.  No bike and a hungry stomach equals no Flagstaff.  Some day soon though.

title: Taking Suggestions...
author: Steve
body: So, I'm taking suggestions on our next group adventure. Where would you like to go? What day/time? How long? Personally, I like lunchtime rides (11:30-1) that last about an hour. My favorite rides, of course, are hills, including Flagstaff Road, Fourmile Canyon, Poorman Road, and Sunshine Road. Speak up! Let your voice be heard! Vote now!!

comments.comment_body:
How about a Chataqua run/walk? That would be fun. Meet at noon at the trailhead that goes up the hill through the open prairie and then heads in to the woods? Runner's go first followed by hikers?

--Mark.

title: The Duel
author: Steve
body: Yup, that time of the week again: The Flagstaff Duel. This week, however, I think the roads won't be good enough to bike. So, why don't all runners meet in front of Telecom at noon. For those who want to wend their way up to the trailhead on their own, you can meet us there at 12:15p. Hope you can make it...it's fantastic running or walking in the snow!

title: Fourmile-Poorman-Sunshine Loop Ride
author: Steve
body:
Usher out the month of February with a ride in temps forecasted near 70F!! The Fourmile Canyon—Poorman Road—Sunshine Canyon Loop ride is a real fun one, with good ascents and descents, as well as some dirt for your fat tire fanatics. Hope you can make it!

Ride Specifics
Meeting Place: In front of Telecom
Meeting Time: 12:10p
Distance: ~12 miles
Elevation Gain:~1000 feet
Approximate Time: 1hr

title: Thursday Thrashing
author: Steve
body:
So, you thought Initiation was hard? Well, have we got a treat for you! This Thursday, we'll be running a special edition of Dave's favorite trail run, aptly named Commando. Here are the specs:

Commando Duathlon
Start Time: 12p
Meeting Place: North side of Humanities
Distance: ~3 mile bike, ~3.5 mile run
Elevation Gain: ~700 feet (~500 feet in 800 feet on crux)
Crux grade: ~63%

Hope you're up for it!

comments.comment_body:
"More fun than a root canal, without that annoying novocaine flavor!"
"Rock rash, cactus spines, snakebites, torn hamstrings, and a chance to meet the search and rescue guys... again. This run has it all!"
"Be sure to sign the log in the PVC can at the top of the Crux... it help the coroner i.d. the remains."
-Recent reviews from satisfied customers

title: Thursday's Thrashed
author: Steve
body:
Is it Rob or Spiderman? (gallery)

What a run! Even though there were only three of us, there were plenty of prickly pears to go around. As you can see in this photo of Rob Leary, the grade of the run is brutal.

The rewarding views at the top, however, were well worth it! Steve was first to feel the gentle caress of the thorny slope, followed shortly after by Dave, whose puncture wounds are worn with pride. Some ambitious walkers on the Boulder Canyon Path tried to follow us, but then realized this wasn't the trail for them.

comments.comment_body: Suppose we should send the sherrif's dept back up to check on those civilians that followed us?
OMG.  That was one heck of a climb/run/ride.  And I'm sure there's plenty more where that came from!

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Nothing like steady noodling up Fourmile Canyon on a warm March day. Because the grades are gentle, the pedaling is too. There's still a touch of corn-ice on Fourmile Creek and absolutely no green in the woods to speak of apart from the parched ponderosa needles. Still, it was nice to reach Wallstreet, chuckle at the news kiosk in "downtown", quaff some gatorade mixed with water, listen to the wind chimes and the creek, and then coast down. Hardly had to use my brakes either, as the wind was out of the southeast. Just a nice day!

title: Super-Flag Friday Report
author: Steve
body:
Crankset Carnage

Last Friday, a few brave souls tackled Flagstaff Mountain and Flagstaff Road (also known as "Super-Flag"). The grade of Super-Flag averages 7.4% with a 0.3mi section at 14%. There were several gear mashers present for the occasion, as well as a small gaggle of runners. The gear mashers included:

Matt "Top Gun" Burton
Matt made it farther than he ever had before, appreciating the cooler, slightly thinner air on Flagstaff Mountain.
Dave "The Pedal-Pulverizer" Underwood
With triple crank gearing, Dave was a winged angel floating up the road. Unfortunately, his wings (and quads) overpowered his bike, as the sheer force of his pedalling shattered the whole drivetrain (see picture above).
Greg "The Spinning Noodle" Stauffer
The unique frame of Greg's bike propelled him all the way to Lost Gulch Overlook, and while the mere sight of the 14% grade scared him profoundly, he still soldiered on to the stunning viewpoint of the Continental Divide.

Several runners also graced the slopes with their gazelle-like strides:

The Honorable Brian Kent
Brian made it known to all that Friday's run was a mere warm-up for his weekend sojourn: a "routine" run encompassing all peaks in the Front Range (without food or water of course).
Rob "Lightning Bug" Leary
Known for taking cellphone calls on trail runs, Rob impressed his fleet-footed partner Brian by actually sending a fax to the bikers saying they were a bunch of slow @!#$%....

Perhaps we can do this again on Friday (March 24, 2006)???

comments.comment_body:
This ride is a helluva lot easier on Google Earth. And the resolution is much better. Think I'll just stay in the office and heat up a mouse pad... I'll meet you guys at the top.
(Kidding; see ya' Friday!)

Anyone care to run?

Rob

hmm... sounds like a good chance to get some "base" training in and try my new HRM.

(geesh, i never expected i'd be talking about base miles or even own a HRM! i've been assimilated).

anyway, i'll be patiently spinning on my hardtail while you speed/road freaks pass me on the way up.

terry
Was that bike mangled in Photoshop?!?

title: Flagstaff Duel Report
author: Steve
body:
Reflecting on the words of the great Ben Franklin:

You must not, when you have gained a victory, use any triumphing or insulting expression, nor show too much pleasure; but endeavor to console your adversary, and make him less dissatisfied with himself by every kind and civil expression that may be.

Today it was great to be out-of-doors in the warm, spring air with good friends. The runners ran hard, and the bikers pedaled fast. Heart rates and spirits were lifted, as we all suffered through what Dave calls "the drama of climbing." I have a great job and even better colleagues! Thanks for coming.

Have a great weekend or vacation, all!!

comments.comment_body: I stand humbled before greater men...although I'm pretty sure it won't keep me from talking smack as needed.

As Steve and I waited for the runners just above Heartbreak Hill, I fished around in my jersey pocket and found an old dog-eared copy of Finigan's Wake that I'd been meaning to read. I was just past page 456 when Steve said he heard the runners coming up the trail... but it was just the Nature Appreciation Group from Golden West Nursing Home. They said they had passed the runners back down around the Bouldering Rocks, and they would probably crest the hill sometime after the war in Iraq was over. We really wanted to wait around for the guys, but I had to get back to town in order to catch my great grandson's college graduation. So we headed back down... Wonder if they're at the top yet.

I think I speak for the honorable Brian Kent as well when I ask, "How many gears, Steve? How many speeds does that fancy bike of yours have?"

My running shoes... well, one speed is all I need.

Well met today on Flagstaff. Next time....beware!!!

RL

well according to my HRM i spent 45 minutes above my target zone and only 5 minutes in the zone. that's good, right?!
;-P

while i must admit to being last to the top (behind the runners), i can say w/o question i was first/fastest one down.

you guys will make a roadie out of me yet -- NOT!

until next time.

terry

title: Fish Food (DU's Final Virgin Islands Report)
author: Dave
body:
Toto, I don't think we're at Boulder Rez anymore

I was perched on a mangrove stump next to Mary's Lagoon, reading the misleadingly named Touching the Void (I'd picked it up at the airport assuming it would be a field guide to SB's cerebral cortex. It was, in fact, about mountain climbing) when I heard a scream.

I looked up to see Zack, hip-deep in the tidal bay, dancing wildly and holding a thrashing four-foot reef shark by the tail. The poor creature was throwing a fine spray of salt water into the air as it gyrated about, mouth agape and clearly panicked. The shark was equally agitated.

Z had been fly fishing for bonefish on the sand flats when Jaws slammed his size 4 Green Meanie lure, and now the food chain appeared to be going through a review process.

"Dad!!!! He just took a chunk out of my finger!!! What should I do?!!!"

"Don't bleed in the water, Z... you might attract more."

I went back to my reading, thinking how tough it must be to put a climbing trip together in the Andes, what with everything being so remote and all. This book really made you realize how logistically challenging a big mountain is when you're faced with a multi-day approach and precious few local resources.

"Dad!!! He's trying to kill me!!"

Sure enough, though held at arm's length, the shark was coming within millimeters of Zack's ribs, each determined lunge bringing its snapping teeth closer to paydirt. Dark shapes could be seen gliding in across the turquoise flats to Zack's right. How cool; Zack had stumbled on a whole fleet of the buggers.

Kids, Â I thought, returning to the book, they get into the damnedest predicaments sometimes. Just like the guy in this story. Imagine having your rope cut, then plummeting deep into a crevasse. Reminded me of the time...

DU

Like Leno, Steve Is Bumped to a Later Spot

Underwood posted right over me this morning. Sheesh, how's that for "I missed you while I was gone"?! Yeah right, pal!


Dr. Werner thinks we need to follow this video's example to relieve stress.
Obviously, he hasn't been on a Frenzy ride lately.

Not sure what I've done to offend the gods (well, in truth, I'm pleading the 5th on that one). I had rear flat number three this morning on the commute in.

That's right, this time "the truck" flatted! Since it's a different bike with a different tube and since it happened in a different place, I can only conclude I've been eating too much ice cream and pizza.

Add to that misfortune the return of DU, and it's clear for everyone to see, I'm cursed.

Reunited Report

He's back! Good ride with my long lost pal, Dave, today. Finally reunited!

I was able to determine that these rear flats are just a fluke—not the result of added ice cream and pizza weight—too!

Unbeknownst to Adriana, I borrowed her carbon-fiber wheels and rode up Flag without any flats. Yay!

comments.comment_body:
Zack, you're alive! Wasn't sure if Dave was so engrossed in his Andean adventure that he forgot you. Glad that wasn't the case.

Word on the street is you have a challenge for the Frenz. Please, throw down the gauntlet. We're always up to challenges...

In response to "fish food"
Not quite how I remember it, but I guess I did loose a lot of blood...
I think the plot flaw is apparent when I ask my dad for advice.
Zack

title: Duel Cruel Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Some like it hot. Not us.

Conditions were perfect this afternoon, if your idea of perfection includes hypothermic shock: 22.8F at the Mesa Lab and overcast with light snow.

I had dressed lightly, thinking I'd ride "the truck" to Gregory Canyon, lock up, and run the rest of the way. But no, I let Underwood hoodwink me into riding the whole way.

Good times! It was fun to see icicles on the rocks. Dave's brakes were like gelato dispensers, so kudos to him for keeping the crank-arm turning. It was a feat of something or other.

Time to go shiver under some wool blankets. Gammon says it's been in the 50s in Orlando. I don't feel bad for him, though; after all, he's pimped out his parents golf cart.

Have a great weekend, y'all!

comments.comment_body:
Yup, it was a cold, sloppy mess up there today. In fact, I'm still feeling it.

As much as I claim to love this slop, I really am looking forward to those first balmy rides of Spring. 

DU
You guys put the "boys in blue" to shame...! Way to weather the ride!
"it" was a cold sloppy mess? Are you referring to yourself in the third person again, Dave?
Yo, iSean... I would've said lukewarm sloppy mess, now wouldn't I? You need to slow down and read more carefully, just like Mrs Adams told you in the second grade. DU

title: Super-Walker Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
This kind of riding makes you look forward to summer! (gallery)

I suppose all of you would-be participants were shaving your legs last night, and that's why you skipped out.

Well, regardless, Terry and I enjoyed the extra hour of daylight while spitting dirt at Walker Ranch. It was a real treat to watch Terry tear it up. I mean, one minute I'd be descending right behind him, and the next he'd be a quarter mile ahead of me catching air on every bump.

In truth, I was only "right behind him" for a few seconds, as I'm a really granny on the descents. Still, we both had perma-smiles plastered to our suncreen-lathered faces, all the while enjoying the single-track meadows and gurgling creek crossings. We're going to ride it again soon. Hope your legs are smooth, 'cuz ours are sore!!

comments.comment_body:
D'OH!
man, you aren't messing around are you?!

i thought we'd have a few weeks to work up to this... guess i shoulda known better.

no worries-- i'll accept the challenge. assuming walker is dry enough to ride by then, i'll do my best to represent for the fat tire crowd (even if i arrive at the trailhead an hour after all you lung busters).

see you tuesday.

terry

don't all jump up at once to join us!

terry

well so maybe it wasn't "super", but it sure was fun!

steve "ironman" bailey shamed me on the climbs, even though he'd already ridden to the kansas border and back during his lunch hour that same day.

guess i need a few (hundred) more base miles under my belt...

terry

title: Sunshine Canyon Report
author: Steve
body: Due to potentially annoying NW winds, we scrapped our Old Stage Road plans in favor of a more protected, though possibly tougher, trajectory: Sunshine Canyon Drive. The winds at the mouth of the canyon were vaguely vexing, but as we hit the steeper pitches, it was nice and calm, with only the flutter of our over-taxed tickers stirring the air. Great views of the still very snowy Divide today! Let's hope for pleasant weather tomorrow.

comments.comment_body: The best Frenzy ride so far for views! Well worth the extra grind above the Poorman intersection. Let's get Greg and Rob up here...

title: Super-Flag Bailout
author: Steve
body: Due to the weather and demands on our time, we're bagging the Frenzy today. A first!!

title: Old Stage Road Wednesday
author: Steve
body:

Lee Hill → Old Stage → Lefthand → US36

Meeting Time: 12:15p

title: Neva Road Ride
author: Steve
body: If you've been waiting for us to post a flat ride, today's your lucky day! We've decided to sail out US36 to Neva Road, then slog our way back along Foothills Parkway and eventually Folsom Avenue. It's a longer ride, usually taking around 115h, so you might want to eat beforehand or take a nice snack. Let's meet at Gate 5 of Folsom Stadium at noon. Hope to see you there!

comments.comment_body:
Counting the stinking stoplights, I pulled this one off in 1:06, round trip from the stadium. Came back via the Diagonal/Iris/Folsom. I'm gonna get one of those stoplight jamming devices for my bike and see if I can get under an hour.
Let's hit this one more often; great spinning down Neva in 52/13!
DU

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Yes, a weird start time, but I've got a meeting that runs until 12:30pm. So, let's meet on the north side of the Humanities building at 12:40pm and head up Fourmile Canyon.

First we'll ride up Boulder Canyon, then hang a right on Fourmile Canyon Drive, following that until Salina (or however far YOU want to go). Should be another nice day for a ride!

comments.comment_body:
I'm in... I think this is SB's day to break 26:00 to Salina. In fact, if he pulls it off, I'll have my wife bake his wedding cake.
DU
WAIT A MINUTE! Just a day or so ago, it was 27:00 that I was supposed to aim for...now you're saying 26:00?! That's like 14mph the whole way!!

Steve,
When you hang a left on Fourmile Drive, hang on tight as you bounce down into Boulder Creek!
One more vote for SB making Salina in under 25:00! Go Steve!
Funny...ha, ha. According to Google Maps, it's supposed to take 17 minutes by car!

You can do it Steve! I'll be in your wake, cheering you on!

Greg
24:30! Holy cow. Looks like SB gets a wedding cake after all. Great job bro!

Mmmm...cake! It was fun leaving everything on the road today. My head is thumping and I'm sure the uncontrollable coughing will kick in soon. Still, it was great to push my limits today, knowing my pedalling pals were doing the same. Tough riding in this warm weather, but it only gets worse from here on out. Good luck with the knife tomorrow, Dave! Thanks for riding Greg, Matt, Adriana, and Davester!

Stats:

Time: 24:30
Distance: 6.7mi
AVG Speed: 16mph
AVG Grade: 4%
MAX Speed: ~35mph (short downhill)

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride
author: Steve
body:
Sunshine Canyon in 3D

Looks like sun and warm temps today, so it's only fitting that we noodle up Sunshine Canyon.

This is a great route for mountain bikers, as the slope is quite steep, making for a spinny ride up and a nice slalom down. In fact, I think Terry's hit 45mph before on the descent.

Though I undoubtedly won't reach speeds approximating 35mph, I will enjoy the lovely weather and fun descent. Hope you can join me!

Sunshine Canyon
Meeting Time: 12p
Meeting Place: north side of Humanities
Distance (r/t): 11 miles
Elevation Gain: 1663 feet

comments.comment_body: Fantastic ride today.  Blue skies and virtually no clouds.  As a result, Matt Burton and I were afforded great views of the Divide.

Ah it's the slacker's life for me! While you endorphine-toadies were cranking up the canyon, I strolled up to the hill and had a nice fattening lunch (the fries were so greasy you could see through them... cool!). So this is how it starts...
DU

title: Neva Loop Report
author: Steve
body:
Somehow it doesn't make sense that we had a headwind in three out of four of the cardinal points, but it was still a lot of fun spinning today. What a great crowd too, which made the pedalling easier:

  • Dave Underwood
  • Matt Burton
  • Greg Stauffer
  • Rob Leary
  • Kevin Notheis
  • Steve Bailey

When we get clearance from Dave's Doc, we'll hit the hills again. [Dave says he was riding pain free again, which is bad news for all of us who benefitted from his sore knee.]

comments.comment_body:
Steve,

This is THE classic "old timers" lunch ride. Enough distance, hills, and wind to make it a challenge. Can you break an hour??? I bet Cav can.

Dennis

As a classic old-timer, I concur; this is a nice, soft ride in the country. My favorite part: the wind whistling through my dentures as I chuff away down Neva. Sort of a C-sharp minor. ZZZZCCCCSSSSFFFFFHHHH!!!
See you guys Thursday.

DU

cav rides?!
;-)

terry

P.S
yo steve, thought thurs was gonna be mtn bike day? what happened to super walker?

i see how you are... you roadies are all just one big clique aren't you?
rain or shine?
If there's rain, I'm going to pass.

Rain? I laugh in the face of rain. No nancyboy, I!
Actually, one of my post-op directives - the only one I'm following, in fact - requires that I keep the knee dry for a week. So I guess I'll beg off if it starts to drop buckets. Damn.
BTW, got up 4-Mile yesterday, saw RL on the way back to the office. He was on his way to physical therapy. Hope they can salvage the ol' bloke; he's got real promise.
DU

Hey all:

Just got off the phone with Dave, and as I'm so terrified of rain, he suggested that we cancel the ride today so I don't have a phobia-induced heart attack while out riding. Furthermore, the folks in ETFS were calling me, saying something about me needing to deliver data projectors here, there, and everywhere, so I think I need to bag. In solidarity, Dave is bagging too.

We'll try again tomorrow!

Oh, and for what it's worth, the PT says I can start running UP hills. Anyone care to ride their bike UP flagstaff next week, and then run down? I'll be happy to escort your bike DOWN the hill for you :)

RL

Here's a thought: Since I should still be taking the occassional rest/recovery day as a post-op consideration, I'd be happy to drive you back down Flagstaff one day next week. Let me know.
DU

notice how the runners are the ones falling apart and needing physical therapy?

...oh well, guess that's what health insurance is for, eh?

tb

Terry, you're so right. I should just stop running right now. I'll trade you a nice pair of running shoes for that swift bike of yours :)

Meanwhile, I'm up for the ride tomorrow at lunch.

RL

Nice ride guys! Too bad about the wind, but I figure we got a 15% better workout fighting the damn breeze... I'm wiped out.
Imagine going UP Neva today!
DU

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Adriana in Fourmile Canyon

What a nice stroll out in the country today! Judging from the comments below, Dave wasn't happy that I sped ahead...but I had to water the bushes, so to speak. That's the only thing that motivated my frantic pedalling. Otherwise, I'm sure I would've wilted under the gear-mashing pressure!

Today was the return of the camera to our rides too. I was kind of hankering for some pics of our rides, especially since it's getting so nice outside. The creeks are actually sounding like creeks again, and the valleys are getting lush...for Colorado. Unfortunately, Greg was so far ahead that we didn't get any shots of him. Next time.

comments.comment_body:
Here's what I hate... You're in front, you're rolling along really well, w/ a guy - let's call him Greg - on your wheel. You pick it up, really start motoring, and when you come to a nice steep little switchback, you scoot back in the saddle a bit, and hit it as hard as you can, with no warning.(The trick, of course, is to appear ultra-casual when you attack: shoulders loose, elbows bent, upper body relaxed.)
You're sure you've dropped the guy - let's call him Steve now - and you motor like hell up through the next turn. That's when you dare to take one of those furtive little peeks back over your shoulder to see how badly you've dusted him... and he's RIGHT THERE!!! SMILING!! Then what? He pulls on through and leaves you in the weeds, that's what.
Actually it's all part of why we love cycling, isn't it?
Great ride guys!
Yay photos!

title: Ride Reports
author: Steve
body:
Phew! What a week of riding!! We went out everyday this week, which is a sign that spring has sprung. On Thursday we were joined by Noel Lenski, Chair of Classics, for a classic butt-kicking spin up Old Stage Road that would've left Zeus in the dust. Ouch! The next day, Friday, we felt the sting of our hubris in our quads, struggling to keep the pedals ticking over on Sunshine Canyon's 14% slopes. The clouds were welcome, as were the views of the Indian Peaks.

Next week's agenda will be posted soon, so stay tuned. I'm looking at fox/hound again on Monday, then possibly Fourmile Canyon on Tuesday, and maybe Super-Flag on Wednesday. Let me know if you have preferences. Otherwise, bon weekend, mes amis!!

comments.comment_body:
Thursday: It was awesome watching Noel vaporize the east face Old Stage in his 42/21 in the saddle. Bet they could hear the rivets popping from Boulder Heights! And trading chops w/ the guys on the run down Left Hand was a blast! In my humble opinion we made the other lunch-time cyclists out there - and there was a ton of them - look like zombies...
Friday: SuperSunshine was a super solar oven today. I was fried from the get-go. I'll be glad when Boulder Creek drops back below flood stage and we can hit the ol' swimmin' hole on the way back to the office again.
Great pace today Greg and Steve!
DU

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Transfixed by Dave Underwood's impossible climbing cadence, we three pursuers neglected to watch the pavement below us, and poor Dave Fuller had an unfortunate encounter with a small stone with a mean edge. Fourmile foiled Fuller, Notheis, and I, but Underwood, Burton, and Raudzens forged onward to conquer the storied canyon walls. Burton is looking stronger everyday—rumor has it he's been practicing on weekends too! Raudzens is a daring descender on her electric blue Townie. And Underwood is...well...Underwood "The Badger"!! Until tomorrow!

comments.comment_body:
I tried to keep up w/ Townie on the descent, but I was going so fast it made my teeth hurt (apologies to Davis Phinney). After staying w/ her for about a minute or so, I was forced to clamp down hard on the brakes and return to a more earthly, subsonic pace. It felt a little like re-entry. In fact the negative G's actually parted my hair neatly down the back. Looks kinda' cool, actually.
DU
Kudos to those in the pit crew and their assist. Will have to sacrifice this one to the 4Mile Gods up the canyon walls and revisit my destiny. Foiled but not forgotten, Trail-Rasta

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Well, with winds on the plains of 24mph, gusting to 35mph, we bagged Neva Road today. And thank goodness! It was actually windy on our alternate route, Flagstaff, which is a rarity, as it's pretty well protected--but not from winds out of the southeast. Anyhow, we were treated to a great battle between the Daves, as well as a super-strong ride from the ever-improving Mr. Burton, who will soon be dropping all of us, as he has youth on his side. Anyhow, lots of fun coming down, and picture-perfect weather and temps. Don't miss tomorrow's ride!!!

comments.comment_body:
I tried everything I could think of in my somewhat limited arsenal to drop David Fuller: mind games (I did say limited, didn't I?), carpet tacks, a banana peel, fake siezures, the works. But it was like trying to shake a bill collector from Cheese-of-the-Month Club... I simply couldn't lose him. Last night I even dreamed I saw him in line behind me at the Royal Fork Buffet. Aaaarrgh!!
(Great ride Davey!)
DU

The heat was a factor ... so when I viewed you lagging on the ascent I had to seal the deal. The debt for the Gorgonzola is minor, I trust a bill of your own will materialize in my check register soon. Buffet Patron with a score to settle, Trail-Rasta

WEDS:
you may have prevailed this time bailey, but the hounds won't be so forgiving next time!

title: Flagstaff Mountain
author: Steve
body:
Let's hit our favorite hill today for a 10ish mile round-trip. The temps will hit us on the way up today, but the breeze will be our reward on the descent.

Flagstaff Mountain
Meeting Place: Gate 5 of Folsom Stadium
Meeting Time: 12p

comments.comment_body:
Oh so prescient abt the temps. RL (not Widman) and I were heat-treated on the climb, but the descent was the berries.
Nice ride!
DU

You had to wait until I left town for another Frenzy, eh?

SB

There was NO WAY I was going to let the Bailey clan hammer me into a fine paste in Left Hand Canyon. I have to deal with one Bailey on a routine basis, and, subsequently, my ego feels as if it's been downsized and outsourced. Two Baileys? Yikes!
Kidding of course, SB2; I hope next time you're in town we get to ride together. I'd enjoy that!
DU

title: Flagstaff Friday
author: Steve
body: It's time to climb. Let's meet in front of Telecom at 12p on Friday. From there, the way is clear.

comments.comment_body:
I'd like to come along (I have my bike here and everything), but a 1 PM meeting snuck up on me. Have a nice climb.

Kevin

Sorry I missed you Steve and Noel. I had a meeting that went til noon. When I got to my office I looked out and saw you two just taking off. Had a good ride on my own though. Looking forward to celebrating #600 with Dave next week.

Greg

title: Flagstaff Ride Report (#599 for DU)
author: Steve
body:
Dave's slick new crankset

What a ride today! We were able to test out the new drivetrain we got Dave (see photo at left). He reports that he LOVES it! The crankset is a Ritchey compact (50/34), with 172.5mm crank arms—much better for a tall guy like Mr. Underwood.

We also got rid of the old cluster, replacing it with a new 12-28 cluster. So, if you're out on Poorman tomorrow, that hummingbird noise buzzing by you is Dave spinning his new drivetrain. Rounding out the new equipment is a new chain, cuz why burn a new crankset and cluster with an old chain!

Other frills that were throw in (for Dave's own personal safety): headset tightening, brake tightening, brake hub adjustment, and front wheel truing. Now, with all this newfound speed and knee-saving efficiency, Dave needn't worry about breaking his handlebars or losing control on the descents. Don't miss Wednesday's ride!!!

comments.comment_body:
Can't wait to chase Dr. Lenski up Old Stage w/ these new cogs. He'll still drop me like an old sock, but at least now I'll be in the power band!
Thanks everyone, and more soon!
D

title: Matt Burton's Napa Valley Ride Report
author: Matt
body:
Napa Valley

This past weekend I slipped the confines of Boulder County to bask in the beauty of the Napa Valley in northern California. I had the opportunity to rent a 2005 Specialized Roubaix Comp featuring a full carbon fiber frame and Shimano DuraAce drive train.

On Saturday, June 10 I set out early from the town of Napa, CA to wind my way through the back roads of Napa county, over the hills ringing the valley, west through the town of Sonoma, CA and finally swinging southeast for the return to Napa. My planned route was just under 50 miles. I had an incredible bike, plenty of water and nutrition, and an entire day to kill.

The first 10 miles was on a two-lane road following a small creek that climbed from Napa's perch at 17' about sea level to a brisk 554' above sea level. The next stage in "Tour-de-Wine-Country" put me to the test in a manner similar to our own Flagstaff Mountain. The aptly-named Trinity road rose from 554' to 1750' in a mere 4.7 miles, including several sections with grades in excess of 9 percent. The road for my efforts was a 7.2 mile down-hill section of steep grades and beautiful views.


Steep grades abounded

After coming down the west side of the hills I entered the small town of Glen Ellen, CA - Home of Jack London State Historic Park. After some two-hours and change into my ride I took a break in Glen Ellen for a well-earned Clif Bar. From there I headed south towards Sonoma, passing the infamous Agua Caliente Road. After another seven miles or so I entered the outskirts of Sonoma, CA.

Attempting to bike through the town of Sonoma took nearly an hour. Navigating the side streets and bike paths was slow and difficult. In retrospect I should have circumvented the town for a bit less stress and a bit more cycling. I left Sonoma headed southeast on the shoulder of California Highway 12 towards my starting point in northwestern Napa.

The next nine miles along highway 12 were uneventful, even with the high traffic, due a rather large and recently paved shoulder. Just before entered the southern part of Napa-proper I elected to take a detour to the west on Old Sonoma Road to by-pass the southern section of the city. After my misadventures navigating Sonoma I figured that a few extra miles of enjoyable riding was more prudent that returning quickly.


Winding roads of CA wine country

Old Sonoma Road too me to a familiar road that ran near the house I was staying at for the weekend. I savored the last few miles with the knowledge that I had little stamina left for further riding that day and I needed to return the bike that night. The ride took just under five hours including a quick lunch stop in Glen Ellen and many, many frustrated stops in Sonoma attempting to navigate the city.

The vertical profile took me from 17' in Napa to 554' near Dry Creek to 1750' at the top of Trinity to 206' in Glen Ellen to 50' in Sonoma andfinally back to 17' in Napa.

This was a truly fantastic ride. I could not have done it without Steve Bailey and his daily prodding to get me to start cycling and his constant encouragement to continue.

Thank you for the plug, Matt! I'm always happy to introduce people to the pleasures of masochism! Ed.

comments.comment_body:
nice job matt!

glad to see you're so enthused about riding (now we just need to get you away from the influence of all these ITS roadies and get you more time on the dirt!).

something tells me though someday we'll see matt in a yellow jersey atop a podium-- "i'd like to thank steve bailey..."

terry

title: Report: Dave's 600th Ascent of Flagstaff
author: Steve
body:
Dave makes it 600! (gallery)

Thanks to everyone for participating in today's momentous ride, especially our surprise refreshments goddess, Kristen!!! Congratulations to Dave for making it to #600, to Tom for making it to #1, and to everyone else who's somewhere in-between!

Dave still claims he likes the "new" bike, but he still despises the heat...100°F today!! If you'd like to relive the climb from the comfort of your air-conditioned office, check out the gallery. Otherwise, see you again soon in the hills!

comments.comment_body:
dave you're an inspiration to us all...

to think, 78 years old and still riding flagstaff; impressive my good man.
;-)

(something tells me after dave retires we'll be doing this celebration again for mr. steve bailey's 600th ascent).

terry
will it count if i've been secretly using a silent motor?

The only thing better than doing Flagstaff 600 times is doing it with great friends! Thanks everyone!
And thanks Kristen, for the cooler-load. What a great sight. (A little different day than that one last winter when we ran the ski-jump trail at 2 below, eh?)
Thanks again,
D

Wow... a flagstaff duel! And I thought there would never be another run listed on this blog! See you there!

RL
Silly, Rob.  We only run in snow, sleet, freezing rain, or high winds.  If there's not some combination thereof, we're probably riding. :)

title: Bastille Day Ride Report 2006
author: Steve
body: After a week of searing heat, we hit Flagstaff one more time today for a half-hearted duel, which was less a competition than a test of mettle. Let's face it, it was DANG hot out there! Anyhow, thanks to Matt, Kevin, and Dave for participating. We'll do it again sometime soon, when temps are more agreeable. Don't days like today make you wish it were snowing?! See you all next week.

comments.comment_body:
Holy cow, tomorrow's Super Flag could be deadly, with temps in the mid-90's. And all amid the hubub of the IT Community Support Event... OK, see you there.
RL

title: Valmont Reservoir Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Steve rides Adriana's townie around town

Since Adriana was out of town this weekend, I decided to take her bike for a spin. Unfortunately I mistakenly grabbed the cruiser rather than the new carbon fiber road bike. Oops.

In spite of my foible, I was happy to be out on the bike, for I knew my friends would never make fun of me for riding a girly bike. In fact, a few of them seemed to be genuinely jealous of my ride.

We hit the road and eventually joined up with Linda Drake, who let me draft off her, which was very nice. She claims she left us behind half way through the ride because she had to get back to the office, but I think she was embarrassed. In any event, we had a great time, despite the sweltering heat. Thanks for coming, everyone!

comments.comment_body: Oh sure, you guys think it's funny; zipping around the county with this guy on your wheel. It felt like Pee Wee's Big Adventure. Matt and Linda and I tried to lose him, more for the sake of keeping up a "professional" image than anything else. But the harder we worked the more it became apparent we were stuck with him. It was like a bad dream. The Curse of the Velcro Cruiser. Nightmare on Folsom Street. In fact, I think he might be behind me at this very moment! Aaaarghh!!

comments.comment_body:
I thought some of you might be up for *watching* cycling at the IMAX theatre in Denver. Check out Wired to Win: Surviving the Tour de France

--Mark W.

Mark,

I saw that at the IMAX a while back. Funny story: it was supposed to be called "Brain Power" and star Tyler Hamilton, but after he was busted for doping, they cut him from the film. That's why you may have noticed a certain lack of continuity...they had to go back after the Tour de France was over and film those two guys from Francaise des Jeux (Baden Cooke and Jimmy Caspers). Too bad for Tyler, eh?

Travelogue, date August 8th, time 12:11ish. Participants, Dave "hammerhead" Underwood, and, Dennis "I'm still back here trying to hang on" Maloney. Hot ride but lots of fun.

So, where was everyone else???

Re: "Wired to Win" - bike geeks would know that the bikes used in the refilming portion were not yet available for the 2003 TdF. Oops.

Dude,

We were out there, just running late. We weren't able to sneak out of Telecom until 12:05, and it took us a few to get ready. Obviously, we weren't fast enough to catch you two maniacs. Sorry!

Well now, that's just icing on the cake. I knew Dennis and I were smokin' the route, but now that I know the Frenzies were back in the propwash somewhere, unable to reel us in - even with our 20 minute head start - why, that's just ducky. I guess, in retrospect, I can now freely say that Maloney/Underwood would have dropped the lot of ya' anyhoo.
Can't prove otherwise.
DU

All,

That was fun! Although Dave and Greg lied to me about portions of the trail, I will try to be a good sport. However, I have a long memory.

I expect to have nightmares of stairs.

Dennis

title: Last Minute Flagstaff
author: Steve
body:
Not even early fall snows stop the Frenzies (gallery)

Neither the nippy weather nor the utter lack of organization on my part stopped the Frenzy faithful from climbing the ramparts of our favorite flatiron today! Dave was savvy enough to bring a camera even, just so those poor saps at Educause could get a taste of what they're missing. I'm thinking Old Stage tomorrow if the weather looks promising; if not, let's seriously consider the Sanitas Duathlon.

title: Old Stage Ride Flagstaff Mountain
author: Steve
body: We ended up dropping the Old Stage ride for today due to work obligations. The ride up Flag was quite nice, requiring only a shirt-sleeved jersey on the ascent and a puffy vest for the descent. Nothing like yesterday's ride, as temps today are 64°F. Maybe a flat ride out east tomorrow....

title: Valmont Rez Report
author: Steve
body: Oops...I've been slackin' lately as concerns posting rides before we actually ride. My apologies. Thanks to heads-up play by Mr. Burton and Mr. Underwood, a ride was arranged for Valmont Reservoir. In spite of the lenticular clouds which suggested high winds aloft, we were able to do this ride out east in great conditions: sun, temps in the 50s, and only gentle winds. Tomorrow promises more of the same. Perhaps it's time we hit Sunshine....

comments.comment_body:
So nice having Matt B wearing his bright yellow storm anchor (windbreaker) today. The extra drag was just what we needed to keep him in check. Now if we could just get him to put playing cards in his spokes...
DU

title: Old Stage Road
author: Steve
body:
Get ready for riding the Old Stage Road

Thanks to our frictionless wooden wheels and a few horses, Matt and I had a great ride out there today. Felt colder than yesterday at first, but then we warmed up, especially while climbing Old Stage Road itself. Matt got to experience the thrill of getting pulled down Lefthand today, and now he's a born again drafter! Promises to be nice into early next week, so let's do some more road riding while we can. Meantime, have a great weekend, everyone!!

title: Fourmile Canyon
author: Steve
body:
Pretty quiet out there today, except for the cement truck that followed me down from Salina. I did manage to make it to where the pavement turns to dirt, and I remembered how much I like that little town. If you haven't been up there, it's worth the extra 5-10 minutes of suffering...feels like an alpine village in the Old Country.

We'll see if the weather dictates duathlon or ride tomorrow.

comments.comment_body:
Hey,
Fall is the season of nostalgia, and I got nostalgiac for Sanitas. Did the duathlon a day early. Holy cow that's a steep sucker. My legs acted as if they'd never been there before... Like, "Hey we don't do stuff like this! We're tired! We want to go home!" That kind of nonsense. I had to remind them that the three of us (me, left, right) used to make a regular diet of climbs like Sanitas, but they just acted stupid and surly. We all left in a bad mood.
DU

DU, et al.:

Since you already hit Sanitas today, perhaps we can undertake another adventure run I've been eyeing of late: find the connector trail between Sunshine Canyon and the Anemone Trail so as to permit a nice loop....

title: Colorado Trail Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Last MTB ride of the year near Breckenridge

A hardy group of Frenz headed for the high country this past weekend in the hope of squeezing in that one last high ride of the season. Though the coat of snow we encountered driving through the Eisenhower Tunnel made us a little weary at first, we ended up having a great ride. We've assembled a nice gallery to share our fun with those otherwise obligated this weekend. We're sorry we missed you!

comments.comment_body:
is that a special ed enduro that matt is rockin' these days w/ a bomber fork?

that guy is getting more serious every time out isn't he? ;-)

hope all is well in boulder...
me? i've been on the bike as often as possible lately (perks of unemployment).

cheers,

terry

title: Flagstaff Mountain
author: Steve
body:
Our route in 3D

Rob has a new bike! A Kestrel no less!! At his request, the Frenzied will point their front tires at Flagstaff Mountain and climb. Hopefully there won't be any icy spots waiting to ambush us! Here are the details:

Meet at 12:10p @ Telecom.

title: Sunshine Canyon
author: Steve
body:
Föhn wall cloud sitting over Boulder

Some type of front is definitely moving into the area, as evidenced by the Föhn wall cloud sitting over the Rockies just west of Boulder. [See NCAR's great streaming video showing different types of Rocky Mountain wave cloud formations...you can fast forward to 1min10sec to see the Föhn wall cloud video.] Sunshine Canyon Drive had lots of sand on it, making for a sketchy descent--the blustery winds making the descent all the more sketchy. Still the temperatures were just right for riding uphill and even for coming down. It's great to feel like you got your ride in right before the storm. Looks like wet weather for the first half of the weekend....

comments.comment_body:
Great video, Dr. Bailey.
This may be a bit thick for the Frenzy, but isn't it interesting how these cloud-behavior clips so clearly illustrate the relativity of time? We can't see the true nature of how the clouds are acting until we speed the camera up. Then, at quadruple speed, we can tell exactly what's going on; the relative elasticity of time enables us to detect movements that we previously had overlooked or misinterprated. The same techniques and principles could be applied to Burton on his bike, though quadruple speed may prove insufficient. (This is the Frenzy, after all; serious discussion is vigorously discouraged and trash-talk reigns supreme. Almost forgot!)
DU

title: Neva Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Though a young pup by comparison, Mr. Burton displayed sagacity beyond his years yesterday in sitting squarely on Dave's wheel until he detected a moment of weakness, at which point he pounced on the exhausted power-house. From a distance, I could see this epic battle unfold, and I'm excited to see more fireworks on tomorrow's climb up Flagstaff!

comments.comment_body:
Quote of the day: "So Dave, are you taking it easy today?"
- Matt Burton as he easily slid around DU and hammered off to catch Greg "The Diminishing Speck" Stauffer.
Yeah, Matt, I was taking it easy. Only using my left leg... Saving the right for the big kickball tournament after work. Uh-huh.
DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
A picture is worth 1000 words

Not today! Burton nearly bested his PR with a quasi-serious effort, but it wasn't enough to beat Dave. As Dave confessed, he's just got too many tricks up his sleeve for the youngster. Good group today! Thanks to Dave, Matt, Rob, Kevin, and Adriana for coming.

comments.comment_body:
Somehow this blog has turned into a big "Dave vs. Matt" cycling match. Wasn't that settled yesterday when I smoked Dave on Neva?

I keeeed, I keeeed.

Wonderful day, great ride. Dave retains his crown.

Still trying to solve that pictogram... Penant + petrified snake = semi-retarded designer. I just don't get it.
By the way, the Burton-Underwood conflict appears to have reached a stalemate... at least for now. The combatants have agreed to scale back the level of corrosive trash talk and to demonstrate at least a modicum of civility in their day-to-day dealings both on and off the bikes. And - good news! - victory is close at hand in the Iraq War.
Pinch me.

Dear Matt,

I suggest you pay more reverence to dear old Dave. Jim Croce has a song that you might use as a mantra the next time you decide to mess around with le superman Dave U.

You don't tug on Superman's cape
You don't spit into the wind
You don't pull the mask off the old Lone Ranger
And you don't mess around with DU, da do da do...

Dennis

Dennis,

Matt would happily talk trash about you, you old geezer, but you're never around. :)

"Old geezer?!"
How long have you worked here Bailey, not counting tomorrow?
DU

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Big storm's moving in...reminds me of my old place of employment

Whether it was the trash talk or the humiliation from yesterday, we will never know. One thing's for certain, though: Matt was conspicuously absent today. He claims he had dinner with a friend, but that doesn't explain the quiet sobbing I heard from the other side of my cube.

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Pesky wind! I was fluttering in the wind on the way down Boulder Canyon, and it was deceptively cool out for bikers. Still, it's always fun to watch Dave and Matt duke it out on a steady uphill grade. Thanks to Matt, Dave, and Adriana for riding!

title: Freaky Frenzy Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
It didn't take much to turn us from Average Joes into freaks (gallery)

In spite of the conspicuous absence of many who seemed to have voted in the poll, the Freaky Frenz celebrated Halloween in style today. We all jammed to The Meters on the way up, then froze our butts off on the way down. It wasn't that bad really. Thanks to everyone who showed up: Adriana "The Construction Zone", Dave "The Scotsman", Rob "The Devil", Matt "Jared from Subway", Greg "The Mormon on a Mission", and Jason as himself. Should we roast a turkey (or tofurky) for Thanksgiving?

comments.comment_body:
Hey, I think a lot of you buzzards voted twice! Besides, I signed on for cross-training, not cross-dressing.
Sheesh.
DU

I'd like to take back my reservations about seeing Dave in a kilt. She's a good looking man!

Brian

Do I look fat in this?
DU

title: Sunshine Canyon Report
author: Steve
body:
These kinds of temperatures are good training for when it gets REALLY cold

Rode solo today. Don't know if it was the strenuous in-costume riding yesterday or the cold temps out there, but something kept the rest of you away....

Definitely a nippy 36° out there, especially coming downhill! I guess I've qualified for the 40° club in the new poll...though I'm quite sure I can go colder. Indeed, though I look like a boy scout on a weekend outing while riding in the cold, I don't mind carrying lots of gear up for the descent. It's amazing what a dry shirt, hat, and windproof coat will do! The rest of the week promises warmer temps, so hope to see you guys out there!

comments.comment_body:
Sorry I couldn't join you today. Kilt rash.
DU

Stupid classes....

RL

title: Boxing Boulder Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Slim pickins out there today too. At least Kevin made it. Mr. Burton text-messaged us from DIA, where he's stuck at the terminal, to express his regrets for not making it. Was chillier than the JeffCo Airport led me to believe—maybe 42°. Rob has put in a request for a run tomorrow, so I may end up posting his requested route and a bike ride route too. Extra credit for those who do both!

comments.comment_body: I wish I could go, too.  Instead I'm stuck at DIA waiting for a (delayed) 737.  Am I on vacation yet?

I went up Flagstaff. W/out Br'er Burton to chase it was a lackluster event.
DU

title: Freedom-To-Choose Friday Report
author: Steve
body:
Steve (seated) betrays Frenzy faithful; runs with Rob (standing) for Â£20,000

I feel dirty now. On top of it all, it was 66° outside, which is about my cutoff for running. I'll need to change this week's poll if this weather sticks around for a while. Thanks to Rob and Brian for leading me to the dark side. My apologies to Kevin for going Benedict Arnold on you.

comments.comment_body: Wow, is that a map of boulder, or is it somewhere in New Hampshire?  It's hard to tell!

title: Cherryvale Ride Report
author: Dave
body:
Monday's dash out Baseline to Cherryvale was a dandy. RL pushed his new mount (LeMond!) to hitherto unseen speeds, and Burton and Underwood labored to hold on. As the trio shredded their way through the bucolic plains south of Boulder, the obstreperous winds managed to stay consistently face-on. Very fast pace, at least in Underwood's opinion.

Rob and Matt came this close to picking up a moving violation as they flew through downtown Marshall. Thank God radar guns don't see carbon fiber.

Great ride... do we ever have a bad one?

comments.comment_body:
Three Frenzy faithfuls (Dave, Rob, and Matt) took to the streets only to thumb their noses at Steve's assigned "homework" ride and instead pointed their tires southeast toward Cherryvale Road citing something about wind.

On the return to campus (via the Broadway bike path) Dave and Rob complained about the slow pace and constant interruptions.

Mr. Underwood was (mis)quoted as saying, "Dagnabit, that there youngin' Burton is stopping to canoodle with every 21-to-25-year-old lass seen within a half mile of this here trail."

Mr. Burton was unavailable for comment.

title: Flagstaff Wind Report
author: Steve
body:
Lucky for me, Matt didn't ditch me after I showed up late in my work clothes. Instead, the gentle giant of the asphalt waited for me to get ready, then accompanied me up the classic climb of Flagstaff Mountain.

Shame on Dave for skipping to vote. You've got the Frenzy Poll...what more do you need?!

title: Who Needs a Tailwind?
author: Steve
body:
When Classics guys ride, you're forced to draft off their egos

Ouch...the wind was biting hard today up on Poorman. Not a cold wind either!! I had that stinging sweat in my eyes—you know the one that tells you "Hey, Dummy, drink more water!"

We were graced with the presence of the Chair of Classics who deigned to share the same road with us. Normally those Classics guys wouldn't give you the time of day, but today was different. Maybe it was the Zéphyros cascading down from Mt. Olympus.

Seriously, thanks to Noel, Dave, and Kevin for making the Chinook bearable!

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body: No report filed.

title: Another Windy Sunshine Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Submitted by John Keats

O SOLITUDE! if I must with thee dwell,
Let it not be among the jumbled heap
Of murky buildings; climb with me the steep,-
Nature's observatory - whence the dell,
Its flowery slopes, its river's crystal swell,
May seem a span; let me thy vigils keep
'Mongst boughs pavillion'd, where the deer's swift leap
Startles the wild bee from the fox-glove bell.
But though I'll gladly trace these scenes with thee,
Yet the sweet converse of an innocent mind,
Whose words are images of thoughts refin'd,
Is my soul's pleasure; and it sure must be
Almost the highest bliss of human-kind,
When to thy haunts two kindred spirits flee.

Great one!

comments.comment_body:
Hmmm.... Sunshine canyon.... Best hope that the sun is shining as the 40-degree wind might be pretty cold coming down!

Anyone care to go for a flat run at Wonderland Lake?

RL

East I spun,
Through malls and parks of dull industrial commerce.
My spokes like quicksilver did charm the bustling hoard,
As I, clad all in spandex, lycra, chrome, and steel,
Did attack pavement, concrete, and the innocent pebbl'd cob.
For I was the Armstrong of the Creek Trail,
The Meteor of the Sidewalk, nursing my sanguine wounds
In stealthy pursuit of dilute and crippled endorphins
On backstreets, in alleys, and through nursing home parking lots.
No longer shall the misty heights of Dear Flagstaff, Poorman, and Sunshine
Feel the bruising crease of my elderly rims,
For I am a slackard, a flat-lander, and a wuss.

O Time, thou hast robb'd me of my youth!

(Had to take a short lunch today... went spinning out east. Sheesh.)
DU

title: Super-Gusty Flagstaff
author: Steve
body:
Are those my chicken legs?

I'm surprised that we actually saw people out on Flagstaff today. Apart from us (Greg, Dave, Burton, Adriana, and I), there were three dudes from the TIAA-CREF Cycling Team (I recognize two of them: Brad Huff and Blake Caldwell) and one regular, Brian, whom we've seen quite often on the vaunted slopes.

Now, I thought I was chicken when I dismounted on the 15-20% hairpin near Lost Gulch (which was ice over gravel), but when I got down, I learned (via confession) that Mr. Burton actually asked a woman for a ride down!!! At least he admitted it, tho', I guess.

I'm a little worried about Greg. That guy has no fear! Maloney, you'd better do a background check again on him.

comments.comment_body: Where's the cutesy graphic?  We can't ride without a cutesy graphic on the blog!
Looks like Jared on 1/2 a Subway sub a day. -Pokey
Looks like me in 1982 'cept I had 32 spoke wheels. DMM

Am I the only one in this group that has any sort of survival instinct?

Yes, when the wind nearly blew me over (when I was stopped) I decided that catching a ride, if possible, would be the most prudent thing to do.

It's crazy that the single, care-free guy of the group is telling the marrieds to play it safe(r).

Guess I didn't notice... Was it windy?
DU

title: Frenzy Observer Network
author: Steve
body:
A Frenzy observer at an undisclosed outpost

Let's meet at Humanities at 12:20p. Bring your bike and a lock, for I'm leaning toward some type of duathlon.

I wore my running shoes today. I view this less as a lack of faith in our ability to ride into the teeth of 40mph winds and more as the expression of a desire to wear bright orange shoes. You, O'Gentle Readers, will understand, I'm sure.

In any event, today more than ever, the Frenzy needs your help. If you have a window in your office, please post your weather observations as comments before the noon hour. Your readings will help decide our fate today! Bon courage!

comments.comment_body: my office has a window but i'm at home today with a sick child. looks pretty nice from here though. have fun but steer clear of the ice! -Greg
Opps. Looks like my comment is a day late...and a dollar short. Same applies today though, have fun and steer clear of the ice!

title: Frost Pockets in Little Europe
author: Steve
body:
Hidden hamlet just outside Boulder, aka. Little Europe

Swooping down Fourmile Canyon, it was hard not to notice distinct temperature changes from one stretch of road to the next. The cold air had pooled in frost pockets, spilling out of rocky basins and splashing onto our numbed faces. If you bump into Dave, Kevin, or Matt today, don't be surprised if our speech is slurred for a spell.

comments.comment_body:
Sounds chilly. It was sunny and warm on sunny Flagstaff today.
Bryan

Bryan,

Thanks for the Flag report! We'll see you again soon out there!!

7:55 Thursday morning. My speech is still slurred. Starting to be concerned. Is this how it starts?
DU

title: Raucous Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Matt
body:
Today's ride featured a legendary role reversal and the fall of a dynasty. Or maybe not.

Moments prior to the start of the ride Dave Underwood was seen canoodling with a sweet 20-something young lady with blonde hair, normally a task seen performed by Matt Burton. This role reversal began the ride up Flagstaff Mountain on a beautiful day in the low-60's (just like Dave!).

While Steve Bailey looked on to his amusement while Dave and Matt raced up the mountain as fast as their (relatively) leisurely pace would take them. Dave held an initial lead only to have Matt catch up and thank Dave for waiting for him. Dave was not waiting for him.

At the top of "The Wall" just below the junction of the main road and the summit road the tide began to turn. Steve Bailey describe the epic battle as akin to "...watching the Tour. Burton caught Dave's wheel and made an attack at just the right time."

Steve was also heard mumbling about EPO, drugs, and performance-enhancing substances. Nobody was listening.

The role reversal was complete when Matt crossed the entrance to the summit parking area before Dave, beating Matt's personal best time in the process. The (still) Mighty Dave finished third and his transition between "elite athlete" and "old guy using decades' old stories to pick up impressionable young ladies" was complete.

The End. Let the trash talk begin.

comments.comment_body:
It should be noted that that woman approached Dave, not the other way around. Even more poignantly, she approached him as he was doffing his shirt, in spite of his modest attempt to disrobe in peace (near Euclid Parking Garage).

It should further be noted that Burton started talking smack about those who are next on his "drop" list: Rob, Steve, Greg, Kevin. I believe I overheard him say something about another list of "easy drops", which only included Dennis.

Notice served.

Holy Cow... Where to start.
First, let's do some math. MB weighs in at a scant 25 years, DU at just under 55. This conquest - if you can call it that - is then akin to DU smacking an 84-year-old in a Frenzy event. DU is confident he could do that, if he ate and slept well the night before and if his tires were well aired (so to speak). He might also want a wee bit of a handicap.
As to canoodling, DU defers to MB. MB admittedly canoodles at a world-class level, and DU is awed.
DU would like to remind MB that one goes into battle with the body one has, not the body one might want or wish to have at a later time.
DU must go now; his Depends are binding.

title: Change of Plans...Again
author: Steve
body:
Open meadow views (Haiku Times)

The cloudy start to today's ride left everyone scrambling for extra clothes. We were veritable marshmallows as we disembarked. In spite of the cold and the fact that it's Friday, attendance was very good. Thanks to newcomer Kimberly, old-timer Dave, young-whippersnapper Matt, and the timeless-one Greg for coming!

Dave has promised to furnish us with a map of a new route for next week—I couldn't hear his exact description during the ride (due to the wind), but I was able to discern the words "hill", "dirt", "vicious". Sounds fun. Bon weekend, les amis!!

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Anyone seen this rider?

The give and take continues. After waiting for Matt like the Gentleman he is, Dave goaded Matt on with a hard charge up Sunshine. Matt didn't bite and allowed Dave a quarter mile lead, which he never regained. To his credit, though, Matt did make it up the steep ramps beyond Poorman Drive.

Dave, concerned about the whereabouts of his young protegé, notified the dairy industry—the first place I call when my pals go AWOL.

Thanks to Dave, Matt, and Kevin for the company. Big 'W' goes out to Kimberly, Adriana, and Greg who claimed it was "too cold."

title: Neva Ride Report
author: Steve
body: No wind and warm temps...what was the excuse for today's no-shows?

comments.comment_body:
Sounds good to me. Anyone up for a trail ride tomorrow?

RL

My excuse? We had some consultants in until 12:30 to install a demo content switch for testing. Sorry. I did manage to get out for a solo ride and enjoy the weather.

Kevin
I'm afraid my excuse makes me sound like a turkey but it's true--I have a cold. Gobble gobble.

title: Endo on Poorman
author: Steve
body:
Rob tests the clipless pedals

We had a good mix of fat and skinny tires out there today. And, dang...it was warm!! If Dave had been around, I'll bet he would've taken a dip in Boulder Creek! Thanks to Rob, Adriana, Matt, and Kevin for taking a spin up Poorman.

Happy Tofurkey Day!

comments.comment_body:
Really, since I quit drinking, nothin' beats fallin' on my head for bringing on that soft-focused, glow-y "holiday cheer"!

RL

title: Fourmile Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Like a bumptious burr in my sock, the cold air clung to me today, mercilessly forcing its fridgid fingers down my throat. Swaddled in sheer spite (and a few puffy layers), I soloed my way up just the same. Actually, it wasn't that bad...I'm excited to try again tomorrow when it's colder!

comments.comment_body:
Good god, I can't imagine riding today! Anyone up for a slow run?
R

So where are we going today?

RL

title: Flagstaff brrrrrRide Report
author: Dave
body:
With the helicopter grounded, film crews had to watch the duel from campus

Steve and Dave both earned new merit badges today with their snowy trip up Flag. Rob earned an 'A' for effort and heart, but was hampered by a knee injury shortly after starting and wisely returned to the base.

Fans lined the streets, gawking in amazement as the ambitious duo boogied up the hill with knuckleheaded zeal. In this view from the ATLAS building, Steve is at least three wheels ahead of Dave and gaining. Steve did pause just past the gate, though, giving Dave a chance to catch up for the final push to the top. Congratulations to both for showing us that common sense, like ketchup, is damn near worthless below 20 degrees.

comments.comment_body: Hey, what's wrong with frozen ketchup?!

title: Flagstaff Road/Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Avoiding snow plows and dump trucks is a good idea on road bikes

Finally!!! All roads leading to Flagstaff were dry: 16th, Baseline, and Flagstaff.

Though ridable, the route was rendered more challenging by the winds and sand. The winds imposed themselves on the ascent, and the sand made its presence felt on the descent. Still, by averaging 5mph on the way up and down, I was able to manage the objective dangers.

Speaking of which, how was lunch with Matt and this girl? Sounds like everyone was there to coach Mr. Burton.

comments.comment_body: I'll have to pass on the ride today.  I have a lunch appointment with some sushi and a wonderful young lady.  Enjoy your ride!

I have to skip today's ride also... I'm having lunch w/ Matt and his wonderful young friend. You don't mind do you Matt?
DU

Dave, you and I are normally the bosomest of buddies on two wheels.  However, I must admit that I do not need competition from the likes of you when it comes to cavorting with the ladies on my lunch hour.  We have seen what happens when you doff your shirt in the presence of the 21-to-29 crowd.  Be a friend and stay as far away from my game as possible today, mkay?

I think DU is on to a good idea, provide Matt with Chaperone services for a free lunch. Count me in.

DMM
As usual, I have a regularly scheduled 1 pm meeting today that will preclude me from joining the ride. But on the bright side, I think I can squeeze in lunch with Matt!

title: Sunshiny Day
author: Steve
body:
Rumor has it, Dave left work with wussitis today

There was a pronounced temperature inversion in Sunshine Canyon this afternoon! Once again, we saw one of the TIAA-CREF guys—a sprinter whom we only see on climbs...go figure.

comments.comment_body:
I have a doctor's excuse for missing today's Frenzy. I'll fax it over to Frenzy Central Thursday morning.
How do I pay the fine? Cash? Check? Speedtype?
DU

We only accept doctor's notes from shady physicians, known as preparateurs in the cycling world.

Usually, they make you better by taking some blood and replacing it later so you'll feel twice as strong as before.

The Frenzy Headquarters is looking into hiring such a character, but they don't come cheap.

Actually, this guy comes highly recommended....

title: Out East Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Wow! Kevin was psyched to be on the bike again...glad I had the video camera!

Kevin and I took a spin out east today, chit-chatting all the live-long day. The banter ranged from good books to baseball to future Frenzy gatherings. Notable among our ideas were: a winter overnight in the Indian Peaks and Rockies game this summer. Who's in?

PS: If anyone's interested in giving to a good charity for the Holidays, please contact Dave. He's got a great cause, and I'm down!

Submitted by Dave "I do my own damn rides" Underwood

Bet you didn't see me boxing Boulder in a clockwise direction today... I started down the hill and it occurred to me that it was bloody cold. Don't question the logic; I headed toward Flagstaff. Took the creek trail up to 6th, then wiggled up toward Baseline. One of the streets I ended up on was solid ice. Cool; I can work on my ice-riding chops. Except I took a fall and it knocked all the ambition out of me. Bagged it and came back to the office early. Probably a good thing, given having a cold and all.

comments.comment_body:
I'm going to make a copy of the note from Dave's doctor, white-out his name, and write mine in today. My case of wussitis is a side-effect of my very first sports injury! I'm going to use my Turf Toeâ„¢ as an excuse to head over to the Rec Center and lift weights instead of riding today.

My magic eight-ball says "Signs Point to Yes" for good weather and a great ride tomorrow.

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Graham Watson Photo: Tour de Suisse, the peloton descends

Today was a ride for the ages...or at least for late fall. With temps nudging 60°F, we were in shorts and short-sleeves, admiring the splendor of soft snow over rough terrain. On the descent, we witnessed another strong temperature inversion, but the slight chill was well worth the lyrical beauty of cyclists swooping down serpentine roads in formation. Ah, what a way to usher in the weekend!

title: Neva Loop Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
It's wasn't snowing, raining, or windy, so we were able to get in a spin on Neva Road.

There's a good deal of excitement among the Frenz in light of the new bio page with PRs. Indeed, everyone's cadence seemed to be 10-20 RPMs higher today.

comments.comment_body:
Sweet new header there Stevie B. Thanks for keeping it fresh. I'm actually feeling like a short romp through Chataqua. If anyone else wants to join me around noon, give me a ring (5-1608).

Greg

title: Scouting Mission, Part I.
author: Steve
body:
Dave hits the climb (gallery)

Great riding day today. Around campus it was quite windy, but as soon as we got over to 4th, it was calm...we didn't even notice a breeze.

What was so fun about today's ride was feeling like an early American explorer looking for the Northwest Passage. There are some potentially good rides up off Linden Road, we just need to find one that does a loop.

Dave and I ended up going up Cedar Brook Road, cresting a little col, then ending up at a dead end after descending a very serpentine street. The riding was so fun, though, we didn't mind at all.

In fact, we were so jazzed by the exploration that we may schedule another ride this week whose express intent is scouting routes. If you're interested, come join us! Stay tuned...

comments.comment_body: Prance?
I do have a bell on my commuter bike.

title: Hoodwinked
author: Steve
body:
So, after posting the South Boulder ride, having second thoughts and canceling it, I stepped outside to catch the bus, then—perhaps it was the gentle persuasion of the breeze on my shoulders—I suddenly decided I would saddle up and ride home in spite of the wind. I just couldn't bring myself to wait for the bus, ride the bus, go home, catch the bus again, ride again, and walk back to my office.

I'm sorry if my mercurial mindset has ruined your day in any way. I promise to make it up to you tomorrow with a punishing ride.

title: Northwest Passage Found!!
author: Steve
body:
The Frenzy Expedition successfully discovered the Northwest Passage

We've found a ride that rivals Poorman. Actually, Northwest Passage makes Poorman look rather impoverished—a poor imitation as it were.

Thanks to Dave, Kevin, and Matt for participating in the dangerous scouting mission. Bad news for them: I think I've found yet another, even more secretive route!

comments.comment_body:
Well that was fun. 
My favorite part? The story SB and MB concocted to allow for the huge gap Kevin and I had on them by the time we hit the climb out of 4Mile. Claimed they stopped to help a downed Postal worker deliver his mail and overhaul his Jeep. 
Wow; where do they get this stuff?
DU

title: Thank You for Flying the Frenzy Skies
author: Steve
body:
Thanks to the westerly winds, it's dry out there!

Great fun today with Dave, Greg, and Matt. We fought the cuckoo-inducing Chinooks valiantly. At least on Flagstaff, the wind is at your back in one direction of the hairpin turns!

My throat is utterly parched from our favorite little zephyr, though. I drank an entire bottle of water to no avail. Maybe I'll tote bottled oxygen next time.

If we do get some snow this weekend, get ready for duathlons next week—perhaps even "True Initiation".

title: Tech Talk Ride Report
author: Steve
body: The mile-long ride along the Creek Path over to the Computing Center was fraught with difficulty. Cold air, steep grades, and patches of ice all marred the way. The Frenzies prevailed, however, showing their renowned grit and determination. Dave, did you survive the shopping malls?

comments.comment_body:
No me today either... 
DU

title: Capture the (Super) Flag Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Steve descending Flagstaff's sand-dune hairpins today

Surprisingly good conditions today! I think both Dave and I were prepared to turn around at the first sign of ice, but there wasn't a patch to be found.

In fact, the road was completely dry! The lower section (up to the Amphitheater service road) didn't even have much sand; the upper portion resembled the dunes of the Sahara.

Coming down the super-section, I did ungracefully dismount rather than try to dune-buggy my way around the beachhead hairpins. This made for an unusually long descent, wherein large shavings from my brakepads were discarded roadside.

While carefully picking my way down Heartbreak Hill, imagine my surprise when I saw Brian Kent (not a typo!) climbing on his lime-green Bianchi. He even suggested we may see him on wheels tomorrow too!

Given the unknown trajectory of the impending storm, tomorrow's itinerary will be up in the air until the morning. If we can sneak in a ride, we will likely hit Flagstaff again or possibly Sunshine. If it's snowing, we may settle for a duathlon at Sanitas.

comments.comment_body:
I saw Mr. Kent also. At first I thought it might be a ghost or some obscene trick of atmospheric distortion. But as the distance between us decreased, I noted the singular outward characteristics - the see-sawing motion of the bike against the violent rise of the mountain, the shoulders hunched and taut in a powerful knot of aggressive energy, the foppish pink bandana - that indelibly stamped the struggling figure as none other than the legend himself.
