Knowing it was gonna be a wet one, I packed a spare of just about everything and shoved off. Chautauqua and its environs are much greener than when I left, and the low clouds were reminiscent of some Hobbit scene.

Atop Flag, pea-soup fog lent a mystical air to the road, which was pleasantly devoid of tourist traffic. The only problem was the humidity. Had to take off my glasses for half the ride. Not a bad problem to have, though, if you ask me. Speaking of soup, I'm craving something warm.

Good to be back!

comments.comment_body:
Afraid I'm going to have to take the day off again due to a nasty lingering cold. I actually skipped the Bolder Boulder because of it. Bummer! But thanks to a hand-me-down from LeCarla, Olivia rode a bike for the first time over the weekend. She loved tooling around the neighborhood on her training wheels and I can't wait 'til she can join the Frenz on a ride. Don't worry Dave, it will be a few years until she's breathing down your neck. It was also great to hear her utter a universal biker's complaint: my butt hurts. It was a very proud moment for this dad.
-Greg

JG and I got to the creek crossing on the Royal Arch trail today. All the rain has cloaked the foothills trails in deep green and it's absolutely beautiful up there right now. It always strikes me as ironic that the trails are mostly deserted on the prettiest days. A little rain or snow or sub-zero weather inevitably weeds out the bulk of the "outdoor enthusiasts," and leaves us diehards with plenty of elbow room.
I'm not complaining.
DU

Can we say "Butt" on the Frenzy? Perhaps this will end up being rendered as bu**.

Funny one, Greg...

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Our name is now in lights...well, you get the metaphor!

Our sign is up! During the ride today, Noel, Dave, and I got to see first hand our name etched in Boulder history. Now we just have to do an actual clean up. I'm thinking clean-up session, followed by brunch. How's that sound, boys?

Great weather out there today. Dave says if it never got hotter than today, life would be perfect. Unfortunately, he hasn't seen the forecast for this weekend. Sigh.

comments.comment_body:
I'm w/ you, bro.'
See you at 12:30.
DU

Do we really have a section on Sunshine Canyon named for the Frenz? If so, that's cool.

Greg

Greg,

It's true. Dave didn't Photoshop that!

Now we just have to get some bags and be familiar with how to react to a meth lab, should we stumble upon Dave's distillery:

http://tinyurl.com/5qu4pu

This is going to be fun, huh?!

This changes everything. The Frenzy is no longer a ragtag, loose-knit band of biking ne'er-do-wells, but is now, instead, a real organization, like the Cub Scouts or the Elks or the Retired Mail Handlers of America. Whatever. The point is, we're officially official now.
Take a memo; we need a press secretary, someone to handle all of our PR stuff and run interference when we need it. Who? Scott McClellen? He's available you say?
DU

title: Boxing Boulder Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Some footage from our brief stint in London

Fun ride today. I'm sweating profusely again, which means it's summer or thereabouts. Despite the heat, Rob, Dave, and I encircled our fair town. Poor Dave got a flat along the way—or perhaps he's been keeping his tire pressure even lower than the normal 15psi.

Construction has once again taken over many of Boulder County's roads, rendering the stretch on 75th between 63rd and Jay frustrating due to long wait times. Because it's one-way, there's a certain pressure that goes with being a cyclist; no one wants to be the guy who holds up the traffic waiting on the other side. Especially with Sherrif Rosco P. Coltrane patrolling our streets.

comments.comment_body: How was Boulder Boxing?

In answer to Leeds DATC...

Hot! It felt cool when we took off; it ain't now. I picked up a snake-bite puncture going east on Baseline, and by the time I got it repaired the dynamic duo (Bailey, O'Leary), were already in the next time zone. Never saw 'em again.
The county crews are repaving 75th - filling old potholes and making new ones, so that would be a good area to avoid until they wrap it up. You can check their official website to see when that will be:

leaningonshovelsanddrooling.gov

Come ride w/ us sometime!
DU

title: Fourmile Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Had I known, I would've tried to visit last week

Heading down University into a noticeable headwind, I decided to forgo the planned Fourmile ride in favor of the less traffic-prone Sunshine Canyon climb.

Well worth it too. The Indian Peaks are still coated with snow and stand in stark contrast to the cobalt blue sky.

But my motives for riding Sunshine went beyond a desire for nice scenery. I wanted to see if the "Adopt-A-Road" sign marking the upper end of our territory was in place. It is! I didn't have a camera, though, so no pix.

Dave and Kacey Jones have invited me to tag along for a Jamestown ride to the Merc tomorrow. K-No's outta town for a week or so, but anyone else wishing to join should present themselves at the Greenbriar Inn at 8am sharp.

Happy Weekend!

Greg Wins Award

For biking to work this week from the far off land of Broomfield, Greg has been awarded the Frenzy's "Commuter of the Week" award. The award is sponsored by The American Urinal Refurbishers Union, a real force in the fight for your right to pee upright.

Congrats, Greg!

comments.comment_body:
Way to go on that award, Greg! I got mine back in '88, and though I know a lot of people look askance at that little Golden Puck perched on my mantle, it really means a lot to me. And the folks at The American Urinal Refurbishers Union just couldn't be nicer... Once you get to know them you realize they're just like anyone else in the toilet maintenance and reclamation industry. So don't be nervous; the awards ceremony is over in jif, and the meal afterwards is always fabulous! (Don't let the rubber gloves throw you; they always do that to "newbies.")
J and I found plenty of shade on the Ampitheatre Trail today. Gregory Creek is humming along and it do feel like summer!
DU

title: Old Stage Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Adriana and I were happy to be back in our stomping grounds this weekend!

Knew I shouldn't have been so ambitious on a Monday. Dave had a lunch date, and since he was the motivating force behind the Ye Oulde Stage ride, we decided to hold off until later this week for that adventure.

Instead, Greg and I spun up Flagstaff. Since Greg rode 50 miles this weekend as part of the Elephant Rock, he emphasized the "spin" part of today's ride.

I think we did a good job of riding easy. The rule was "you have to be able to sing" or you're going to fast. Funny, though, neither of us crooned the whole way. Spirit of the law, I suppose. Or perhaps we were content to cruise while comparing notes on Kimbo Slice.

In other news, you can tell it's summer on campus, because the Berlin Wall cordoning off Humanities is back in place. Very difficult to get to my office if you're on the south end of campus.

My woes pale in comparison to Dave's, though. Hopefully he'll regale y'all with his epic (or tragic?) commute story from this morning.

Happy Birthday, Mr. Werner!

comments.comment_body: Those are great scenes. Thanks.

SB asked, so here I go... my morning commute:

I'm riding the bike in to work w/ a pack full of groceries on my back (lunches for the week).
I'm southbound on the Diagonal, have a flat, fix it, get about 150 feet down the road, have another flat. No more spare tubes. I want to call Ronna for a lift, but realize I've forgotten my cell phone. I start walking off toward the soccer fields, borrow a cell phone from a nice lady walking a beagle, call Ronna, tell her I'll be over on Iris in 15 minutes. I walk all the way down some very quiet street by the cemetery, realize it's a dead-end, and that there's a 6 - 7 foot high chain link fence with a very ragged top between me and Iris. Bummer. I hang the bike on the top of the fence, toss the pack over, then remember the yoghurt (that's right; it all popped open inside the pack) I take off my cleats and climb the fence barefoot, slicing up my big toe and tearing my shorts on the way over... rrrriiip. Then I drag my bike across, bending one of the shifters and screwing up the front brakes. I walk over to Iris and wait for Ronna. And wait. And wait. To put more zest into the situation, I've had a full pot of coffee for breakfast, and I could really use a little privacy and a bush. No luck; it's rush hour and the nearest tree is in the front yard of the day care across the street (Wouldn't that be a headline?). The only thing that keeps my mind off my increasing agitation is watching the two colonies of ants fight over the yoghurt oozing out of the bottom of my pack. The reds prevailed just as Ronna pulled up and asked me why I was so damn grumpy.
But enough about my day; how are things going in your world?
DU

Dave,

Silver lining: we won't be able to tell if you have any new holes in your cycling shorts.

Hey, with a morning like that, you've gotta really stretch to take away something positive.

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Ride report, courtesy of Dave:

So nice not having to search Four Mile Creek for bodies today. SB and I briefly interrupted our Poorman ascent to help a couple look for their lost son. He'd been missing for over half an hour, and had disappeared while chasing butterflies. The creek was way high, and they were pretty sure he had tried to cross. Yikes. Call in the divers, break out the hooks. Other bikers stopped, cell phones were flipped open, and things were approaching meltdown. (One guy on a mountain bike was almost smacked by a Jeep as he crossed the road to join the search.) But then, just as some guy was dialing 9-1-1, SB mentioned seeing an old codger up the road, milling about like he was looking for a place to relieve himself. Case solved; that was him... the 62 year-old son (the dad was pushing ninety, mom a spry eighty-something).

Otherwise, a nice breezy trip up our favorite dirtpile. The top section could use a little rain - very loose.

That was an odd "search and rescue," eh? It was all I could do to keep Dave "Brook Trout" Underwood out of the roaring creek.

comments.comment_body:
I still have the bitter taste of yesterday's Nightmare on the Diagonal in my mouth... A dash up 4Mile sounds like just the thing to wash it away.
See y'all at 12:30.
DU

title: Flagstaff NCAR Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dave calls me this all the time. Now I know how to spell it. (courtesy of Mark)

You heard that right! Today we stepped outside our comfort zone and tackled NCAR. Good call, Rob. Despite Dave's absence, our numbers were impressive: Rob, Noel, Greg, and me.

Often we shy away from NCAR simply because one has to ride the bike path to get there and it's not exactly sheltered from chinook winds. But, after today's double lap, I'm going to dial it up more often. Fantastic ride.

Thanks, guys!

comments.comment_body:
JG and I did a variation on the Poorman duathlon; High Ho Silver, a newly discovered summit just south of the upper pipecut saddle. I don't think it's ever been climbed, and doing it w/out oxygen was especially satisfying. We left fixed ropes for the next party.
On the way back to campus, J hit a '97 Camaro w/ her bruiser - I mean cruiser - bike. Holy cow. J claimed she didn't feel a thing.
DU
Steve, where is the picture of the Frenzy Adopt-A-Road sign?  Pictures or it doesn't exist...

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
It's rainy here, and above 8500ft, it's snowing...in June!!

It's just this kind of day that makes me glad I live in Boulder! Today's ride, despite the 47° temps and rain, was spectacular. Verdant green!

Venturing out in such conditions does require some preparation, however. First off, I revived a trick my mom taught me for sledding in the wet New Hampshire snow: put plastic bags on your feet. Then, I relied on some MWO and USFS experience in bringing dry clothes (in a small backpack).

With all that, I was perfectly prepared; in fact, it was one of the warmer cold rides I've done.

Needless to say, I was alone out there: no other Frenz or even other cyclists. I'm not sure why either. With the steady, prolonged rain, all oils have long since been wrung out of the pavement, so one only needs to beware of the paint stripes. Otherwise, the biggest concern is de-fogging your glasses.

Saw a touch of snow on some of the upper ramparts of the Flatirons. Otherwise, just a lot of worms out on the road.

My dear wife left me a nice warm egg and cheese bagel, so life is quite good. Now back to the craziness. Tomorrow, be ready for an epic ride (something to do with Lee Hill); ask your boss for some extra time at lunch—or concoct some story about Dave's tire puncturing...that one ain't a stretch!

comments.comment_body:
You weren't entirely alone out there today, Steve-O. JG and I did the McClintock loop, keeping you company in spirit at least. We didn't see a soul on the trail, and on this, one of the most beautiful days of the year!
I know what you mean about being glad to live in Boulder. Just think of the poor saps in Denver who ride around and around and around Wash Park on their lunch breaks. Holy cow.
DU

i think steve needs to check out http://glazeddoughnut.us/sanity/index.php.

Dennis
I'm only about 80% insane, thank you very much!  Fully qualified to work in the CTO's office.

That list of stuff on the insanity check... they meant all in one day, right?
Then I think I'm okay. Mostly.
DU

title: And It Burns, Burns, Burns...Report
author: Steve
body:
Yeehaw! Now that's a ride!!

The Ring of Fire certainly delivered on its promise, though today "Whirlwind of Fire" might have been a more apt moniker.

Dave and I spent a long day in the saddle. Only minor traffic to deal with and a few other cyclists to boot.

We really enjoyed the descent down Lefthand. I almost overcooked a turn near the Lee Hill/Lefthand junction, but I recovered in time. Then, Dave and I found ourselves embraced by an F5 tornado at the top of Old Stage. Yikes. I guess they'd call that the effects of orographic lift.

Anyhow, great time. Happy weekend, all!

comments.comment_body:
What kinda' pervert would dial up a ride like this? And on a Friday!
See ya' at noon.
DU

title: Spin Out East
author: Steve
body: Dave's trying to organize a slacker ride, leaving around noon. Give him a call if you're interested in spinning out east (2-2672). I'm in a meeting until 12:30p. No me today.

comments.comment_body:
Slacker ride? Yeah, that's got my name all over it. I'll be giving you a call DU.

Just saw the latest clip from the Gloucestershire Cheese Rolling derby (http://youtube.com/watch?v=OpzEF0D2xfE). I wonder what this would look like if the Frenz tried to pull off the Boulder equivalent? Would we call it Boulder Hippie Rolling? Or Boulder Frosh Rolling?

ges

Speaking of cheese rolling, GS borrowed my bike - Widowmaker - for a ride today. I warned him that it was a cantankerous beast, and that it was wont to capriciously toss unfamiliar guests into the weeds. He was feeling brave, evidently, and took off like a flash, claiming he and K-No were going to go "hammer the biscuit" out east for awhile. I pictured them cranking 28 mph for an hour straight, up South Boulder Road and back on Lookout or somesuch.
Half an hour later they were spotted on the creek trail. Turns out they were trying raise lunch money by match racing the nice ladies from the Fraser Meadows Velo and Needlepoint Club. A quarter a gear to the railroad crossing and back.
Bad day for wagering, though... I had to lend GS five bucks when he returned the bike.
DU

title: Magnolia Road Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Hmm...coming down into my price range

Wow! Now that's a climb.

Dave and I braved 86°F temps, traffic, and tunnels on today's adventure. Oh, did I mention 20% plus slopes?!!

Yup, Magnolia is a killer. But, the rewards are spectacular. I think it's got some of the best terrain and views of our lunchtime forays. I'll definitely head back up sometime this summer, perhaps as part of a big loop on the Peak-to-Peak.

Anyhow, Dave hit the creek on the way down. Needed to bring his core temperature back down to 104°F. You okay, Underwood?

Wonder how the Frisbee Frenz outing went? Report, anyone?

comments.comment_body:
Say what? You'll have to speak up; I have water in my ears.
After scrappin' our way up and down the Big Mag, the creek was my first choice on the menu. The water's still cold enough to inhibit normal breathing, but damn, it felt good!
The last time I rode Magnolia, I was with Jeannie Longo. Okay, okay... not with her exactly, but in the same race, the Mike Horgan Hillclimb. She was a little ways out in front of me (5 miles, +/-) for most (all, really) of the race. Afterwards, we laughed over drinks (she on the jet back to Paris, me in my boxers on the back porch) and reminisced (passed out, actually, in my case).
Oh, the memories...
DU

Doris, Mike, and I went to the course near Broadway and Greenbriar by the South Boulder rec center: http://www.ci.boulder.co.us/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1386&Itemid=452

The course wasn't too crowded. Mike was the master, lofting drives up to the tee mostly. He definitely broke par.

Doris and I were more the "duffers" of the outing. Doris tried various frisbees, some designed for disc golf, and others for general use. She experimented with various throws: how much to snap the wrist, how much of a lead to give yourself, at what height to let go...

I struggled with my new driver which slices left dramatically (not unlike my regular golf drives). The wind was quite gusty, which made the course more challenging.

A good time was had by all and we hope to get more people out sometime in the future. Perhaps the cycling frenz can play a version of polo by combining mountain bikes with frisbees.

title: Super-Flag Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Rob, Dave, and I had a super ride up Super-Flag this afternoon. One would think it was December, what with the shifty winds and all. Good thing was the wind sure kept your sweat from getting in your eyes or glasses—it's so dry, your sweat flash-evaporates! Indeed, just checked and the relative humidity today is 12%.

Rob had an intriguing idea: a Super-Flag duel, where runners race bikers by taking Gregory Canyon and the Long Canyon trails. Sounds fun!

title: Flagstaff Sunshine Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Word on the street is "The Guthernator" rode with Dave today. Good going, Jennifer! When are you going to join us?

So, Koster and I hit Sunshine today, determined to keep our heart rates below 175bpm. No such luck. Oh well. Great ride just the same. Koster reminded me that I'm a slow descender. Where were you, Greg?

After a weekend of 7-8% relative humidity readings, today's 60% was muggy—though my family back east remind me that that's nothin'! At least I only needed one water bottle.

comments.comment_body:
I'll join you ruffians as soon as you cart a cooler around with martinis and tom collinses for mid-ride "rest stops."

Or when I've learned to live with that soreness between my shoulderblades, whichever comes first.

See you soon!

Yeah, and right behind J's "refreshment cart" you can hitch my crash cart. Double-stock the ace bandage and phenyl-oprabetadine... I go through that stuff like crazy.

Speaking of street rumors, we hear that Rupert Murdoch has shown interest in the Frenzy. He considers it a "fair and balanced" news source, but would like to make a few tweaks. He also mentioned cutting staff. Not to be alarmist, SB, but you do have a backup plan, don't you?

DU

title: Sugarloaf Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Some shots of the steep slopes of Sugarloaf Road (view gallery)

Man, it was gorgeous out there! We could tell it was hot, but it certainly wasn't the 90s Boulder had today. Fantastic day!!

comments.comment_body:
Last week Magnolia... this week the boat ramp on the sunny side of the canyon. Oh boy...
See ya' at noon,
DU

title: Somethin' New Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Tycho is a great deejay, but he's also a talented graphic designer!

Fun spin out to Eldorado Springs this afternoon. Dave, Rob, and I agree the bike path is not an ideal way to open up the throttle, but once you're out on Marshall Road you can glide. Thanks, guys!

I'm out tomorrow, but I'll post a ride for anyone who wants to organize. Dave's out too.

comments.comment_body:
I wish Roberto would race every weekend. I love riding w/ a guy who's tapering. I'll run up the score whenever I can, ethics be damned.

Good luck Saturday, Rob! If that big Valkyrie pulls up alongside you at Mile 3 and tells you "you should start drinking now, believe her. She means business.

DU

title: Neva Loop Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
It's true: Kevin's still working for CU-Boulder...or at least living nearby. He joined "us" today for a great spin on Neva Loop ("us" being me). Long time, no see, K-No!

It was kinda breezy the whole way, so chit-chatting was tough. 63rd was strangely busy with traffic, but instead of taking the Diagonal back, we followed 63rd to Valmont, which was less busy and thus more enjoyable.

So, Kev, when's the next screening of Dexter, Season 2 happening? Happy weekend, all!

Bike to Work Day: Next Wednesday, June 25

Don't forget. Next Wednesday is Bike to Work Day, and our good fox/hound friend Dave Cavalieri has organized an ITS team. So, sign up now and be sure to join the "University of Colorado at Boulder - ITS team".

title: Flagstaff Ride Report?
author: Steve
body:
I had to bail last minute on the Flagstaff ride. How was it, Greg?

Instead of spinning up switchbacks, I spun home to meet the chimney sweep who was trying to keep birds from flying in my house—they've been swooping down the chimney like Tom Cruise.

I did manage to sneak in a little run on South Fork of the Shanahan with Espresso, tho. Of course, later, when I returned home, there was a bird in my chimney again, despite the new screen.

comments.comment_body: Since my nemesis is living la vida loca in Cortez, it's probably safe for me to join today's outing. See you at noon.

title: Poorman Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Very nice spin up the canyon today, despite the hot, desiccating breeze. Lots of folks out on the road, which is great to see. Since I saw no one else out there, how did your lunches go?

Upcoming Events

Tomorrow is Bike to Work Day. Apparently CU is giving away limited edition BtWD tee-shirts at their UMC and Math stations, so get there early. Should be some good food too. If you haven't already, sign up now!

This morning, I went down to the county office and completed my Adopt-A-Road safety training. So, we're good to go for July 10: Frenzy Rubbish Day!

From Dave to Rob

Dave asked me to post this little message for Rob:

A tip of the Frenzy bowler to Rob Leary for pushing aside an impressive moraine of Matt Carpenter wannabes in Saturday's Mt. Evans road race. Great run Rob! Clearly, last week's taper and kid-glove treatment of Underwood the Elder paid off.

-DU (2:41, Mt. Evans Class of '99)

Rob, was it windy? Cold? How'd Maria do?

comments.comment_body:
To all wondering about the Mt. Evans Ascent:

Well, I finished, and i didn't come in too late. It wasn't easy, and it wasn't pretty either. I felt a little sad as DU's 2:41 record passed while I was gasping for air at mile 12, but I persevered. When you think that the guy who won finished nearly an hour-and-a-half before me.... well... I need to train harder for Pikes!

But thanks for all the support I got from you guys... You're the best!

Hey Roberto,
Just remember... that guy who finished 1.5 hours up on you is from another species. He (Matt Carpenter) doesn't breathe the same air we breathe, and he sure as hell doesn't know what gravity is. Some day the podcraft will come and fetch him, then we'll all be happier.
You did great!
DU

Since you asked, Steve...
Jennifer and I were going to do our usual Kohler Mesa thing today, but it was w-a-a-a-y too hot. Stuck to the creek and the shade and it was nice. My idea. J was good-to-go for the climb, but I think I would've keeled over. Can't wait for cooler weather. Only two more months(!).
DU

title: Sugarloafers Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
This is the first decent cycling video I've seen; takes place in Tenerife, a shady place for pro-cyclists

Well, Dave's last ride before going under the knife was a good one: nice cloud cover and pleasant temperatures. In other words, Dave didn't have one of his "light-headed" episodes—his doctor frowns on that type of pre-surgery regime.

Anyhow, I managed to make it up to the burn area off Sugarloaf Mountain, which was quite nice. Apart from being treeless, there's no real sign that the area fried a few years ago. Au contraire, there were meadows of tall green grass and bright flowers.

Still, you can tell something's not quite right about the place. Somehow your eye detects that this shouldn't be an alpine zone. Funny that.

Wish Dave Well

Tomorrow at 0730, Dave gets cut open. Wish him well this afternoon if you have a minute.

Funny, Greg, now that I think about it, your theory about this surgery might not be that far from the truth. Dave's been talking a lot about cyborgs and such of late, and I simply shrugged it off—as I do with most of the tripe that dribbles out of his dehydrated trap.

Let's keep an eye on him when he's back, particularly if he's "recovered" early.

comments.comment_body:
Sorry to miss Dave's last ride before going under the knife. My fear is that the true nature of his "surgery" is not so much about restoring his normal function as it is about giving him super-human powers along the lines of Steve Austin. Afraid my days of edging out the old guy could be numbered.

BTW, hope you didn't come across any bears on your ride up Sugarloaf.

-Greg

title: Valmont Rez Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dave would be proud and jealous of us at the same time, for we had new blood join our ranks today: Hideo Kawanabe.

Much to Dave's chagrin, however, Hideo isn't the fluff newbie Dave's used to beating up on. He's going to be a formidable adversary, the more so since I let him in on all Dave's "rookie tricks." Anyhow, thanks for riding, Hideo!

Rob Leary, Mr. Mount Evans himself, also spun out east with us. Temps were just perfect with nice cloud-cover to boot. The fields are still green, but if this weather keeps up, all will soon be brown!

Once again, hope you're well Dave. Kevin has promised not to write those riotously funny comments that he always posts, lest we add to your already impressive laundry-list of injuries.

title: Magnolia Super-Flag Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dave says surgery went well, but his nurse isn't very nurturing

Knew chances of company were slim today, so when my inkling was confirmed outside Humanities, I decided to steer clear of Magnolia—like having an amigo when riding Boulder Canyon.

Thus amigo-less, I climbed high, nearly making the news myself when I barely avoided a low-speed collision with a fawn that walked right in front of me while climbing the 25% hairpin near Lost Gulch. Fortunately, I was going about 1mph, so there would've been no real news story.

The timing of the accident would've been perfect, however, as I saw ABC Denver News reporter Dayle Cedars in front of the camera at the Gregory Canyon trailhead. Wonder what she was covering? She's pregnant, by the way!

Report from Dave

Mr. Underwood was in great spirits this morning when I talked to him. The operation took four hours, and he hasn't needed any pain meds (no surprise, there).

He said he has "106 channels of crud to watch and a good book," so I think he'll make it through the day. He has another angiogram today and will need to spend the night, but he should be home tomorrow.

Good to hear you're well, Davey!

comments.comment_body:
I'd like to do Magnolia one of these days, but I have a 1pm meeting.

Despite my infrequent Frenzy appearances of late, I haven't been totally neglecting the bike - I've ridden Old Stage twice this week after work. Fortunately, I didn't run into any bears.

Well that was easy.

My surgery was a piece 'o cake, and my doctor tells me my subclavicular vein is flowing along like the Autobahn now. All good news.
The yellow caution flag is still up, though, for at least another week, i.e., I'm under a few restrictions...

1. No lifting anything over 400 pounds above my head. I think I can do that.

2. I have to closely watch my alcohol intake. Not a problem; I can drag a chair right to the mirror before popping a cold one, though I can't imagine how this could be therapeutic.

3. No swimming in Boulder Creek. Though they stuffed me full of antibiotics before they sewed back up, there's a chance that anything downstream of Eban Fine could take me out.

4. I'm to avoid my mother-in-law's meatloaf. (I'm lobbying to make this one permanent.)

5. This one sucks: no biking. My surgeon specifically mentioned my "n'er-do-well buddies from the Frenzy." She said they had "about as much collective sense as a sea cucumber," and that riding with them would void the warranty. What a lightweight.

Sooo... It looks like I'm earthbound again for awhile. That means Kohler Mesa, Kohler Mesa, Kohler Mesa, Kohler Mesa, Kohler Mesa, I s'pose.

Sheesh.
DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Wow! Great weather. It's hot if you're just moping around in the sun, but on the bike, it's just dandy.

On the way up, I once again saw a deer grazing next to the road, completely unfazed by the traffic. Made me a little cautious on the way down...as usual.

Tour de France (Doping) News

For those of you in doubt about the effectiveness of doping or the tests designed to find dopers, here's an excerpt from a recent NYT article:

The researchers were primarily interested in learning whether the young men's athletic performance improved "” it did, and markedly so. At maximum effort, the men's performances improved by 9 to 16 percent. But at a slightly lower level of exertion, performance improved by 50 percent, Dr. Lundby said. Athletes taking EPO can go 50 percent longer at that somewhat lower level of effort, which can make a major difference in an endurance event like the Tour de France or a marathon, Dr. Lundby said.

[full article]

Between 9-16% improvement at maximum capacity?! Up to 50% improvement at medium capacity?! Anyone know the number of a good, unscrupulous doctor?

comments.comment_body:
J and I did the Flagstaff up-and-over trail off of Pleasant Street. Bloody hot! We used the Creek Trail for the return leg, and the shade and the creek were just the ticket.
I'm thinking of trying a bit of so-called running tomorrow. After all, the doc only said no biking.
DU

title: Secret Stroll Report
author: Steve
body:
Sometimes I think Dave is my own personal Sgt. Doakes...

I got really swamped this morning, so I didn't have time to post anything. Fortunately for me, however, the astute Dr. Lenski rung me up and said: Get off your keester! We're riding!! And so I did.

We spun out Marshall, Cherryvale, and Baseline Roads, reeling in and passing folks with spirit-crushing speed. Subsequently, several ambulances were called to fetch the shattered remains of egos from the side of the road.

Good thing too, as those egos really get ripe in this heat.

title: Flagstaff Independence Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Since he can't ride up, Dave decided to bomb down

Just as well, Kev, my meeting with a faculty member ran over (30min), so I didn't get out until 12:30p. Sorry to anyone who may have been waiting for me at 12:10p.

But, as you can imagine, it was a fantastic day to be out. It's a little more humid and hazy than normal, but not unbearable by any stretch. The 73° temps are a welcome respite from the 90s!!

Happy Fourth, All!!

comments.comment_body: The Man is infringing on my lunch.  Meetings at 11:00 and 1:00 mean I'm office-bound.  I'll try to get out after work and not become a total sloth.

That guy descending Flagstaff is on his breaks too much.

-Greg

He's also using his brakes too much.

Greg

Only Greg would say that...
He's he only guy I know w/ cobwebs on his brake levers. He's not reckless; he's simply conserving his brakes for future generations.

"And these were my great-grandpa's brake pads!"

"Cool! It doesn't look like he ever used 'em! Can I hold them?"

DU

PS,
I see my surgeon next Wednesday. (She's doing a demo at Home Depot, so I won't have to drive all the way back down to the Aurora VoTech again. Nice.) I'm assuming she'll tell me it's okay to resume biking. And I'm assuming she's building a conservative cushion into her timeline, because I'm assuming she's assuming I'm too obtuse to grasp the idea of gradual, managed recovery and healing... So look for me back on wheels Monday. Can hardly wait!
Does anyone have a camera Greg can borrow for the hi-speed version of the Flag descent?

Re: the camera for Greg's descent...
Not one of ours! They don't have those little space shuttle tiles on them. No way!
DU

title: Fourmile Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
It is reported that Mr. X "may have" joined the Frenz today. This report has not been confirmed. Sources close to Mr. X declined to comment, stating it would be a "gross affront to common sense" if Mr. X were to have ridden today.

And this reporter will not rat out his pals! Unless it involves Scooter Libby of course.

comments.comment_body:
I'd just finished up a nasty opraectomy when one of the orderlies told me I had a call. I took it on the phone in the scrub room. A voice, reed thin and immediately annoying, told me, "I just saw one of your patients riding a bicycle in Four Mile Canyon."
It was Scube Bellows, my eyes and ears on the outside world. I'd hired him two years ago to do follow-up on my patients, and though he made my skin crawl like a snake on glass, he was good at what he did.
"Which patient?"
"The tall one, the big dumbass you did the rib-job on last week. He was half way up the canyon with one of his buddies, a knobby-kneed little tweaker from the trade school. Had a smile on his mug like the grill on a '57 Buick, and he was riding one of those big pink circus bikes. It was him alright."
"So, did you bring him in?"
"Sure did. He's out in the van right now. What you want I should do with him?"
"Bring the moron up to the O.R.. I think this time I'll..."

To be continued....

title: Bow Mountain Boogie Report
author: Steve
body:
Tim Riggs joined us on today's hot ride of Bow Mountain

Wow! Tim Riggs made his Frenzy debut today, showing everyone he's made of pure salt and vinegar by riding his 2.3 metric ton classic mountain bike almost all the way to Cedar Brook Road on his first ride! Nice work, Tim.

Unfortunately, we lost Dr. Lenski somewhere along the climb. We thought we caught a glimpse of him floating uphill far ahead of us, but we quickly realized it was just paragliders. I think he felt the pace and itinerary were beneath him and took off for thinner air.

Dave and I took it easy. It was just too hot to be ambitious.

Tomorrow's Cleanup Day!

Join your Frenz tomorrow either at 7a @ the Southside Walnut Cafe or at 8a @ the Bald Mountain Parking Lot to take part in our inaugural Sunshine Canyon Drive cleanup.

comments.comment_body:
So I'm riding up Fourmile w/ Bailey the other day when this white van pulls in between us, cuts me off, and screeches to a stop. This little shrew of a guy with bad teeth and a Milwaukee Braves ball cap jumps out and points some sort of little plastic gun at me. Then everything goes black. I dream of barbed wire and wrought iron.

After what seems like an eternity, I wake up. Through the lifting fog I see that I'm back in the operating room at the Aurora VoTech. It's freezing.

"You didn't listen to me. I said no biking for four weeks."

I turn my head and see that it's my surgeon. She's sitting in a chair next to my bed. The latest People magazine is on her lap, and there's a half-eaten bag of Doritos on the table at her elbow. She smells of horseradish.

To be continued....
That's a funny spoof on The 10!
Where is "almost all the way to Cedar Brook Road"? Tim rocks.

Way to go Tim....! Not bad for a life long lover of fine Virginia tobacs lovingly roasted in cheap corn cob pipes. If I do say so myself. By the way, I remember some promises that if I took up riding, you'd take up smoking (tobacco...!). So, grab your favorite stogie, briar, or pack of cigs (if that's all you have) and we can meet at Regent Michael Carrigan's office for a "Smoke In". Any takers? Bueller...? Bueller...?

Tim

I got lost in the twilight zone today and never saw the rest of yas again.

Good work Tim! I'll smoke somethin' on your behalf (though I can't say on this blog what it will be).

Come to think of it, maybe what I've been smokin' has sumpin' to do with why I got lost in the twilight zone today...

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
I have great Frenz! Thanks for joining today, everyone.

Noel, Kevin, Greg, Adriana, Dave, Mark, and I gave something back to the hills we love this morning. Some of the interesting tidbits we found: car bumper, remains of car wreck, retirement diploma from U. of Illinois, and much more.

The most boggling thing was the cigarettes. Come on, people! We found lots of other interesting things too. What was the most interesting find in your minds, guys?

Today's Actual Ride Report

Hot.

comments.comment_body:
A fairly intact deer skeleton just five feet or so off of the road was an interesting find. Dave found a car tire and some parts from a hot tub. We found lots of liquor bottles and cans. That's a bit scary...

Beautiful day. Thanks Everyone.

- Mark.

Alas, my sweet dog was in the hospital this morning, so at the LAST MINUTE I discovered I couldn't make it.

She's been eating rocks again and fractured her tooth. Nothing a little oral surgery won't fix, but it kept me out of the festivities.

Enjoy your recollections!

RL

Oh yeah, I forgot one more thing; there was a golf ball on a fairly steep incline. It was a Wilson. If I remember correctly, I think Mike Matthies hits Wilsons. I bet he teed that one up on the roof of Telecom. I'd say it went ten miles at least on the first bounce. We'll have to call him "Extreme John Daly."

-- Mark.

Rob,

I hope Kylie's okay!! Wish her well from the Frenz!!!

I think finding the University of Illinois "diploma" -- actually just a certificate of appreciation from the Illini regents -- was a cool find. Coming across the scene of a car crash and all the debris was weird. But I have to agree that all the cigarette butts, although not a surprise, were very disappointing with all the wild fires we've had over the last few years.

-Greg

title: Fourmile Neva Airport Road Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Cavs and I agree: bring back the Coors Classic!

Sean Pease broke a record on today's ride, but unfortunately it wasn't the hour record or something else. No, poor guy had four or so flats.

Still it was great to get out, despite the darn heat and dry wind—relative humidity currently: 4%!!! Cavs also joined today's proceedings, and he reminded me that I have no business even pretending to sprint.

Thanks for coming today, guys! Have a good weekend, everyone.

title: Boxing Boulder Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
The Brett Favre story has nothing on this clever invention! (courtesy of Jennifer)

It's a real sauna out there, and not one of those Finnish ones where you can run out the door into a frozen lake. Nope, inescapable.

Still, Dave and I braved the (character building – Dave's words) conditions and spun around town. Dave capped things off with the customary dip in Boulder Creek, which he assured me his doctor has approved...as of this Thursday.

Tomorrow???

Cavs asked if we could do Neva tomorrow. Takers? I'm taking my bike to Full Cycle for a full tune at 10am, so I won't be able to go.

comments.comment_body:
I heard the dreaded "bink" sound, followed by a nasty wheel wobble as we headed back in on Baseline. Bummer. And, as always, the broken spoke is on the fat side of my rear wheel, which adds a fair amount of overhead to the repair... gotta' yank the freewheel, etc..
At least the spoke failed at the end of the ride. Boxing Boulder with a Fanny Fox shimmy would've been a real drag.
Great ride otherwise. Thanks for breaking wind, Steve, so to speak.
DU

title: Easy-Peasy Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
This is from the IT Community Event Keynote. Great piece!

It seemed cooler today. I think it was the cloud-cover. Or maybe it was the fact that I rode the whole way in my granny gear?

It was nice getting a touch of rain yesterday evening—hopefully there will be more of the same this evening. It would be swell if the rain would wait until after I'm home, though. I'm tired of getting expensive tune-ups, only to have rain and sand immediately foul things up!

Not many folks riding up Flagstaff this afternoon. Fine with me. How were the trails, Davey?

Good weekend to all!

comments.comment_body:
Ever since Lance Armstrong made "testicular" a household word, Americans have avidly followed bike racing. Me too. Thus it was, when perusing the cycling news section in the Denver Post (hint; it's just south of the section devoted to water wrestling), that I noticed our own lovely and talented Steve Bailey will be racing in this weekend's Bob Cook Hillclimb, otherwise known as the Race to the Troposphere. How exciting.

I'm anxious to see how SB does. While it's true that Steve is a true scrapper, he's no common schoolyard pug, nosiree Bob. He may be fiercely competitive, but he's also habitually analytical and deeply thoughtful, which is to say he cheats. It'll be interesting to see what happens when the 30cc of HGH2 kicks in. The guy he bought it from assures him that it's well-buffered, and that the shakes and blurred vision shouldn't present that much of a problem. The stuttering could be an issue though, but it usually goes away in 3 - 5 days. (Please don't tease him next week.)

If Steve can hang onto the handlebars and if the hallucinations don't invite him to the All-U-Can-Eat pizza buffet just over that cliff, he should do quite well, possibly even finishing in the top 90 percent. Let's all wish him good luck!

My wheel is still getting fixed, so I'm on foot again today.

DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Well, I had hoped there would be brooding clouds and looming thunderstorms, but alas, only sun and heat!

Still, it's always better to be a little uncomfortable while outside on a bike than comfortable in a chair at your desk.

Anyone see the new Batman? I wasn't as thrilled as the critics, but it was worth going to the matinée.

title: Sugarloaf Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
A little ditty for Ricardo Ricco. Catchy tune... Hopefully CSC hasn't been singing along

Still darn hot and dry. But, today, there's hope that thunderheads will actually deliver. Fingers crossed.

Dave had to be back early, so we stuck close to home and enjoyed our favorite ride. Dave hit the creek after, as per usual. Stay cool, all!

comments.comment_body:
I hate summer. I hate summer. I hate summer. I hate summer. I hate summer. I hate summer.

DU

title: Oops
author: Steve
body: Too busy to ride this afternoon. I'm hoping to ride home the long way to make up for it. Anyone watch the Alpe d'Huez stage?

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dave's Delightful Day in the Saddle

After I last saw you (and after having had my second flat), Dr. No pulled alongside me. We rode up to the gate together, then he aimed for SuperFlag, and I headed back down, being mostly out of time by now.

Halfway down, I snapped another spoke (front wheel) and was riding with a bad case of the wobbles when I had my 3rd flat (front wheel) of the day. I was out of tubes, so I decided to ride it back to the office on the rim, i. e., to-hell-with-it. Noel caught up w/ me back on Baseline and rode alongside me for a bit, but I think the smell of burning rubber from my front wheel really got to him. He offered me a spare tube, but I swear, by this point the idea of changing one more flat gave me the jeebies.

Sheesh.

Mr. Burton chimes in from Florida:
As part of the Aviation Preflight Indoctrination (API) course I took a ride in the pressure chamber. The air is gradually sucked out of this chamber until the air is the same thickness (thin- ness?) as it is at 25,000' above sea level.


At minute 5:00 or so, Matt makes his hypoxic appearance
We start out with our oxygen masks on. As part of the training we take the masks off and experience hypoxia, which is a lack of oxygen to the brain. The effects are dizziness, lack of motor skills, euphoria, and a light-headed feeling—much like being drunk. We play 'Pensacola Paddy-Cake' to test our abilities.

I'm referred to as "number 11" in the video because I'm sitting in seat 11. The dude playing with the shapes toy is the other Air Force student in my class.

Paddy-cake? Are you sure you're really in the Air Force, Matt?

comments.comment_body:
I don't know about y'all, but I think it's a little sad seeing MB end up like this. In fact, I couldn't get all the way through the clip... just too many bad memories.

You see, I lost an uncle to recreational hypoxia, and the sight of MB and his addled pals doing the ol' "Paddy-Cake Punchup" just hits me square in the gut. Jeez... give me a moment; I'm tearing up again. The whole thing is still so fresh in my mind. Sniff.

There, I feel better now, thanks for that Kleenex.

At least they're still wearing their clothes. When the Sheriff's Department finally broke the door down and found my uncle and the other "Paddy Cake PunchBoyz," it wasn't a pretty sight. Helmets and G-suits scattered about, amyl nitrate caps ground into the carpet, a pyramid of empty Mountain Dew cans in the center of the room, and Donny Osmond's "I Wanna' be a Flyboy, too" still looping on the iPod. God... there I go again... sniff.

I just hope our boy in blue puts the brakes on before he skids into a fate like my uncle's. This really is no time to get into bad habits like this. Hell, there's a war on, in case you didn't notice.

DU

Hey guys. Greetings from southern Virginia. I just needed to point out to the working masses that I've been enjoying a lot of the Tour as it happens. Yesterday's ride up d'Huez was a highlight. Lots of attacking and masterful riding by the CSC guys to protect the break by Sastre. When it comes to biking, as a participation sport, I'm having to live vicariously as I don't have a bike here, but I am doing some running. It's just a little tough when it's 80 F at 7 am with 80 percent humidity.

See y'all next week.

Greg

Dang! The air force looks like fun. Reminds me of my days in the circle, chanting something that made the paddy cakes easier.

"Stella ella ola
Quack quack quack
Say es chigo chigo
Chigo Chigo Cack Chack
Es Chigo Chigo Vallo
Vallo, Vallo vallo vallo
Say 1-2-3-4-5"

Something you could try, Mr. MB? Maybe if D's uncle and his cronies had been using the power of the chant, they wouldn't have ended up loosing consciousness to Osmond... maybe.

Vive la Tour!

Greg,

I can't believe you're running in VA at the height of summer. Don't they measure humidity in gallons there?

Remember though, Steve. Greg doesn't sweat, he glows.
DU
Dave, you leave me speechless.  Or oxygen-less... one of the two.
When I ran x-country in VA, we never complained about the humidity.  doing so would inevitably lead one to a "private meeting" with coach kelly in his, er, office.

title: (A Little More Than) Neva Loop Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Wow! Big ride today. Great group too! Turns out Dave flunked his InDesign course last week and had to take a remedial course this week. Slacker!

Anyhow, Julian joined Rob and me on a little Lefthand Canyon excursion. Hearing about Dennis's new bike and seeing Julian's definitely makes me want to get a new ride. I like the Cannondale and would still use it as a winter bike, but a nice new light ride would be swell.

Anyhow, thanks for riding today, guys! Have a good weekend.

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Mount Elbert hike gallery; no wonder my legs are sore.

Well, the brooding clouds almost scared me off, but not quite. Indeed, I rode into the belly of the beast this noonday and re-emerged a changed man.

Just kidding. Actually, it started raining at Crisman, and by the time I was in Salina it was a steady rain and noticeably cooler. Luckily, I had brought my brand new wind vest, which is white and now somehow has grease on it(!!), so the trip down was comfortable.

Still lots of pain in my quads and calfs from yesterday's hike. All those unused stabilizer muscles, I guess. Sounds like I might activate them again this weekend with some type of Divide run. Interest?

title: Flagstaff Spin Report
author: Steve
body:
With all eyes on him this year, Cadel Evans revealed a different side of himself

Dave and I sauntered up Flagstaff today, reminiscing about the comfortable 16°F days of winter. Last night I ordered insulated boots from Sierra Trading Post, so this must be part of a larger biorhythm thing. It is almost August, after all. Soon, I'll be chopping and squirreling away wood.

Anyhow, it was great running into Julian, Hideo, and a hefty contingent of the ETS gang shortly after we arrived atop Flag. Good to see you out there, guys!

Dave, how was the creek?

Again, anyone up for a little run this weekend?

comments.comment_body:
Nice getting my bike back in order and on the road again today, though I felt a bit like the crew on the first flight after the Challenger crash; I kept my eyes firmly glued to the big red EJECT button all the way down. Any time I do my own mechanical work, especially on mission-critical stuff like wheels and brakes, I naively renew my faith in soft landings.

The creek was lovely, thanks. I raced a golden retriever for a tennis ball bobbing up against the opposite bank, but the pup was quick for a dog paddler, let me tell ya.' I just hate it when they gloat. Jeez, I would've given him the ball anyway.

DU

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Sean found this funny graph. Can we slap on an ITS logo, Dave?

Wow! Our numbers more than doubled today, going from two to five—quintupled if you consider the fact that Dave and my collective intelligence equals that of a four year old child who's been locked in a closet.

Greg returned from steamy VA, and Hideo and Rob joined in. We would've been six, but rumor has it Hideo pleaded with Julian not to ride with us. His doctor says riding with Julian is bad for his health.

Sunshine was not really the coolest ride around; in fact, it may have been the hottest choice. But, as Dave always says, it was a character building day. I can't wait for cool fall breezes.

comments.comment_body:
Two Men and a Brain... That's SB and me alright. Halfway up Sunshine we concocted a new goal; biking Flag at both ends of a one hundred degree spread. We've got the high end set at about 101Â° or so, but our southern border is currently only 16Â°, so there's work to be done. If my math is right, we need to pick up another 15Â°. I'd rather do it at the low end.

Speaking of dumb, the guy I saw cliff-diving in Boulder Creek today will surely be ejected from the gene pool, if not later this afternoon, then certainly within days... weeks at the outside. I think The Men's Warehouse would have classified this guy as a Portly, and the way he abused gravity was breathtaking... I pitied the trout. Yikes.

DU

title: Sugarloaf Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
4,654 visits since Jan 1; I think I know who's responsible for the Latvia and UK visits

I had to summon all my strength just to get out the door today. I'm so tired of this heat that it's becoming hard to motivate. I'm just not sure it's actually healthier to ride.

In any event, as usually happens in these situations, once I hit the road, I was glad to be outdoors. Since no one had time to ride or since they found the 12:30p start time inconvenient, I decided to forgo the dangerous Boulder Canyon and instead tackle Flagstaff.

Ended up tagging along with a current CU student who was quite a talented rider, though he was feeling out of shape. I assured him that 100°F temperatures do that.

Mr. Burton chimed in again yesterday with an update from Pensacola, FL. Here's an excerpt from his latest missive:

My latest adventure was Aviation Preflight Indoctrination (API) at Naval Air Station Pensacola. As you by now I'm doing joint pilot training with the Navy; that is I am in the Air Force and doing an exchange program of sorts.

The last stop before "flying the plane" pilot training is API. It consists of four weeks of in-depth academics covering aerodynamics, weather, systems, flight rules, and navigation. In addition we completed Navy water survival, land survival, and parachute qualification. But enough of my babbling... onto the videos!
The Dreaded Helo Dunker (Video)
Courtesy of a class that came through a couple weeks before I did. We had to take three rides in the darned thing from three different positions. On the last ride we wore goggles that were spray painted black to simulate nighttime conditions.
Redneck Parasailing (Video)
This is the last event before 'graduating' from API. We spend time in both the classroom and in gravel pits practicing our landings prior to the big day. It's 'Redneck' because we're being towed behind an F-350 instead of behind a boat. Can you believe I'm getting paid to do this?!
In true Navy fashion I have about three weeks downtime with minimal work during the week until I start formal pilot training. It kicks off on 25 Aug with two weeks of academics before FINALLY hitting the flight line.

Until then...

Dave, what's your take on all this?

comments.comment_body: Lafayette is number 3? Either I visit way more often than I think, or I have someone stalking me and posting live details.

My take on Burton's latest?
Go ahead, twist my arm.

Helo Dunkers? Redneck Parasailing? Paddycake in a G-suit? Did Burton join the Air Force or Phi Kappa Phi? When is the Slip 'N Slide on Quaaludes scheduled? Right after Yager Night in the flight sim? God forbid the Russkies should launch the big one while America's finest are executing flawless "weenie rolls" on the 14th green.

It's like "Jackass, the Movie" with an eighty-billion dollar budget.

I'm just thankful YouTube wasn't around back at Normandy:
"Here's my pal Jason lighting farts on the beach. Yeah, those look like real tracers, but we added 'em in last night with iMovie's new Combat Effects plug-in."

Does Al Quaeda watch this stuff?
"If you see the American Devil paragliding over the motherland, aim at the trailer hitch. But, remember: I have first dibs on his iPod."

Lord help us all.
(Just kiddin' Matt... You're doing great!)

DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Yesterday, Rob and I ran the Niwot Ridge Loop; Rob's preparing for the Pikes Peak Half-Marathon

With the painful reminder of yesterday's pounding 13.3 mile run with Rob through the Indian Peaks still in my legs, I struggled to muster the courage to step out the door today.

It would've been all the easier to say "Screw it!" given that I forgot my jersey and water bottles as well. Perhaps even the claps of thunder or careless foot- and car-traffic should have dissuaded me.

But today was a test, as I see it. At first I resolved to make it up Baseline. Then, I said "Ah, why not Flagstaff House?" Upon reaching that goal, I told myself "Just make it to Crown Rock, then we'll be ahead of the game."

In the end, I rode up to the Amphitheater Road, proud that I didn't quit in the face of adversity.

Metaphorically speaking, when do you guys think one should just turn around? Depends on the situation, I suppose?

As an aside, I forgot that Dave is out of town. So, the long-awaited showdown QB competition didn't happen. Dave has been traded to the Vikings.

title: Fourmile Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
I did Fourmile last week, so I decided to make a last minute change and head for Sunshine. It's noticeably cooler, but it seems more humid. I sweat a lot, anyhow. Probably better than 4% humidity from a health standpoint, though.

So, can anyone picture Favre playing for the Vikings? How much motivation will he have playing GB twice a season?!

title: Jamestown Jig Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Watch how Dennis keeps Greg from joining a Frenzy ride (courtesy of Greg)

Long meetings kept me occupied right up until ride time. Fortunately, Julian, Greg, and Rob were scheming away. Unfortunately, Greg's plans were scuttled when he learned he was being traded to either Tampa Bay or the NYJ. Sorry, Greg.

Temps are definitely more bearable out there, but today the strong easterly winds were something else! Too bad you can't form an echelon on US36 without getting run over.

Hideo, Rob, and I took it easy, like flaccid flowers in a summer breeze. Julian, on the other hand, had a different mindset, which he revealed in his pre-ride invite (excerpted below):

I hear murmurs of recovery ride blah blah blah

These fightin' words remind me of another tall, athletic Frenzy figure who's on vacation at the moment. Does Julian also have a log book with little crossed out stick figures representing riders he's hunted down and slain?

comments.comment_body: I'll have you know that I set off at a very relaxed pace! It wasn't until I was in the canyon that a number of Louisville Cyclery riders threw down the challenge and I started to foam at the mouth. A good ride despite the wind which always seemed to be in my face....go figure. JK
We're just razzin' ya, Julian!  We saw you pedaling easy on the way out 36 while some punk was trying to grab your wheel.  He was working hard...little did he know.

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Kevin called not long before lunch to let me know his 1p meeting was cancelled. He suggested we ride Flagstaff, so I said "Sure!"—we aim to please here at Frenzy HQ.

Kevin was kind to me today, for I had failed to eat this morning, save for a couple cups of coffee and a chocolate-chip muffin with sugar on top...a recipe for bonking if there ever was one!

I managed not to bonk, and Kevin didn't try to talk me into riding Super-Flag either. Just as well, as we both would've gotten our butts kicked by Tyler Hamilton (wearing Rock Racing's old red kit), who cruised by us no problem. Probably one of his easy days.

Bon weekend, all!

title: Recovery Ride with Rob Report
author: Steve
body:
Adriana, Espresso, Baxter, and I hiked up Signal Mountain to see snow from this mid-August snowstorm!

After seeing the giant welt on Rob's leg and hearing about the 20°F temps, I'm thinking this Pikes Peak Ascent might be a rollicking good time.

Greg, Rob, and I spun up to the Amphitheater and tippy-top to take in views of snow-coated peaks today. Impressive snow cover for August, if I do say so myself.

I had the fireplace going on Friday and Saturday nights. I'm ready for cold weather, I think.

comments.comment_body:
Who is this Baxter fellow?

I too am pining for lower temperatures. Here on the Emerald Coast (as the locals call the Gulf Coast) lower temperatures mean anything below 80F at 0600.

title: Orienting New People
author: Steve
body:
In search of a motivational speech...

Today I'm attending and speaking at orientations for new French and Italian TAs, new faculty, and new Spanish and Portuguese TAs, so I won't be able to join you.

I'll bet Dave's rattling his cage over there, though, chomping at the bit to get outside. Leave a comment for him if you're up for a ride.

comments.comment_body:
Hey Frenz,
I'm rattling at the bit and chomping the cage for true. Let me know if you want to get away. I'm leaving at 12:45-ish.
DU

Even though they both love the Dark Lord like a brother*, Noel and DU agreed that a day of biking clear and free of SB's shadow was an unexpected relief.

Noel enjoyed the civilized pace, and found that hanging back w/ DU provided a good introduction to "micromovement," the latest craze to hit cycling.

DU, whose ears still rang from his last outing w/ He Who Shall Not Be Named ("Spin, Donkey Legs, spin!," "You look like a Q-Tip in Spandex!," "Allez, Allez, Allez, Lard Butt!!!"), enjoyed the first intelligent conversation he's had over handlebars in years. Syllables! Content! Purpose!

Breezy on Flag today, but not enough to defeat the rising temps. Looks as if we'll be suffering a good deal more before Fall's welcome arrival.

* The one in the attic that the family refers to as "Bump."

title: Lord Voldemort Returns Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
One of my favorite works of visual design (from Thinking with Type by Ellen Lupton)

I'm back! Prepare yourself for an overabundance of vacuous inanities.

Dave's right (about something for a change): there's a hint of fall in the air! Fourmile canyon had a gentle refreshing breeze, some leaves hinted at turning soon, and the light is slightly different, as Dave observed. Can't wait.

Not much else to report. Dave didn't show any visible signs of disgust with my rambling observations. But, come to think of it, he did have earplugs in; either that or Dick Cheney was feeding him pat responses—a testament to Dave's inability to think or speak for himself.

comments.comment_body:
Actually, Joe Lieberman, who was riding immediately to my right most of the way up the canyon, kept tugging at my jersey and trying to confuse me.

I quit listening to Dick Cheney right after he told me there was a terrorist hiding in that burning paper bag on my front porch.

DU

BTW, the Cheney comment got me thinking...

Remember when the Dickster bagged his first attorney (Sadly, it was during quail season, so it got no mention in the Boone and Crockett record books. The sucker was huge.) and there was loose talk about alcohol consumption and a long wait before calling the authorities?

If you recall, the vice-prez said something about "maybe having a beer under an old oak tree."

Under an old oak tree!

Say what you will about the VP's hygiene, the dude is one smart cookie. Because apparently, when you rig the under an old oak tree suffix to a statement, you can get away with anything.

We invaded the wrong country under an old oak tree.

Mom and Dad, I think I just sniffed glue under an old oak tree..

Little Darryl dressed up like a nun and dismembered his math teacher under an old oak tree. Bless his heart.

I'm just thankful there aren't any old oak trees on Flagstaff.

DU

dave... step away from the printer ink solvent....

RL

title: Get Me Outta Here! Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Greg probably won't ever ride with us again, as neither Dave nor I can form a decent paceline. We look more like folks queuing up for a Dead concert. Sorry, Greg.

comments.comment_body:
Great spinning out east w/ the Frenz today. I was especially fond of our "missing man" paceline. My fault; I kept getting sucked back into the propwash and lord knows it's hard jumping back on a moving train.

In Greg's opinion the water at the swimmin' hole was a tad brisk. Must've been from that snow in the hills last week. It did feel a bit fresher.

DU

title: During Steve's Absence...
author: Dave
body:
Steve foolishly left me the keys to the Frenzy website. How nutty can you get, eh? In any case, I'm gonna' just let it go on autopilot. I figure we can simply rubber stamp this week's schedule until Grizzly Adams returns. Here's what he had:

Monday
Flagstaff/SuperFlag
Telecom
Tuesday
4Mile
Humanities north side
Wednesday
Neva Loop
Stadium, Gate 5
Thursday
NCAR Hill
Telecom
Friday
Gregory Canyon Bridge

All at noon. I guess the meeting places all are that really matter. If we vary from the routes, who'll know, right?

title: Poorman Ride Report
author: Kevin
body:
Steve's handed me the keys to the site. Let's hope I don't drive it off a cliff

Greg, Rob and I had a nice ride up Poorman today. Matt would have come along but a foot issue relegated him to the pool. The sun hid behind the clouds for most of the ride, so it was a little cool at times. The scenery was great, though, as all the rain has made everything lush and green in the canyons. And aside from a few washboardy sections, Poorman Road was in good shape.

comments.comment_body:
That's just what I was thinking!!! See you there...
RL

My toe is letting me know that I should stay off of it today; at least until I see the doctor this afternoon.

Enjoy Poorman Loop! I will be doing laps in the pool unfortunately.

Think I found the workout that'll get me through the next 3 months. Bike to Settler's Park, then run the Anemone pipecut up to what I've always called Poorman Hill. Then walk back down to the bike.
It's a relatively safe bike ride to Settler's and the pipe cut is super steep... easy on the knees and very aeobic. It's hell being an arthritic bleeder. All I need now is one more malady to make it really challenging... Sheesh.
If someone wants to join me sometime, Poorman Hill is really nice.
DU

Hey, Boys!

We arrived today in one piece after blitzing the whole route in one go (no stops). The weather was so severe in KS that we didn't want to camp or even find a motel, so we did the smart thing and tried to outrun the storm.

Keep sweatin'!

PS: I had looked for that SNL clip before...nice work finding it, Kev. You're hired!

title: Flagstaff Ride Reports
author: Dave
body:
Since SB is running on about four hours sleep - that's for the last three days - I'm
tossing in some white noise of my own.

Flagstaff was primo yesterday and today. Plastered snow and thick fog yesterday,
with a little snowpack on the wall. Today the road was pristine; the Boulder County
Highway guys had cleared things beautifully and the sun had dried out the last of
the moisture. The ride was about as pretty as it gets.

Greg went his own way, headed for a Chautauqua duathlon. I'm sure he had a good
outing... hard to go wrong with weather like this!

DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Kind of a sad day today: the last before the students return to campus en masse and biking around becomes infinitely more dangerous.

Still, it was a nice one. It's warm out, but there's still a hint of Greeley in the air, which is to say a smell vaguely resembling Kevin's biking gloves and which is to say the wind is blowing from the north and that Kevin's gloves need to be washed thoroughly.

Anyhow, good luck to all who are dealing with the return of the kids. Have a great weekend!

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Thanks to Dave for getting me out of the office for an hour! It's too hot. Someone turn down the thermostat and dial up fall, please.

title: Sunshine Canyon Poorman Loop Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Just saw Jeff Spicoli in the class next door. Is it me or did the pizza guy forget the sausage on Spicoli's pie?

Excellent crew out there today: Rob, Dave, and Greg.

Greg showed up despite his frustration with our inability to form a paceline a few days ago. Way to forgive and forget, Stauffer!

We weren't sure about the surface of Poorman Road, but upon closer inspection, we discovered it has recently been watered, keeping the 3-inch deep moondust at bay. Great ride, fellas!

Now we'll see if I get to eat before 5pm today. Maybe I should take a cue from Spicoli....

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Like Steve Martin's character in the movie Roxanne, I knew something was wrong with the air as soon as I stepped outside this morning. And, as it so happens, my nose didn't deceive me .

Just now, Noel sent me this note from the Emergency Manager at Environmental Health and Safety:

[T]he smoke may cause minor lung and/or eye irritation, and may be a nuisance for individuals with existing medical conditions such as asthma. To minimize the effects of the smoke, keep windows and doors shut and remain indoors when possible.

Ignoring common sense and basic health practices, Dave, Noel, and I strode up Flagstaff like a couple of cocksure peacocks (consonance).

My throat was really dry the whole way, so I took several pulls off my water bottle. But, Dave says that this is a character-building day ("It's actually good for you," he opined); of course, Dave isn't known for his sense of self-preservation....or his good character.

Dave's bike broke down once more, so Rob has found him a manly new one on Craigslist.

title: Labor Day Vacation Reports
author: Steve
body:
Our Labor Day Trip to the Bighorn Range, Wyoming

Send me your vacation report!

Dave's Report

Anyone know these guys?

Why, it's the Masons, Darryl, Dusty, and Buck, three generations of Saguache County game wardens. There's a little stone and plexiglass shrine to them at the entrance to the Mason Family State Wildlife Area on Cebolla Creek, our favorite place to lose the crowds on Labor Day. In fact, it was all ours this weekend, and except for the odd bits of so-called music escaping from the Fender Palomino and the patter of rain on the roof, the place was surreally quiet. No campers, no ATV's, no yuppies in Orvis waders, no Texans in RV's with 80-megawatt generators, no nada.

It's great knowing we can still find places to be alone in Colorado, even on holiday weekends. Frenz tell Frenz about treasures like this, knowing they'll be discreet.

title: Sunshine Canyon Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Here's Dave's report:

Like fair wingéd Mercury, Steve Bailey chased
My vanishing shadow up Mapleton Place.
"Toward Sunshine!" he cried, "Underwood's there!"
"I'll render him pulp as the fox does the hare!"

Through turn after turn he tore like a fright.
His lungs burned, his legs jelled, but no geezer in sight.
For I, like the fox, chose Flagstaff instead,
And let foolish young Bailey just race in his head.

Like Amy Winehouse says, you know I'm no good. I am indeed no good, as I stood Dave up.

Sorry, bud, but the only thing chasing you was your Walter Mitty imagination.

comments.comment_body:
"Hello, this is Frenzy Headquarters. How may we help you?"

"Yes, I'm calling about your ad: Learn to Trash Talk While You Sleep. I'd like to order the tapes."

"You're talking about the tapes produced by our CEO and spiritual kingpin Steve Bailey?"

"That sounds right... The ones that promise to turn you into a shard-spitting monster in just two weeks."

"Great. We can have those shipped to you by the end of the month."

"Oh jeez, I can't wait that long! I'm getting beat up something fierce out here. I need those tapes yesterday!"

"You sound like a motivated buyer. We could overnight them, but it's pricey."

"Money's no object; I'm flush, believe me. I just need to get armed and soon. I can't even defend myself against a senior citizen at this point. I want an acid tongue and a styrofoam conscience like Mr. Bailey. His stuff makes your brain pucker."

"Okay fine, we'll get the order started for you right away in that case. Can I have your name, please?"

"I'll spell it for you; it's kind of unusual. B-A-R-R-A-C-K O-B-A..."

DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report from Dave
author: Steve
body:
Dave's new Flagstaff pal, Jean-Yves Blondeau

The cloak of fog seemed to encourage the criminal element on Flag today... Saw a guy wedeling down the road on a skateboard wearing a full-coverage motorcycle helmet and a smoking sole.

And a bunch of high school kids hotboxing in a BMW just below the Boatramp. They must've cracked the windows a hair to lean up the mixture, because I could smell the reefer from two switchbacks down. Their little secret.

Great ride; cold, foggy, and wet. Bailey weather. -DU

comments.comment_body:
Now that the press is going through every sock drawer in Wasilla, I've come to the rather sad conclusion that, thanks to the Frenzy, I'll never hold an elected office:

Wolf Blitzer: "It's said you once referred to a blogmate as a wheeled carp with the personality of a trivet. Any truth?"

Me: "Well, maybe... but when you take it out of context like that... What I meant to say was..."

Wolf Blitzer: "You claim to have ridden from CU's student center to the top of Flagstaff Mountain in just over seven minutes. Is that entirely accurate?"

Me: "I rounded off."

Wolf Blitzer: "Did you really ride a bicycle while wearing a kilt?"

Me: "That's absurd! I can't believe my opponent is spreading such..."

Wolf Blitzer: "We have pictures."

Me: "Oh... Well look, if Rudy Giuliani can go to the 104 St. Gym in toreador pants and a very nice peasant top, why is it so bad for me to do a little drag racing of my own, so to speak?"

Wolf Blitzer: "How do you rate you chances in November?"

Me: "Ummm..."

DU

title: Bike Path Spin Flagstaff Assault
author: Steve
body:
Dave and I must have crossed our wires today. I missed chaperoning him to Flatirons Hospital. Let's wish him well, as he finds out if it is indeed a ruptured disk.

Shortly after you wish him well, it's okay to make fun of him. So here goes.

The reason I missed him was that he gave me the usual Monday morning phone call that runs something like this:

DU: Rush had some really salient points this morning...
SB: [Puts down phone. Gets up to make coffee. 5 minutes pass.]
DU: ...Anyway, that's what G. Gordon Liddy thinks. You there?
SB: Thanks, Dave. Gotta run.

Somewhere in that exchange, I missed that Dave might be running late and we should postpone until a few minutes after 12pm. Oh well.

Good day out there just the same. Saw a deer and redd foxx...oops, I mean a red fox. Today was the first day I got to wear my Smartwool beanie too. Needed it!

I walked out of my office, having just looked at the webcam (since I don't have any windows down in HQ). Darn thing was stuck on an image from yesterday—I missed the Important Notice warning!

Imagine my surprise when the promised sunny skies turned out to be fog and drizzle. The temp at the Mesa Lab was 44°F, which when combined with wet conditions means soup weather.

I'm just now getting the feeling back in my shins. Shouldn't have done the shorts today!

comments.comment_body:
This truly sucks... not only did I have to spend an hour in a cramped plastic tube getting bombarded by billions of sub-atomic mind-control particles (I, of course, was unaffected... no place for them to burrow in), but I also missed the season's premier of Bailey in his Smartwool (?!!) beanie. Bummer.

I had a good ride before the "procedure," though. Great weather, at long last.

DU

title: Bait and Switch Celebratory Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Rob and I had every intention of riding up Sunshine, but then, of a sudden, we chose Flagstaff instead. So far this week, I'm two-for-two.

Today was warmer than yesterday, but it was still quite humid. Rob and I were both put off by the brown cloud, which came into view as we rose above it. Probably not good for our lungs!

comments.comment_body:
hmmm... could it be the frenzy is running slowly today?

or is it the shiny new ".org" attached to the name????

RL

I noticed right away that there is a box dedicated to "Recent Comments," and that a certain "DU" is an insufferable, long-winded hack. But that's about all.

DU

Nice! The Frenzy is finally "official" with a redirector waving folks over from the .
from .blogspot address to its very own url and Bailey must have installed a copy of the blogger free... no, wait... wordpress is the new backend!  How much custom code did ya need? But here on Mac Firefox, lines start to disappear from the right side of the comment box, instead of automatically wrapping, curious. In any case, it looks great, very well done, and maybe if there's comment field issues, trash talking won't be as easy as the pie it usually appears to be.

Ooh, the subtle diagonal line pinstriping just sunk in for me. 

Just one of many improved, but not gaudy, features of the new design.

How astute, all! But Gunther gets top prize. Indeed, last night (until 3:30a), I moved my recently purchased "flagstafffrenzy.org" domain into my DreamHost webhosting. Then, I installed WordPress and Gallery2, which no one noticed...the gallery is coming back! Then, I imported all 575 posts and 300 or so comments, as well as all associated media, into WordPress. Then, I had lots of tweaking to do with the design and I just barely got to some custom-scripting before I realized it would be a good idea to sleep. This comment box is annoying, eh, Gunther?! This is just the tip of the iceberg. I have big plans for us. In an excellent A List Apart article, Cameron Moll eschews the value of "realigning" sites instead of just "redesigning" them. That said, there will soon be lots of new functionality that I think y'all will like, plus a new design to accommodate my sprawling and unchecked ambitions. Meantime, thanks for playing! And stay tuned. Now that I'm done with the Buff Bike Classic, I can tend to such important things, or as Adriana would say, waste time on such things
Comment box issue should now be fixed. It was the darn <textarea> tag!

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride Report (and Gravatars Tip)
author: Steve
body:
Dave and I got another taste of fall today while we were climbing up Fourmile Canyon. A touch of yellow in the trees and the slightly lower angle of the sun, not to mention the cooler temperatures. Good time!

You may have noticed that Frenzy comments now include avatars. To get yours showing up, sign up for a free Gravatar account, make sure the email you use to create the account is the same as the one you use to leave your comment, then leave a comment. Simple as that.

Note: Unfortunately, your new avatar will not be retroactively applied to old comments, as they are not affiliated with your email address.

comments.comment_body:
Could someone bring along a bunch of bungee cords? I may need a tow up Poorman.

See ya' at noon:15,

DU

Hey, did Dennis really insinuate that he'll be joining the Frenzy rides once he's retired or was it my imagination? And Dennis better come out of retirement, bike racing retirement that is, since he's got that hella dope bike now.

Hey guys:

new site looks cool... and i'm sorry i missed the ride today!  see you tomorrow?

RL

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Big crew out there today. Dave, Greg, Rob, and I were all present and accounted for, climbing Flagstaff's ramparts under bluebird skies and warm temps. Greg and Dave enjoyed some drive-by plum picking even! A Frenzy first for sure.

Frenzy Cleanup Part Deux!

Don't forget, tomorrow is the second installment of our Sunshine Canyon Drive cleanup. Gather at Bald Mountain Parking Lot at 8am or at Southside Walnut Cafe at 7am. Hope you can make it and don't forget your work gloves!

comments.comment_body: Saraheit 451 You have to admit it: had Sarah Palin been successful in her attempt to purge the Wasilla Public Library of everything save the Bible and Cabella's 2008 Master Catalog, browsing the stacks would have been much easier. And if she prevails in November, look for other adventures in streamlining: Washington, April 22, 2009 (AP) Just days after John McCain's accidental choking death in a White House mop closet, newly-minted President Sarah Palin has announced sweeping changes to the federal government. The Departments of Energy, State, Defense, and Justice have been merged into one new office, The Department of Public Works.
