"It worked really well in Wasilla," said the former Miss Mukluk as she signed the executive order directing the massive changes. "You could get anything you needed by simply dialing one number. We even mailed out those little magnetic do-hickeys you can put on your fridge!" Palin has pegged political unknown Cole Bledsoe to head the new organization. Bledsoe, who hails from Moosepellet Alaska and has a PhD. in Hillbilly Science from Bob Jones University, spoke with the press about the challenges of filling leadership roles in the new mega-agency, saying "It's hard enough finding one decent horseman in Alaska, not to mention four." President Palin, who will be hunting and camping somewhere on the White House grounds over the weekend, has scheduled a press conference for Monday morning in the executive skinning room. Gad. DU

title: Northwest Passage Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dave and I felt as though we were frogs on the road today!

Great minds don't think, as they say!

Indeed, today Dave and I followed our misguided hearts, which called us to the Northwest Passage. Like a Shackleton voyage, our journey was filled with hazards and objective dangers, but we survived with teamwork and determination.

Well, actually, it was just some basic bikehandling skills. Still, great to dust that ride off the shelves. Thanks, Davey!

comments.comment_body:
Steve-O, you're a mind reader. I was just looking at NW passage while walking up the hill this morning and thinking we're way overdue.
Great call!

DU

Never seen so many people trying to kill us in one ride. Did someone put a contract out on us? 

Nice try, whoever you are, but you hired a bunch of nincompoops. 

DU

title: Big Game Ride
author: Steve
body:
If you missed SNL this past weekend, you missed a great Sarah Palin impersonation

No, we're not hunting big game. There IS a big game between CU and West Virginia.

If you're interested in cruising around the bike paths either around noon or after 2pm, let us know by leaving a comment.

comments.comment_body: I'm up for something.  I have my road bike here for the first time this month and I'd like to actually ride it somewhere.

title: Criminal Mischief Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Kimberly found this ergonomic keyboard for pirates; it is International Talk Like a Pirate Day after all

While I couldn't make the Pirate festival over in the Stadium today, I did block off time to ride. I had to block off time, in fact, because Friday is "All Faculty Call Steve Day" (unofficially, of course).

With Dave's help, I slipped out the side door, disguised as a janitor. Then, we hopped on our steeds and rode off into the sunset. Good ride. Still comfortable temps; no sun; and good company!

comments.comment_body: Arr. Weigh anchor and hoist the mizzen!

title: Trail Ridge Road Ride
author: Steve
body:
Thanks for suggesting this unforgettable ride, Matt! (gallery)

We didn't sit around this weekend! Au contraire! We rode up the highest continuously paved road in the US-of-A!

title: Eldorado Mountain Run Report
author: Steve
body:
Not sure you'd classify what we did as running, but... (gallery)

I joined Brian Kent on a shin-shredding run up the un-trailed Eldorado Mountain. In case the bushwhacking wasn't enough of a challenge, a miscalculation dropped us on the wrong side of a train tunnel, which we had to run through Standy-By-Me style. Thanks, Brian!

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Adriana put the new Townie through its paces today

Adriana wanted to see if her Electra Townie Cruiser would enable her—bad back and all—to climb Flagstaff. It did!

title: Magnolia Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
I've been finding myself pining for cooler temps, like those found back home

With Dave out due to an MRI that looks like the Isthmus of Ipswich, I had to fly solo today. What better way to celebrate the freedom of the road than with a little cruise up Magnolia Road?

Ouch! That hurt. Some of the driveways up there are quite literally on the brink! I found myself constantly on the brink too...on the brink of a bonk, that is.

comments.comment_body:
Anyone interested in planning a Fox/Hound game in the near future? Doesn't have to be this week, but sometime.

(and I'm out Oct 8-14, so you'd better not plan something then, damn it).

It was one of those dreams: the kind that flickered to life as soon as his head hit the pillow. It was vivid and bright and achingly familiar. Phyllis Schlafly had just hung out the "Do Not Disturb" sign and was putting little umbrellas in the Mai Tais when the phone rang. It was Carruthers, the intern. "Mr. President, I hate to disturb your nap, but I knew you would want to know..." "Know what?!! It's not that sniveler Paulson whining about the banks again, I hope." "No sir, it's..." "McCain? I've already promised him I'd lay low 'til the election. What's he after now, blood?" "No sir, it..." "Dick bag another scheister?" "No sir. This is much more important. The gallery is back up on the Frenzy, sir. It seems Steve Bail..." "Hot damn!" cried the Decider as he snapped upright from the couch. "This is great news, Carruthers! Get in here and turn my computer on for me, will you?" "Right away sir! Shall I bring you an Ovaltine to celebrate?" "Hell, yes! And cancel the reception for Gordon Brown tonight... I've got some catchin' up to do!" DU

title: Back Alley Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Hinault is described as being in a machine-like, detached state in this video; so was Dave an hour ago

Fantastic day out there today! The skies are crisp with nary a cloud. The air clean.

Still, climbing up Back Alley is never a cakewalk. The unrelenting grades are said to have buckled the tree-like legs of Hulk Hogan, leaving him curled in the fetal position and asking for his pink blanket.

But the Frenz are badgers. Dave, Greg, and I tackled dirt and pavement alike with aplomb, intoxicated as it were with the poetry of suffering. Or something like that.

title: Flagstaff Sprint Report
author: Steve
body:
My darling wife just had the above video published in the NYT Science section

Man, this is like summertime! I made it to Crown Rock before having to turn around, which is great. Good little ride, and enough time to do the sink bird-bath, wolf down a salad, and go teach a 2hr class.

I've been itching for "Initiation" lately. Anyone? That means, Greg, of course!

title: Gimme Some Sugar-Loaf Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Betasso Preserve, a nice ride with views.

It's distinctly cooler out there. Mesa Lab is reading 60F. There's also the typical swirling headwind in Boulder Canyon, which made pedaling down nearly as much of a workout as pedaling up.

Still, these are the conditions I like.

Hit Betasso Preserve today, turning around at the water treatment plant. Fun ride. Always impressive to see either Magnolia or Sugarloaf from one or the other side.

Missive from Matt

Greetings!

Welcome to the big leagues -- Joint Primary Pilot Training!

Once again we find our hero -- okay, maybe that is took strong a word -- in the little hamlet of Milton, Florida just outside of sunny Pensacola, Florida. I am now in formal pilot training at NAS Whiting Field. Everything I did before was akin to the minor leagues leading up to this. From here on out every grade on every test, briefing, and maneuver counts towards which plane I will fly in the future.

Yesterday I had my first flight in the T-34. The experience was quite a rush; it was much different (read: faster and more maneuverable) than anything I had flown before. The first two-hour sortie passed by quickly and I can't wait to get in the air again. I love the smell of jet fuel in the morning!

Check out these YouTube videos to get a (humorous) look at flying the T-34 out of NAS Whiting Field. No, I'm not in them -- I don't have the time or the inclination to get permission to haul a camera up with me at the moment. Rest assured I will try to get some in-flight action shots before too long.

"Navy Flight School"
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bx3Vjkqz9V8
"Making a Pilot, Vol. 1"
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1iwSuWb2gMg

I wish I could be a bit more verbose in my description of pilot training but the ability to write escapes me at the moment. My buddies and are off to celebrate my return to the skies!

title: Flagstaff Climb Report
author: Steve
body:
The colors are getting there, but not quite...

Dave, Rob, and I took advantage of the lovely weather to spin up Flagstaff. It was warmer than yesterday, so the vest I toted up wasn't really necessary.

For the second time in as many weeks, I've found myself staring off at Inititation, wondering when the weather will be cool enough to seek out its zigzagging ramparts. Whoever said it would snow by the end of September, should be thankful we didn't place real bets.

Speaking of which, I just read the Winter Park Weather Forecast for next week, as I often do, and I liked what I saw:

The overall pattern is still expected to become more fall-like in early October, with larger storms ginning up in the Gulf of Alaska, affecting the Northwest US first, then gradually moving into Colorado with possible snow. This weekend into the following week (3rd onward), our unsettled weather pattern may deliver a strong early-season low pressure system with possibly significant snow in all resort areas (but mainly northern resorts, along and north of the I-70, including Aspen, Vail, Winter Park).

Will it snow in early October here?

In other news, Matt's email updates are distinctly different from his Facebook page, as evidenced by the photo below:


Matt's rigorous Air Force training includes "How to take hostages"

comments.comment_body: I'm beginning to wonder if Matt really went to the Air Force. I suspect he might have started a farm in western Colorado instead. That might explain the photo above. Perhaps those pictures we've seen before of airplanes are really from crop dusting school. Hmmm...

Can you imagine waking up to this? A woozy night in the Officer's Club. Elbows still sticky with rum and head throbbing from the Pensicuda's asthmatic 80 watt P.A. system, he must've felt like death. And then to scrape down the hallway from the bathroom, certain the very earth was cracking under the worst hangover ever conceived, he sees this thing, sprawled over the dinette in a drying pool of RC Cola and cracker crumbs. It turns, looks him in the eye, and says, "Hi, I'm Matt. Can I go home now?" DU

title: Fourmile Canyon Super-Sugarloaf Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Apart from the now outlawed Criminal Intent, this is the most epic Frenzy lunch ride by far!

So, Dave tells me: Let's do an epic ride tomorrow. Always the willing accomplice, I mentioned a ride I've had my eyes on for a while, namely Logan Mill to Arkansas Mountain. Today, I christened it!

It'd be nearly impossible to give someone directions on this route, as there are so many potential wrong turns. I had looked at a Google Map before, but today I had to rely more on the Force than anything else.

Apparently, the Force is strong within me.

Indeed, I had to ignore road signs like Street Closed and Rough Road in order to stay on course. The driver of the white van that passed me near the top of Arkansas Mountain looked truly stunned as I rode by.

Still, this is not much different from Poorman or Northwest Passage, with the exception of its length, 20.5 miles, and of course keeping in mind that much of that distance is loose dirt at an incline of 15% and above.

The beauty of the ride, aside from the sudden views that come out of nowhere, is that each of the steeps is accompanied by a "recovery roost," where you have ample time to prepare for the next climb and admire Fourmile Canyon far below.

Arkansas Mountain Road is a tricky descent, as it's been recently graded and suddenly turns into beach sand. I almost bought the farm once, but it's doable. Took 1.5hrs.

So, if you're up for this adventure sometime soon, vote in today's poll!

comments.comment_body: Yah, but, can you do it on a townie?

Hmm...The Townie would struggle in the small ravines that run down the middle of the road on the 15% uphill sections; however, it would be much safer for the descent of Arkansas Mountain Road's volleyball sand!

Sounds like a fun ride, Wild Man. 
Now let's try it after a good snow, eh?

DU

title: Fourmile Flagstaff Bailout Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
With storm clouds gathering, Dave and I decided to forgo the planned bailout ride and really bailout by riding Flagstaff. Good choice.

Today was much like a day in winter, in that there was the feeling of a front moving through, which seems to be less frequent or noteworthy in the other three season. It was a nice prelude for things to come.

title: Friday Flip-Flop
author: Steve
body:
Yep, I was for a lunchtime ride today before I was against it. But, the fact remains, I can't ride at lunch. Leave a comment if you're coördinating something.

Meantime, have a great weekend.

comments.comment_body:
Anyone up for a jaunt up the hill?
Give me a buzz; 2-2672.

DU

I will never be up for a ride that goes over a bridge that goes nowhere or on a road that leads to nowhere. Unless of course DU is the guide, then and only then, it probably has an importance.

Dennis

A Discovery Channel addict, I remember watching what seemed very much an ad—not a Discovery Channel program—about this Bering Strait Bridge and thinking to myself: Why? I honestly wonder who was behind the program (Discovery contracts with production companies). Likewise, I question the true motives behind the bridge, especially considering its greenwashed name The Intercontinental Peace Bridge. Wouldn't oil barons like a pipeline to Kazakhstan, with its stores of oil that rival those of the Middle East?! The Kazakhs just built a pipeline to China, after all. Reactionary, you say? Well, try poking around the internets a bit and get back to me. Or just watch minute 4:20-4:45 of the Discovery video. What's this have to do with cycling, you ask? What's the capital of Kazakhstan, I retort?!

title: West Magnolia Bachelor Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Rob, Eric, Kevin, and I carved some turns without powder today!

Rob's my kind of guy: doing a bike ride for the bachelor party!

comments.comment_body:
Hey Steve:

looks great!!!  Thanks so much for capturing the beauty of the season!

RL

Rob,

My pleasure.  Next time: helmet cam!  Have a great wedding and celebration.

Amazing fall colors, gentlemen!  I would gladly trade a month of wonderful Florida Fall weather for a nice Indian Summer day on the trail in Colorado. The recent temperature drop here from "hellish" to "bearable" has made riding much more attractive in the past couple of weeks.  It's still does not compare in any way, shape, or form to the riding back home in Colorado.

I truly miss the regular "humblings" I received on both trail and asphalt from the more seasoned Frenz.

Great video chops, Steve-O!

I am truly grateful, though, that you were nowhere near my bachelor party. It was somewhat different from this. 

Hey to Matt, also. I like "seasoned."  

DU
Wow, y'alls were up in my neck of the woods.  Great video although I would have liked to see a little more air on some of those jumps.  Congratulations Rob!  :)

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dang it, guys! My faculty appointment went past 12p. Sorry. I'll have to spin after work or take the pooches for a good trail run.

Note: You can now subscribe to Frenzy posts by email or by RSS, and you can subscribe to Frenzy comments by email or by RSS.

comments.comment_body:
Too bad about SB getting caught up in the office today. He missed a perfect fall ride.  

Rob and I shared the mountain; he took the dirt, I took the pavement. We both had a great time separately together.

DU

title: San Francisco Bike Tour
author: Steve
body:
A little flavor of the city that Rice-a-Roni built

After a 4:30am red eye flight, I arrived in San Fran with plenty of time to kill. Luckily, my hotel agreed to hold onto some of my stuff. I was more mobile for it.

To stay awake, I just started walking north, which is quite a workout given all the hills here. Before dawn, I passed Lombard Street, crookedest street in the U.S., and several other landmarks. No one was about, so I had the town to myself.

After some time, I found a breakfast joint (Home Plate), where I grabbed coffee and a bite. From there, I wandered around looking for the bike rental place, whose whereabouts I vaguely remembered from looking at GMaps—yes, Sean, an iPhone would've saved me some meandering (still, I found my way by actually talking to people...imagine that?!).

After renting a bike, I headed through The Presidio, across the bridge, and toward the Marin Headlands. Somehow I ended up on a hiking-only trail, but the NPS trail workers who spotted me were tremendously nice and pointed me toward the actual biking trails.

From there I passed through Sausalito, a wealthy town with a houseboat community (and snobby bike shop). After several more rollers and onshore breezes, I ended up in my destination, Tiburon. From Tib, I took the ferry back to town, jumped a streetcar, and arrived at my conference hotel in time for orientation. Great day!

As a funny aside, I was a little worried that, given the constraints of trying to pack two small carry-on bags with clothes for 13,000 feet, the beach, and a "with-it" town, I would arrive at the conference somewhat of a rag-tag clown.

Ah, but these are the Arts and Humanities, and judging from the sartorial choices of my conference peers, I fit right in. I even ironed my shirts!

As another aside, while at the Mauna Loa Observatory, I bumped into a Google engineer who, like me, was riding his wife's coattails at 13,000 feet in Hawaii. It just so happens that he's working on a beta project called Knol aimed at higher education. We're officially invited to test drive it and provide feedback. Serendipitous, eh?!

See y'all soon! Go Sox!!

comments.comment_body:
Wow! Judging from the feature story on the CU homepage, looks like Adriana has been hard at work since returning to Boulder.

CIRES has its own chronicles of the research project too. Ah, YouTube seems to have compressed my video. I'll bet it was out of Gunther's hands...just a hunch!
Did you have that camera in your helmet?

Hi, JCL(?).

Actually, I only had one hand on the handlebars for all those shots.  

I thought about putting up the warning "Do not try this at home," but I figured most of my gentle readers already regard Frenzy activities and tales with that caveat in mind.  Thanks for commenting!

Thanks for sharing the video Steve! I'm glad the souvenir shops in SF still sell these tapes. In fact, I think I used to own this exact one. It's nice, but Number 314 in the series, Hurdling the Homeless is still my favorite. Some really good footage of jumping over the streetsleepers on lower Polk Street. I'm still not sure how they filmed it; they clear some really BIG guys! Other than the trip down to Hal's Kurio Korner, did you get out of the room much? I mean other than to the "conference?" Hope everything went well and that Mastercard still XXXXXXX's out that one line on the receipts. I had a problem with that once, but then I'm a designer, so it was fixable. Let me know if you need help. We miss you. Tim told me to say that. DU

Heya Steve,

Had a wrassle with the lovely video, but was unsuccessful in wrapping it in a nice .flv format. If you can believe it, what you saw was YouTube's interpretation of your lovely .flv. Anyway I keep talking with Mz. Bailey about how Mike (our web developer) and I would love your help developing a more permanent video solution. YouTube was a last resort. 

Hope you're recovering from any jet lag and enjoying the town, human condition that Dave refers to and all. Glad your rags worked ;)

As if your trip to Hawaii wasn't enough. You had to hit S.F. too! Very jealous. BTW, Camille and I did the same ride you did but on a tandem. I think it's Camille's favorite ride of all time and probably mine too.

title: Happy Birthday, Kevin!  Flag Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Steve with camcorder in hand and lava flows behind

Thanks to Dave and Greg for joining me on my altitude re-entry ride. Perfect conditions out there, though chilly on the descent. Looking forward to the rest of fall!

Happy Birthday, Kevin

A little rappin' gift for K-No

It's Kevin's birthday today, so be sure to speak up when you see him. The hearing aid is on order.

comments.comment_body: Insensitive doesn't feel quite right. Not enough bite. While my fingers thrum away at the desktop and I search for a more appropriate word, let's examine the facts. SB has flown over 300,000 miles in just the past six months. While we worker ants have dug ever deeper into the parched sands of the University, our hairfine legs wobbling under burdens twice our size, Herr Bailey has visited Hawaii, Latvia, San Francisco, Washington (all three of them), St Tropez, Tahiti, St. Petersburg, Bermuda, Moscow, Old and New Belgium, London, Paris, Miami, Gandwanaland (still the same old place), Saigon, and the far-flung Isles of Langerhans. That's the short list. Oh, how we "love" looking up through sweat-rimmed lids to see yet another of SB's travelogues. Nothing quite like seeing the free flight of the butterfly from the dank confines of the diving bell. Guys in the joint know the feeling; a postcard from Curly (Cell 23, the A-bunk, 16 years) from someplace with lots of sun and, just around the corner, two-for-one specials on well drinks every afternoon. Curly's new friend Lola says hi. But this is video, for gosh sake! Narrator: We liked this spa a lot because, as you can see, Mt. Pukliaki is just visible over the roof of the swim-up bar. And you can almost smell the mint wrap in this scene, can't you? Voice in background: More ice please! And could you let the guy in the Hummer know we'd like the tire pressure lowered a few pounds for the drive up to the waterfall? We detest a rough ride. It's not as if we don't travel. Last summer there was the trip back to Uncle Gaylan's place in Indiana. What a thrill! Re-brazing a hog trough in the mid-day heat... boy, there's a memory no one can ever steal. And I'll never forget playing deviled egg roulette (Is this the one that they forgot to refrigerate?) in my cousin's double-wide in Garden City. Torrents of fun, true... but is this something you want to see posted on the Frenzy in living color? That's what I thought. We shouldn't complain; we have a good job and a warm seat near a window... Picture Uriah Heep with a Mac, though not nearly as healthy. And next summer, if the Tercel doesn't throw a rod or something, we may get to go see Mom's cousin Sadie in Amarillo. There's a nice HoJo's on the way, and her hide-a-bed is real cush. Now what is that word? DU
Ah... But as my good pal Dave well knows, life is richer for the stories we spin, regardless of whence we spin them.

title: Sunshine Ride Bailout Report
author: Steve
body:
Dave couldn't make it; Rob's on his honeymoon; and others are tied up. Given this and the impending cold front, I thought it best to wait until I get home to run with my dogs. Tomorrow might be a good day for a duathlon or duel.

Dave says it snowed on the 13th, which means two folks were winners in this year's first snowfall poll. Congrats!

Beware: Screed Below!

In other random news, why don't baseball relief pitchers have to make a quick transition into the game? I think those switches should be more like hockey substitutions...no darn warm-up pitches! Just run out there (don't walk!) and throw.

comments.comment_body:
I saw the first snow on campus last Monday (10/13). It was gone by 10AM, but there was plenty on Flag at noon. 
Hoping to see more tonight!

DU

I'm not sure we can believe someone like "DU" (if that is, indeed, your real name).

"It snowed! I was right! I'm the master-predictor! ... Oh you want to verify that claim? It... uh... it was totally gone by the time anyone saw it."

Good try, but no dice.

I must remind iSean that there is precedent. On the very day the somewhat damning Branchflower report was scheduled to hit the bricks in Anchorage, Sarah Palin released a report of her own. The result? "Palin Clears Self." (I first tried this same approach at age five with a broken vase and an errant Super Ball. Sadly, I hadn't yet fully developed my chops.) So you see, iSean, it can be done. And while I celebrate truth as much as the next guy, I fully realize it has its limits. Thankfully, the Frenzy provides safe refuge for "reality inventors" like myself, a virtual redoubt, if you will, for those of us who know the road to Truth is straight, flat, colorless, and mind-numbingly dull. Sort of a highway to nowhere (wink). DU

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
When your biking and trash-talk pal is a graphic designer, you should always beware!

Wonderful riding conditions these days. There's a nice, crispy contrast between the mountains and the sky. Likewise, there's a nice crispness to the air that dries jerseys in seconds at the pinnacle of the climb.

Adriana finally figured out that the Tsunami signs in the video above aren't telling you to run towards the tidal wave but rather that you're entering a Tsunami danger zone. Not very intuitive if you ask me.

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
More of Paul Frederick's fantastic work.

Warmer today—stuck with shorts and short-sleeves for the ascent, adding a vest, wool beanie, and arm warmers only for the descent. The breeze has again cleared skies of haze and added a little refreshment to the climb, especially in the corners. Have a great weekend!

The above video reminds me of the sugar maples in Sugar Hill, New Hampshire. This video was shot in Rumney, NH near where my dad teaches computer science courses, Plymouth State University.

I don't see the Frenzy on Comscore's recent domain rankings for September—but WordPress is #33. The Frenzy only had 120 unique visits in September. Good news is that only 9% of our total hits were from folks using Internet Explorer.

comments.comment_body: I'm in a meeting until noon. I'll be going out for a ride after that. -G
Does the hit count include the RSS feed?
Matt, we get about 9 requests/day for the FF feed according to Feedburner.  I noticed about 7 hits on the website from Florida last month.  Wonder who that is?!  How's things?

title: Poorman Loop Ride Report
author: Steve
body: This weather has been splendid of late! Dave and I took advantage with a quick spin up the smooth, tacky dirt on Poorman Road. Still vest and arm warmer conditions.

title: Linden Loop Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
The Gammonizer suggested this one. I liked this one too.

Glancing at the forecast, I'm afraid I'm going to run out of superlatives for the clement weather by Thursday. Suggestions?

Anyhow, Rob and Dave joined me for a wonderful stroll up Linden Drive. Lots of steady climbing, followed by steep descending.

Rumor has it a certain man of classical tastes might tag along tomorrow. Dave's advice to us: Take him on something hard. Will do, my friend. Shout out to the Gunthernator from us.

comments.comment_body: A Comedy of Ayers Steve's right; we'll have to ration our superlatives if want them to last the week. Even then, we may have to raid other languages. If the weather holds, if the humidity stays low, and if the backlit leaves shimmer and vibrate like speckled trout in fast-moving water, we can use the German Verflertaugensteigen for Thursday. I'm worried about Friday. In any case, Linden Loop was a super ride. Thanks, Rob and Steve. And speaking of super... Super Tuesday is only a week away, and you can really smell the desperation coming from the McCain/Palin camp. Smells like... defeat. Look for Gollum and Daisy Mae to really crank up the heat on their Obama-left-the-seat-up-again campaign until this whole wretched thing finally pulls up to the curb and shuts off the motor. But now the mud simply won't stick. I think the American people are finally done with this stuff. Mind you, I don't think they're any smarter - after all, these are the same brainiacs who re-elected GWB. I just think it's our turn to get lucky. So, however we get it, let's prepare to savor victory, our delivery from eight years of darkness, incompetence, and swagger. And let's wish La Palin a nice bus ride back to Wasilla, America's little window into the Paleolithic. DU

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
The Frenz honor Late Antiquity at a superbowl dinner party; iSean offers this redux.

No one can cast aspersions on Late Antiquity anymore—not until tomorrow, anyhow. Indeed, imperial attitudes were set aside, and pedals mashed instead. As though the heavens condoned the beatific mood, there was neither a cloud in the sky nor a zephyr on the hillsides.

This Just In...

Rob just wrote me to suggest I take cover. See video below.


How can I retrieve my mail-in ballot from the recycling?! Dave, can you mock one up?

Eric Rudolph says he thinks I can make it in the mountains for a few months.

comments.comment_body: Late Antiquity Himself is coming and fully expecting to be trounced by all you barbarians!

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Dave, Rob, Greg, and I rode up Flagstaff under bluebird skies. At the Amphitheater, we split into two factions: one tackled the summit and another the height-of-land on the road. Boringly nice out.

title: Upside Down Report
author: Steve
body:
Mark sent this from Orlando...kinda feels like my workday

I did manage to sneak out with Greg and reach the Flagstaff House today. Neither of us was dressed up, but Greg was riding a strange new bike.

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
More of Steve's music choices foisted upon you...

Saw Dave on his way down today. He had to get back by 13h. Adriana was able to join, though, so I wasn't alone. For someone not having ridden in a while, she's in great shape! Now that she's almost done applying for the NSF fellowship, we hope to see her more.

As an aside, NASCAR?!!! Come on, guys! Are garbage truck drivers "athletes" too? They get thrashed around. Pushing down on a gas pedal?!

comments.comment_body: Well Wikipedia thinks NASCAR is a sport:. My Snapple All Natural Green Tea bottle cap for today says "'Real Fact' # 167: You have to play ping-pong for 12 hours to lose one pound." I guess Ping Pong might not make the cut as a sport if number of calories burned is a factor...

title: Decision 08
author: Steve
body:
Dave, Greg, K-No, and I will be in a meeting until 13h. Dave's covering for Mr. Riggs, so he might not be able to make a post-meeting ride. But, I'd like to get out. I may just dial up Flag again, if anyone's interested.

I forgot to mention yesterday that the gate on the Amphitheater Road is now closed, which means we've got the summit to ourselves until May 1. Yippee!!

Tomorrow, Sir Brian Kent has agreed to run up Initiation. Who's in? The weather's shaping up just right.


Steve taking care of his little sister

As a final aside, after years of cajoling and allaying irrational fears of mountain lions, I've finally convinced my sister to move to Boulder!! She'll be here on the 18th. Unlike me, she has talent, so if you know of interesting jobs, lemme know. She can only stack wood and shine my shoes for so long.

comments.comment_body: I don't know about y'all, but I have a big, cheap slug of champagne scheduled for about ten tonight. That's when we'll see the Drillah from Wasilla step to the mike and give the crowd one of those quivering, brave little smiles"¦ You know the kind; like when you rolled up your sleeve and got your first tetanus shot. Mom was so proud and the nurse gave you a cherry lollipop. SP will tell her adoring little goslings that they fought the good fight and that they have everything to be proud of. The standard ode to the common loser. (I heard it every Saturday for two years when I played Little League football. We won approximately zero games.) Then, as the crowd approaches mass embolism, she'll turn and walk off the stage. As she passes a wildly clapping Joe the Plumber, she'll lean slightly toward him and whisper "Interested in Secretary of Labor in 2012?" I'll pour my second tumbler and switch back to Barack's victory party. There, that's much better. DU

At least you did not use the pic of you "helping" me walk where you were actually pushing me down. :)  I'm very excited to see you!

Love,
me

PS - My fears of mountain lions are not irrational.

Uh oh. The Frenzy is moving into Dr. Phil territory. A sibling grudge exposed to the light of day after a decade's-long dormancy. Family dynamics. Phobias. Manias. Political struggles and crib-borne psycho-terrorism. Now that I know the meter's running ("Welcome to the Frenzy. The Doctor will be with you shortly. Please have your credit card handy."), I'll be brief... My Mom always liked my brother best. She told him that if he worked hard, applied himself, and got really good grades, he could have his own dry-cleaning business some day. After all, that's what dreams are for. Me? A different story. Keep your sock drawer organized, tuck your shirt in, and if you're lucky, you'll stay out of prison. Screw up and you'll end up on a bicycle with a bunch of guys half your age... And watch out for mountain lions." DU PS, Gobama!

title: Flagstaff Duel Sunshine with a Twist
author: Steve
body: I completely missed the boat today. Sorry, guys. At least Dave escaped.

comments.comment_body:
Sorry Steve, but I just couldn't sit down to the same plate for the 726th time... I needed a little break so I went a wanderin'. 

I found a cool side loop in Sunshine: the Timber Trail/Seven Knolls route. All dirt, mostly steep. And since it drops you right back in the Canyon, it makes a nice add-on. Reminds me a bit of NW Passage. 

We should add it to the docket, eh?

DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Too bad I didn't have a camera! On the return flight to campus, I saw the grounds crew raking leaves. The winds are gusting to 40mph, and these poor folks are raking leaves! Reminded me of a Camus tale.

The ride was blustery, even for Flagstaff! Still, I was astounded by the number of cyclists I saw today. Usually, everyone's scared away from the mountains at the first sign of bad weather. Apparently, wind doesn't count.

I'm really digging the closed gate! Makes the Amphitheater Road our very own sanctum sanctorum. The more so today since Dave's off fishing, Rob's sick, and Greg/K-No are probably in a fun Friday meeting.

Since I was alone, I didn't have to worry about practicing good manners. Thank goodness.

My dad arrives tonight, and so I'll be on vacation on Monday and Tuesday. I may just try to sneak out for a ride, so stay tuned. I'll get a new poll up today too. Have a great weekend, all!

Dennis's Sendoff Ride

Dennis has identified Thursday next week as a possible Neva Loop Sendoff Ride, in view of his looming retirement. Hopefully a number of you lurkers will come out of the woodwork for this good cause!

title: Sunshine Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Can you name this member of the Frenz? Hint: His birthday is this Friday!

It should've been called "Headwind Canyon" today. Better workout, though, I suppose. Poorman Road is in great shape, either for climbing or descending. Nice hard-packed dirt.

Bumped into one of the Frenzy lurkers, Lori Emerson, going down Fourmile. Lori is a new faculty member in English, who just recently purchased a Specialized Roubaix. She's promised to join us Friday for a ride up Flagstaff. Lurker no more, eh, Lori?

Sendoff for Dennis Tomorrow?

No official word from the man of honor on riding in high winds tomorrow, but I'm guessing we'll hold off. Dennis?

comments.comment_body: That cute puppy is still alive and doing quite well unlike the gentleman in that picture who hasn't aged quite as gracefully.  As luck may have it the birthday boy may end up with a checkride and subsequent solo flight in the mighty T-34C on his birthday.  Fancy that!
Since I am generally a wuss, I think the wind is a bit much tomorrow. Let's shoot for a nicer day. Dennis

Is that young Master Burton? 

A deceptively genteel photo, given what we know today, eh? 

Experts tell us that this is the last known photo of MB wearing clean socks. 

It was only a month or so after this picture was taken that MB slipped into what is now known as his "trog period." It would be years before he resurfaced, and though the historical record points toward a "den" somewhere under Interstate 40 in Indiana, MB's whereabouts during that period remain deeply shrouded in mystery.

In 2005, his overnight apotheosis and subsequent meltdown at the hands of a vastly superior Dave Underwood became the stuff of Frenzy legend.

The puppy went on to become a dog.

DU

title: Flagstaff...Really...Report
author: Steve
body:
Rob and I had a quick ride today. Still, the important thing is that we got out and enjoyed the fresh air. It was chilly coming down, as the shadowy, snow-covered areas still possessed some of their nip.

I'm still savoring the closed Amphitheater Road. It's so nice not to see cars and occasionally startle the woman who walks her two little terriers along the road.

comments.comment_body:
I'm going w/ 12:15 for my departure time. If SB's start time is too early, come ride w/ me. Buzz me: 2-2672

DU

Anybody interested in going to the Warren Miller flick on Sunday afternoon? (http://www.skinet.com/warrenmiller/) It's a great way to get psyched for the winter and there are some great giveaways too. Let me know.

title: Back (in the Saddle) Alley Report
author: Steve
body:
There was light in the darkest recesses of Back Alley today

Man, someone pinch me! It's summery out.

Dave and I managed to cajole Greg into joining us on what now merely qualifies as a semi-crazy ride, given the existence of Patients of Job, Super-Sugarloaf, et al.

It was actually refreshing to swoop down into the frost pockets at the base of Sunshine Canyon. The 10-15° temperature difference didn't chill us one bit.

Poor Greg, though: if you see him later today, ask him what he thinks of our "purge" method of recovering from a cold. Somehow, I sense that he's worse off, which means it was a good ride, of course.

title: Betasso Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Today, Steve got schooled in the ways of cycling

Dave and the crew skipped town on me today, so I figured I'd be riding alone. But, when I stepped out the door today, lo and behold, there was Brian Hutchison.

Now, I won't attribute any malicious intent to Mr. Hutchison—I'm sure he was just looking for some company on his lunch ride. But, despite his innocent intentions, I had a feeling I was in for a painful day in the saddle.

I wasn't disappointed.

The full cycling team kit served notice that I was in for some suffering. That wasn't all that worried me, though.

Indeed, Mr. Hutchison was running a non-compact crankset. What earthly cyclist rides Flag with those gears?! He then informed me he was going medium intensity on this afternoon's ride: climbing the 10% grades exclusively in the big ring. Of course, I think he was just trying to make me feel better; he was likely at easy intensity.

Anyhow, my hackles verily raised, I resigned myself to wheel-clinging, figuring it best to hang on for dear life. I'd hate to see this guy's high intensity days.

Anyhow, as I lost contact on the third of Three Easy Pieces, I heard Phil and Paul saying, Oooh, Bailey's dropped. He's got to be careful here. He's got to ride within himself up to the summit.

Indeed, I felt a little like Jan Ullrich looking down at the pedals wondering where the power went.

Great ride, Brian! Thanks for joining us. Please feel free to tag along again during one of your very easy days.

title: Betasso Fa Shizzle Report
author: Steve
body:
I may encounter a similar scene at home today; our own little puppy Baxter loves toilet paper

Great day again! Thanks to Rob and Dave for keeping me company. Guess what, Dave? I'm pulling an Underwood right now: bought a Mountain Dew.

Anyhow, I have to admit, as much as I like the cold, nasty weather, I'm digging this prolonged summer. Of course, that said, there was a hint of Greeley in the air, which can only mean one thing.

I'm wondering how bad this freezing drizzle will be. On Mount Washington, freezing drizzle (FZDZ) was bad news. It meant the constant de-iceing of instruments with a crowbar.

Hopefully for us, it will just mean carrying a few extra clothes.

comments.comment_body: Booty pads!  Booty pads!

To those about to drink a mountain dew: I salute you.

Regards,
Gunthinator

Happy day, now that winter has at least chosen to drop in, if not stay for a while.  In any case, it looks a perfect day for you cyclists to develop some "initiative"... and get out for an icy, rainy run >:)

I love the taste of Mountain Dew in the morning! Tastes like... Victory. That nasty little wasp who rode part of the way down Boulder Canyon with me yesterday must've been packing some heavy artillery. He tasered me 4 or 5 times while he was onboard, which I find curious. I know that honeybees sting once, then nobly fall on their swords and die. But is not the wasp family subject to any sort of upper limit on moving violations? This guy clearly had been saving up. Today my so-called chest looks like a London Broil. And I'll just bet the little bastid is perched on a rock somewhere above the Elephant Butress this morning, telling his buddies about how he almost drove the milkface on the bike into the ditch yesterday. Hope he freezes to death. Speaking of determined sadists, I had my last follow-up appointment with Our Lady of the Scalpels this week. She's the surgeon who so neatly lifted my rib last June. She was trying to determine if I could still be considered a "billable object," or if I had any remaining bones she might be needing to fill out her collection. She was positively effusive, and a quick glance at the wall behind her told me why. It was a newly framed and mounted certificate proclaiming her recent acceptance into the International Meatcutters Union, Local No. 5. "I wasn't sure they'd admit me. Their standards are super tough," she told me. "You must be very proud," I said. "I am. And you know, in this economy, having a backup is never a bad idea. I think they were especially taken with my skills with the bow saw." "Me too. You did a real number on me. But other than the sound of the Shop Vac, I hardly remember a thing." "You were an easy patient. You can put your shirt back on now. Please. Please." As I buttoned up, she said "Well, everything looks fine. I think you can safely return to your normal activities now." Great... Problem is, I don't have any normal activities. Right, Frenz? DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Another great video vignette from Paul Frederick

Well, as it turned out, Dave wasn't able to join us today. Shucks. Maybe Gunther will actually hop on a bike next week, so we can get our share of Dave time.

Anyhow, I was solo today, which ended up being good, for I checked my front tire pressure while waiting and realized it was at 45psi—not so good for road biking.

After getting some air, I headed up Baseline, where I espied Greg composting his knees running toward Chautauqua. I was sure to point out that it was warm enough to ride in short sleeves, but Greg answered with a flippant guffaw.

Despite the swirling crosswinds, the ride was just peachy. Not a soul at the summit; only the sound of the wind. In the distance, I could see some dark clouds enshrouding the Indian Peaks and the infamous brown cloud squatting on the Eastern Plains.


Apart from the now outlawed Criminal Intent, this is the most epic Frenzy lunch ride by far!

Next week is fall break, which means you can ask your respective bosses for more ride-time. You'll want to for sure, because we're aiming to ride Super-Sugarloaf on Tuesday.

Carve out about 2hrs around noon, boss-permitting of course. The pace will be slow, as there's a lot of dramatic, quasi-technical climbing.

comments.comment_body: Guys! It's 37 degrees. Yikes. I'll be running and looking to sweep your frozen bodies off the road somewhere around Chataqua.
Au contraire, Greg! Since the sun broke out, Mesa Lab temps have skyrocketed! It's now 45° F up high!!

Your share of Dave time? You should be so lucky. I just took one of those self-assessment surveys in the new Reader's Digest, and, based on the results, I'm due for an upgrade. According to the test, one of the reasons I'm falling behind in so many areas (hygiene, common sense, hygiene) is that I'm imprinting on the wrong people (read: Frenz). JG, though unfortunately currently at odds with the Colorado criminal justice system, is helping me get my mind up off the carpet and back in working oder. This is a slow process, but she appears to have infinite patience. Today we discussed Voltaire and something else about Spain. (Or was it France?) DU

title: Super-Flag Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Adriana and I took advantage of the continued mild fall weather today, pointing our skinny tires toward the tippy-top of Flagstaff. Despite the occasional convoy of wanna-be race car drivers, we enjoyed a relatively quiet day in the saddle.

There wasn't much dancing on the pedals this afternoon, though. The winds were at your back at one moment, down your throat the next. Still, when you're climbing in a short-sleeve jersey in November, you really can't complain.

One thing Dave's noted in recent comments is the return of the dreaded sandpits, particularly in the hairpin corners. Be careful when you're descending, folks.

title: Northwest Passage Report
author: Steve
body:
Great spin this afternoon. We were a little chilly leaving Humanities, but after a little while in the sun, we were nice and toasty.

We took a right at the dirt fork today, as opposed to the traditional left, and the road was in decent shape. A few patches of surface mud, but no quicksand. Excellent conditions compared to last time we rode that section.

Dave's right: I did wash my clothes and survive a sewage mishap while moonlighting for the City. Now I know what people mean when they say: I just can't wash out that garlic smell.

Super-Sugarloaf Tomorrow

Don't forget to ask your boss for a little extra lunch time tomorrow. There may even be a little surprise en route for those brave enough to challenge this course.

Matt Burton Chimes In

This just in from Florida:

This past week was quite epic in terms of workload and fun. I had both my first checkride and my first solo in the T-34C on Monday. On Tuesday I started the precision aerobatics block. It's probably the most fun I've ever had in an airplane. Not only do I get to do aerobatics in the T-34C along the Gulf Coast but they want me to do them solo this week and they are paying me for it! Life doesn't get much better than that. I hope to make it through aerobatics and start the formation flying block before the Christmas break.

Biking is, unfortunately, a once-a-week hobby at most. The ever-changing flight schedule and the early sunsets make it difficult to ride on weekdays. The odometer is getting up into the 3800 mile range... on the original front tire and tube!

Unbelievable! 3800 miles on the same tire/tube combo?! The Force is strong with that one.

comments.comment_body: What the heck is super sugar?

Funny how two and two sometimes dance around in dumb, jerky circles before finally merging to make four. At the top of The Great Wall of Mud today, we stopped for a moment to adjust our stuff for the descent. SB donned about twelve layers of Gortex, Kevlar, Tyvek, Poly-Pro, and rock wool. I rolled my sleeves down. As he slipped a powder blue Patagonia NoseCozey over his head, he told me he'd washed all of his riding clothes this weekend. "That's nice," I said, thinking he did, in fact, smell less exhumed than normal. Or at least not as recently exhumed. I didn't give it any more thought. But just now, while I was watching the construction guys chase each other around the new art building with power tools and water balloons (Move-in date December 2009? Not at this rate!), I remembered a little news item I'd seen in the Daily Camera this morning. It seems several workers at the Boulder County sewage-treatment plant were airlifted out of the facility late last night, due to "severe respiratory distress." A spokesman said a sudden surge in "biotoxins and germs the size of plump gerbils" had overwhelmed the plant's ability to keep up. Those workers who weren't physically sickened were nonetheless sent home and scheduled to begin intensive counseling as early as this morning. Residents were asked to flush judiciously until the system returned to normal... hopefully by month's end. See what I mean? Four. DU

title: Super-Sugarloaf Adventure Ride for the Ages Report
author: Steve
body:
Harry Potter preview...

Fantastic day on Super-Sugarloaf!

Thanks to Kev, Greg, Brian, Dave, Adriana, and Melissa for joining the fun. Special thanks to Melissa, who rode the whole way in fingerless gloves and shorts. Ouch!

I should have a gallery up by tonight...forgot the USB cable. Stay tuned.

comments.comment_body: There was blood. Kudos to Melissa for playing my part today and taking the requisite Frenzy Flop. Hope it didn't hurt too bad! Great ride, all! DU
I think Melissa also had the quote of the day...something to the effect of "I was just thinking I wouldn't drive my car up this dirt road..." Never put it past SB to suggest a "rambo" ride.

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Photos from yesterday's ride on Super-Sugarloaf

Shorts and short-sleeves. Need I say more?

Yeah, the day before a little bit of weather moves in, conditions are just dandy in Boulder. Lots of tourists on the mountain, but it's easy enough to ignore them for a day.

Now time to go hear my officemate, The Gammonizer, talk about his dissertation: "Persistently Present." I've invited more people than he expects in order to simulate a real world dissertation defense. Poor guy.

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
The streets on The Hill are packed slush-ice

All in all, great ride today. It's sunny, temps aren't too cold, no wind, and no one to share the road with.

But, despite the seemingly dry conditions on campus, the roads on The Hill are in terrible shape, save 13th and 9th. I'm really glad I took the truck.

While the traffic was light, I was nearly swiped by a snowplow and boxed out by a big SUV—one of those "I know how to drive in the mountains....FAST!" type dingbats. No other bikers at all, however!

I'll say it again: when your work allows you to spend the lunch hour looking at ponderosa pines smothered in felty snow, you just can't complain!

comments.comment_body: I wore 5 layers yesterday on Flag, which means I have 5 layers of bike clothes that are still completely soaked. I could ride in my office togs, but these are my favorite double-pleated Bobby Jones gaberdines and my Foligliano calfskin shoes don't sit well on the pedals. Footwork for J and me today. I'm gonna' hang all my stuff out the window George Bellows-style this morning and maybe it'll be dry and minty-fresh by tomorrow. It'll class the place up a bit, too. DU

title: Flagstaff Ride (Really!) Report
author: Steve
body:
Thanks to Rob, I was able to get out on the roadbike today and enjoy the now much drier tarmac on Flagstaff Road.

While there are still a few sneaky, slush-ice sections, they can be avoided. At least our weather's not as bad as what my hometown is experiencing now!

Have a great weekend, all!

comments.comment_body:
Koster!

Sorry to hear I passed on my cold. iSean will take this as further evidence of my perfidy. Oh well.

The ice can be beautiful, indeed! I remember driving the Kanc once after an ice storm, and it was spectacular. You can't help but feel sad for all the trees, though. Hey, it's New Hampshire...the trees will be back in 10 years!

Yeah, no kidding.  Power and phone came back after 10hr yesterday...but took a 2hr break overnight.  I'm sure this is a faux pas and oh the poor trees that are still standing are all keeled over but it's really beautiful out there.  S&A, thanks for sharing the plague!

title: Happy Birthday, Angela!
author: Steve
body:
Frenz, today is Angela Werner's birthday. Happy Birthday, Angela! See you sometime on one of our lunchtime outings?


Sir Brian Kent: 12/19

Dave Underwood: 12/28

Big birthday month! Does anyone want to do a little 100 mile run with Brian? Dave just wants company on the next ice-cycle ride up Flagstaff.

comments.comment_body: It was cold this weekend, but not too cold to take the family down to see the traveling carnival in the Sam's Club parking lot. They had the usual assortment of squeaky, stomach-churning rides and threadbare oddities of nature in canvas huts. Standard-issue stuff to be sure; I'd seen it all a thousand times before. It was one of the "skill booths" that really got my attention. We'd already worked our way through the ring toss and the paddle-ball arcades when we came to this particular beauty. It looked easy enough at first, so I decided to give it a shot. But it was no cakewalk. If you think the bobbing ducks in the marksman's arcade are tough to hit, you should have seen this thing. I was determined to win a cupie doll or a stuffed polar bear for the kids, but after going through a full stack of quarters I realized I simply didn't have the chops. I didn't hit the damned thing even once. I felt like a total heel and the kids pouted all the way home. SB and I are doing Flag today, right SB? DU

title: Skunk Canyon Run Report
author: Steve
body:
Footage of Dave on Flagstaff today, courtesy of Sir Brian Kent's iPhone

The only person crazy brave enough to join me today was Mr. Leary, who was probably still a bit hypothermic from his run yesterday. Despite our lack of good judgement, we had a fine day in the sub-zero conditions.

Yaktrax were a must this afternoon. What would've been really nice—and Rob and I have agreed this is patent-worthy—is some kind of heated codpiece.

Dave has some such device, but last time he showed it to me, he got carted off like Inspector Clouseau. Suppose the 29th Street Mall wasn't the best location. For now, an extra pair of shorts will suffice.

comments.comment_body:
sure sure, sounds fun and frigid!

RL
I got a rule that when it's cold enough to take your breath away, I don't exercise outside. Y'all are nuts. Think I might hit the Rec Center.

While I was out running on Flagstaff today, I actually saw some maniac out on a bike! Skinny tires! Oh, that was no maniac - that was Dave. Running in this is minor league compared to riding Flagstaff in it.

I coulda' used that codpiece today. I forgot and left it at home, hooked up to the charger. (BTW, if you own the Model SS4-36B, don't forget to pull those cables before you put it on. Oh...my...God) No matter... I had a delightful ride w/out it today. And it looks like I made my goal of doing Flag with 100Â° bookends. It was minus .49Â° when I left and plus .9Â° when I got back (Foothills Lab).... Good enough; I know I've ridden it when it was at least 101Â°. Mission accomplished, codpiece or no. DU

Good lord, Dave!  You're crazier than I thought!!!

It was a good run, Thanks, Steve, for makin' it so!

RL

Hey-- Yaktrax "walkers" or "pro"?

You guys are nuts.  I'm going to ride the rollers.

KK

Brian,

Dave's asinine feats have always (falsely) given me the sense I'm well-grounded!

My size 13 feets further reinforce that sense.

KTK,

Yaktrax Pro!

title: Change We Can Believe In
author: Dave
body:
Yes, we can!

After four years of failed policies and the same old fear-based leadership, it's time for change. Won't you join me and my fellow Frenz as we march toward a new dawn?

(SB has foolishly left me at the controls again as he takes his well-deserved vacation. You'd think he'd learn. Flag looks good today; call me if you're interested. 2-2672)

comments.comment_body:
So cold, Dave!  What were you hoping for?  

I'm leaning towards a run... but hate to leave you "out in the cold" as it were...

RL

Cold? What cold?

Actually, I'd much rather run today as well, believe me. But just look at these knees, wouldya'? Holy crap; even my orthopedist/paleontologist has taken to working on me blindfolded. He says he just can't operate the SawzAll when he's that disturbed.

What a lightweight.

Afraid I'm stuck on the bike no matter the weather. Have a good run, Roberto! 

DU

I'm also thinking it's a good day for a run and a very cold day for a ride. I'll probably drive up to the trail if either of you want to join me for a run or hike. The train will be leaving from lot 310 (behind Wardenburg & Cheyenne/Arapahoe) about noon if you want to join. I'll try hard not to lock my keys in the car this time, Rob.

Hey guys, I "ran" in the snowy northeast woods today and found that knee-deep snow=5,400' aka I had to stop (to keep my heart from exploding) just as often on the uphills here as I did running in Boulder!  Happy Holidays!!
KK

Well, Mr. Stauffer proved a man of his word, and the two of us met up at the Chautauqua parking lot.  From there we skittered our way up Gregory Canyon, topping out by taking the Ute trail over Flagstaff.  We meandered back down the Flagstaff Trail to Crown Rock, where we found ourselves on dry ground (!!!) for most of the way back down.  We even ceremoniously removed our Yax Trax to commemorate the occasion.  We made it back to the Chautauqua Lot with a minimum of fanfare, and back to our desks soon after that.

We didn't see DU on Flag, although we certainly were on the lookout.  Cold?  Icy?  Where were you, Dave???

I was there, Rob, but I was thoroughly bundled up and you probably didn't recognize me. I was actually so overdressed (9 layers on top, 4 below) that the descent felt great! I really needed to cool off. 

Glad you guys had a good run!

DU

title: Super-Flag Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dr. Gammon found this great gift for me! How considerate of him.

The skies nowadays are either snowy or crystal-clear. Today we had the latter.


Steve and Greg ride Super-Flagstaff on a brisk October day

The ride up was quite toasty. Later we realized it was due to a tailwind that lifted us uphill.

On the way down, we realized there was actually a strong, shrill, armor-piercing breeze that left Greg numb. Greg braved the conditions in shorts, summer gloves, and a long-sleeve jersey.

Wonder if he's thawed out? Thanks for joining today, Greg!

comments.comment_body: If this device is called Chair Pants, would a bike be considered something like Chair Running Shorts?

title: A Peek Under the Hood
author: Dave
body:
Being here at Frenzy HQ during the holidays is a bit creepy, I must say.

The Dark Lord (SB) has sent the staff home (laid them off, more likely) and the place is deathly quiet. It feels a bit like The Shining, though not nearly as lighthearted. Since it's so slow, I've taken to poking around in the back rooms and storage closets, and the stuff I've found is truly heart-gagging. Apparently The Dark Lord's hygiene training got lost somewhere in the shuffle. And I gotta' tell ya': typing with rubber gloves is no cakewallk!

I'm walking today. JG has a theory that my limping is simply a problem of imbalance. She feels certain that if I trash my right knee as badly as the left, voila!, problem solved. We're doing Kohler Mesa and I hope she's right. If you'd like to see science in action, give me a buzz; 2-2672.

title: Another year older, sadly no wiser
author: Dave
body:
Denny's: a clean, well-lighted place

It's 2030, give or take, and I'm on my death bed. The whole family is there with me, and my grandchildren (or it could be their avatars; with these little bouyam, I can never tell) have just ordered pizza. No one asks if I still like pepperoni. The doorbell rings. It's the guy from MortgageWorx. He's here to administer last rites and to let Ronna know she needs to be out by midnight. I pull my head down under my carapace of tangled blankets, and, like a bad PowerPoint, my life flashes before me. Lots of grainy images and indecipherable bullet lists. I try to make sense of it all, but it's difficult because the moron who authored the whole thing used a magenta background and navy blue text. It's horribly confusing, but a few nuggets of truth somehow float to the surface like bubbles in a Lava Lamp. And I know now that there are two life conclusions I will not reach: "¢Â I should have watched more television. "¢Â I should have been nicer to Bailey on the Frenzy. No me today; talk amongst yourselves. Denny's is still doing that SofSteakâ„¢ lunch special (those clever devils have figured out a way to outsource the heavy chewing) for seniors on their birthdays, and I don't want to miss out. If I get lucky, the staff might come to my table and sing to me in big print. Tomorrow looks to be balmy. I'm thinking a spin down Neva might be fun. E'tu?

comments.comment_body: I'm thinking the trails will be a bit sloppy today so I'm going to dust off the bike. Give me a call (5-1608) if you want to join me at noon.

I should have been nicer to Bailey on the Frenzy

Now, why would you want to go and do that? That would take all the fun out of it!

HAPPY BELATED BIRTHDAY, BUD!

title: Flagstaff ride report
author: Dave
body:
That's one tough chicken

Greg and I had a surprisingly nice ride up the hill today. The wind wasn't nearly as nasty up against the slope and we didn't get hit by any of those rogue gusts that try to take you off the bike. Kevin, here's your checklist for tomorrow: _ helmet You may want to print this off and take it home with you tonight.

title: 2008: History's Taylor Hicks
author: Dave
body:
Look familiar? It should; it's your 401k

Happy New Year to all of our Frenzy readers from around the globe! Here's hoping you both have a fabulous 2009 and that the warden lets you guys back into the weight room next year. We still think you got a crappy deal. Â  What would the new year be without a reflective look back at the previous year's highlights? So before we put on the funny hats and start drinking 'til we turn cubist, let's take a moment to recap 2008's greatest hits. Here they are, in chronological order: That was easy. Thank God history grades on a curve... it's our only hope. I need to stay close to HQ today, so I'll be hitting Flag again, with maybe a little SuperFlag tacked on. Telecom at noon? I'm out Friday. SB would like you all to break up into small groups and discuss ways to be more productive. Â Â  Be safe, Frenz!

comments.comment_body: Happy New Year, Frenz!

title: Help, I've Fallen and I Can't Get Up
author: Dave
body:
I think I'll be paying for this for a very long time

Forgive me, Steve, for today I have strayed. I totally spaced my duties to the Frenzy and now it's late afternoon and I'm feeling lower than the Dow. Tomorrow, I promise, I'll mend my evil ways. Think a ride up Poorman in the mud will be good penance?

title: A Wrinkle in Time Report
author: Dave
body:
"Hey, Buddy! Hey! Wake up! The meeting's over! Hey, Buddy? Hey!"

I got a late start today, but at least I got out, meeting be damned. I put in a blustery hour's worth of spinning out east... the Baseline Rez drill, clockwise. It was uphill and cold all the way back.

comments.comment_body: I think that's what I needed (a lion to nudge me) at this afternoon's meeting to keep me awake.

title: Well short of a dream job
author: Dave
body:
How I felt when Steve handed me the keys

I know what you're thinking: How in God's green earth did Underwood land this gig? While Bailey picks mooseberries up in Hooterville, Underwood cozies up to the flight deck at Frenzy HQ and makes himself right at home, tweaking this, jobbing that, just like he owns the damn place. While I'm no Dr. Phil, I do know a thing or two about people, and I think you might be jealous. I think you're all "It should have been me. I should be the one at the helm, not that bootlicking toady Underwood, not that hack Quisling with the fourth-grade vocab and the reaction time of a lobotomized gnu." Shows what you know. It turns out this job truly sucks. The workload here is unimaginable. I have to do everything myself. Other than the little Oompa-Loompas down in the mail room, the place is completely unstaffed (SB pinkslipped everyone at the annual Christmas party - a present to himself). The toilets in the main data processing wing are all backed up, and the break room has just been declared a superfund site. To control costs, Bailey has epoxied the thermostats at a permanent 47Â° and all of the cubicles are half-scale. Good grief. On top of that, the accounting firm that cuts the checks is sending out sympathy cards and free ballpoint pens "until the current crisis passes." Makes me wanna' scream. I'll be doing Kohler in the wind today. Back on wheels tomorrow.

title: Poorman; counter-clockwise ride report
author: Dave
body:
The locals call it "Slacker's Row"

No mud after all on Poorman today; Greg and I had an easy go of it. The canyon is in surprisingly good shape for mid-winter and the tail wind certainly livened things up. Great ride, Greg!

comments.comment_body:
Oh Dave, how I wish I could join you.  60 degrees?  Unpardonable!

I'm stuck here in a conference of CTO's, supporting their projections, audio, and web streaming.  Alas.  I can't believe I can't go out to play today :(

RL

GTO's? One of Pontiac's finest cars, though I always thought if they'd tuned the headers on the short block 387, they would have really kicked butt. Oh well... could be worse, I guess. Could be stuck in a meeting. DU

title: Back in the Saddle Report
author: Steve
body:
Thanks to Dave's application of training wheels, I was able to remember how to ride my bike. It was wobbly, but good to be back on two four wheels.

Thanks, Dave!

comments.comment_body:
Double whammy; I'm back, too.

I've been out w/ family stuff, but it's all settled down now and I'm dying to roll.

Thanks to Steve for letting me tank the Frenzy for as long as I did. Good thing he got back while there was still a pulse; another week and it would have expired... just one more Potemkin-village of a blog, all tempera and veneer, no life, no blood, no free T-shirts.

See ya' at noon!

DU

title: Fourmile Canyon Ride
author: Steve
body: It's supposed to be a glorious day. Let's check the water levels along Fourmile Creek. Gather at Humanities @ 11:40a.

comments.comment_body: I'm in a meeting til noon then off to a quick circuit workout at the Rec Center. Enjoy the rollers of Four Mile for me.

title: Flagstaff Ride Nothing to See Here Report
author: Steve
body: I didn't make it out today. But I rode back and forth to Fleming twice. That counts for something, right?

title: Flagstaff Retry Report
author: Steve
body:
Hiking to Gray Knob Cabin in New Hampshire's Presidential Range

Great company and ride up the hill today. We even saw Brian Hutchison, who followed up Flagstaff with a short sprint up Poorman. Yikes! Shorts and short-sleeves. Unreal!


For my dad's Christmas gift, I digitized some of his old 16mm films

My dad shot these scenes circa 1958-9 in Stark and West Milan, NH. Can you spot the black bear?

The unique sleds were the invention of my great uncle Henry, whom you see at the ice falls in a red wool jacket in a place called Devil's Hopyard. Uncle Henry had a crosscut saw world record (1935) and was renown in the north country for grafting apple tree branches (225 different species on one tree).

I think these digitized clips are fantastic. I had them done professionally in Atlanta at an outfit recommended by Wired Magazine; they're called CinéPost. They use a "wetgate" process to remove scratches and a scene-to-scene color-correction process. Results speak for themselves!

title: Sunshine Canyon - Poorman Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Dave and I had a great ride this afternoon. I think today was the last of the short-sleeve weather for a while, so we soaked it all in.

Unusually strong tailwind on the descent, to the point where I stopped pedaling and was still maintaining about 40mph to the Bridge at Arapahoe. Poorman was in great shape: no fingers of ice across the road and no mud!

comments.comment_body: No comments!? What? An injustice. High school shenanigans of that caliber deserve recognition. May we all be so lucky to have video evidence of our long-spent youthful creativity, and be able to share it with Frenz! Mrs. Brown! Carrie! Now where's the fast-forward on this thing...

I agree w/ JG about the fast forward; I clawed for the damn thing.

And once the tape started rolling, I had this sick, visceral feeling I used to get when the attendant strapped me into the Tilt-O-Whirl at the Whizbang County Fair, this feeling of helpless, round-eyed surrender, of knowing that, for the next X minutes, my life and my lunch would be in someone else's hands.

But it wasn't all that bad, in retrospect. I made it all the way through the video in one piece and now I feel stronger for it. This may, in fact, be one of the better New England high school snuff films I've ever seen... admittedly a very thin niche.

Great ride down Boulder Canyon today, eh Steve? Gotta' love a determined tailwind.

DU
So now we finally get the story of how Steve Austin (aka Bailey) became the Six Million Dollar Man!
I knew that by posting that video I'd resurrect the smack talk this blog is known for—it was sluggish of late.  Come on, people!
I knew that by posting that video I'd resurrect the smack talk this blog is known for... Yeah, like dropping a ping-pong ball into a blender. DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Dave soldiered all the way up, while I only made it to Crown Rock. Still, beats not getting out at all! Bon weekend!

comments.comment_body: Brrr.

Blame it on my cherty personality, but I really prefer days like this to yesterday. Too bad Steve had to turn back when he did; he missed the snow flurries up near the top.

Fingers crossed for a major blizzard,
DU

title: Gates of the Arctic and a Dispatch from Sunny Acres
author: Dave
body:
Adriana helps get Steve back in time for Bingo

I just dropped by the nursing home. It was time for the daily wet mop and they wanted visitors to step out for a bit. I told Steve I'd be right back, but I won't, not that it matters; in his state all things are ephemeral, and now is then and then was never. Since he hurt his back, SB has become what his caregivers call a "roiling vortex of need." I tried telling his nurse that he wasn't always like this, that he was young and vital once. She just giggled, and as she stuck the Post-It note on his forehead ("Checked underwear Monday AM.. Check again Thursday"), she said, "That's what they all say." I'm doing Flag at noon. Takers?

comments.comment_body: Flag today? How about the next time it snows we have a snow angel contest...

Do I look fat in these tights? I mean all four pairs. The secret today was layering. I was warmth incarnate both up and down Flag, even if I did look like the Michelin Man. Took me ten minutes to peel all that stuff off when I got back. I'm good-to-go for the snow angel contest, Dennis... Serious wingspan. DU

title: On Your Own
author: Steve
body:
Rode the truck in this morning with the hope of getting out today.  Unfortunately, not far past Fairview High, the gears completely stopped working (pedaling forward was just like pedaling backward).  So, I had to scooter-push the darn thing to the Southside Walnut Cafe, then take the bus in.

In any case, I'm going to take it easy this afternoon.  I won't make the same mistake as yesterday of sitting in my chair for eight hours, but I'm not going to push it much either.

Hopefully, things will be better tomorrow.  Sorry, guys!

comments.comment_body: Bummer about your wheels, Steve. I know how manly it feels scooter-pushing your bike down the road. Remember the time I went to Jamestown like that? When my frame broke? And everyone in town was pointing and snickering when I pulled into the Merc? And I walked funny - okay, funnier - for a day? Yesterday was much better for cycling; it was dry. I don't want to drown out there today, so I'm hitting the stairs in Duane. Ugh. DU

title: Flagstaff Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Zack Underwood at Loch Vale. Dave says, We should do this trail sometime!

Not to be outdone! Dennis at the 10th Mountain Hut near Tennessee Pass

Great ride today! Dave and I enjoyed the cool but comfy conditions, and were only held back from the tippy top by one pernicious snow drift. Thanks, Dave!

Dave and Zack's Sunday Ski Report
The Park was beautiful today. Z and I skied up to Loch Vale. I'm beat to a pulp tonight from countless falls but they were all from being a bumbling klutz, not from vapor lock or whatever.

Though Adriana and I weren't nearly as ambitious, we skied up the Rollins Pass Road a ways yesterday. Because it was Superbowl Sunday, all the snowmobilers were absent, so we had the trail to ourselves. Quite good skiing, in fact!

Before skiing, we did our taxes. It was a romantic Sunday.

comments.comment_body: My bike is at home on the trainer. Duh. I'll probably run up Flag or through Chautauqua, if anyone wants to join me (5-1608).
BTW, that's a stunning shot at Loch Vale.

Since everybody is sharing their weekend activities in pictures, here's mine: http://tinyurl.com/oougv 

Yeah, I'm jealous.

Greg,

I hate to be a pain, but it looks like you missed a spot.

DU

title: Laying Low, Day Two
author: Dave
body:
Sometimes love wears a very stern face

Two things struck me yesterday as I crawled out from under the anesthetic. One; as a recreational drug, cortisone has some catchin' up to do. And two; my doctor. She rapped me across the snout w/ her stethoscope and told me this time I really need to take it easy or else. "I'm tired of pumping drugs into you, then seeing you back on the Frenzy with your delinquent pals the very next day. This time, I mean it: TAKE IT EASY! You're not a kid anymore... Hell, you're not even middle-aged anymore." "So you're saying wait until, like, Wednesday?" Another instant, sharp ding with the 'scope told me that that was possibly the wrong guess. So let's make it Thursday. (I think Steve is buried again today and I'm under house arrest. Woe is us!) DU

title: Waltz of the Walking Wounded
author: Steve
body:
The Frenz sporting the latest in hi-tech cycling gear...wait a minute...is that The Hungry Toad?!

Despite explicit instructions from his doctor, Underwood was out on the bike today, helmet-less among other things. Happy Friday, all!

title: Sunshine Sashay Report
author: Steve
body: It clouded up by the time I hit the road, so conditions were cool but not cold. It was nice to try to ride Sunshine "easy", for it's normally so darn deadly!

comments.comment_body: I woke up about 3 a.m. and couldn't fall back to sleep. So I put my bike on the trainer and did an hour-long spin. And that's where my bike still is. So I think I'll pass on this afternoon's ride although it should be ideal weather.

title: Marshall - Cherryvale Spin Report
author: Steve
body:
Yay! Ryan Van Duzer applied for that dream job off the Great Barrier Reef. He's perfect! Go, Duzer-Cruzer!!

Today was a first: I didn't see Dave try to chase anyone ahead of us. He showed real restraint, which is a good thing since he had surgery only hours ago. I think our little boy is becoming a man! I'm so proud.

comments.comment_body: As my orthopedist hacked his way toward his April boat payment on Monday, he took some great pics of the festivities. He told me his aim was to clear away all the junk that was crushing my ACl and had been making me walk like a duck. As the evidence shows, he may have gotten a little carried away; he was headed north at an alarming rate. He told me later that the microgrinder is so darn much fun it's just hard to stop sometimes. Don't click on this if you're squeamish (Steve). How to make $5000 in forty-five minutes Actually, my doctor is great, a saint even, and I'm all better. If, God forbid, you ever need a knee job, let me know and I'll give you his name. A whispered aside: I get a free set of steak knives w/ every referral. DU

title: Betasso Super-Flag Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Came across this great story yesterday while researching audio slideware. The use of tech is exemplary.
And since my dad re-builds Martin guitars—we visited the factory in PA once—I found the story compelling too

Too bad Dave lost The Battle of Leaky Knee today. Excellent weather for a jaunt up Super-Flag, and Greg and Rob were great stadium pals. Though the sandtraps were out in full force, there were nearly clear pathways through them.

Hope everything's sealed up, Davey!

comments.comment_body:
No me today; my knee misbehaved over the weekend and I'm unhorsed, at least for a day or so.

Drat.

DU

title: Fourmile Poor-Man Ride Report
author: Steve
body: Apparently, Fourmile is not Spare Underwood's Knees. Poor Dave! Hope you feel better, bud.

comments.comment_body:
Perfect call, Mr. Bailey!
See ya' at noon.

DU

title: Sunshine Canyon Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
Just chilled beats and melodies over here in HUMN 1B60

Though it was overcast, it was warm today, so much so that I wished I just had shorts. Oh well. Good steady pace, not many cyclists, and only a few ribbons of sand alongside the road.

comments.comment_body: I'm on probation until the end of the week. My doc fitted me w/ one of those little GPS/cattle-prod hybrids and I'm not even looking at the fence until he turns the damn thing off. -Barkless in the ATLAS Building

title: Northwest Passage Flag / Neva Loop Ride Report
author: Steve
body:
JG, you've seen Helvetica, but Dave's talking to Spielberg about a Si Bodwitz documentary. Interest?

Haven't heard from Julian or Cavs as to how their ride went. I'll bet it was nice, for it's in the 60s with little wind. [Thanks again for the invite, guys!]

I bailed on the Northwest Passage idea for two reasons: it's less fun when riding solo (though still fun) but more importantly, I've gotta get home early this afternoon.

Flagstaff was chock-full of cyclists, runners, and wanna-be F1 racers. I rode up in shorts and a short-sleeve jersey with the zipper down. Rode down with a vest on, but didn't really need it.

I suppose our only hope for knee-deep snow this year will be March, which will mean a day or two of big snows, followed by banana-belt 70°F weather. C'est la vie!

comments.comment_body:
JG, one problem with the whole fleet of "gelvetica" typefaces: not legible, especially in bright sunlight. Really gummed up my MacBook Pro.

The grass one was easier to use, but I was lost at the kerning instructions: To adjust, find trowel.

Oh I just remembered to tell you two: I wanted to point you in the direction of a version of helvetica done in toothpaste -- dubbed gelvetica. Lol! Also this awesome grass typer-do. Under #3 at the bottom, there you can try out writing in grass (a flash app, maybe?), and some of the letters even have baubles in them. Bauble is another great word, like muzzy or piffle.
Thanks, guys. You sure do write up an outstanding fake award and famous designer bio. What's a banana-belt? Is it what I think it is?

No me today... still resting the knee, as per Herr Doktor's wishes. Instead, I'll be attending a "Designers Without Borders" meeting w/ Jennifer.
